questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presented with features of paresthesias & difficulty walking. On examination, you are noticing the gait as shown below.

Which of the following conversion reactions will be affected in this patient?

choices.text: Methyl malonyl co-A to Succinyl Co-A

questions.solution:
In this, the patient diagnosed with Paresthesias and difficulty walking Showing ataxic gait, which
occurs due to vitamin B12 deficiency

  • Methylmolonyl CoA mutase is a vitamin B12 dependent enzyme and its deficiency leads to the accumulation of L -methyl malonyl CoA.
    .
  • Acid is excreted in urine called methyl malonyl aciduria.

option b.) Acetyl CoA to malonyl CoA conversion by acetyl CoA carboxylase require biotin.

Option c.) dUMP to dTMP conversion by enzyme thymidylate synthase require folic acid.

Option a) Homocysteine to cysteine require vit B6.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fight at a bar. He has difficulty breathing and pain in the chest. The pain increases on deep inspiration. On examination, breath sounds are decreased, and percussion is hyperresonant on the left side. Chest x-ray reveals tracheal deviation towards the right. Which of the following statements best describes the changes in lung and thoracic volume in this patient compared to normal?

choices.text:
Lung Volume
			Thoracic Volume
		
		
			Decreased
			Increased

Lung Volume
			Thoracic Volume
		
		
			Decreased
			Decreased

Lung Volume
			Thoracic Volume
		
		
			Increased
			Decreased

Lung Volume
			Thoracic Volume
		
		
			Decreased
			No change

questions.solution:
Option A: 

Lung Volume Thoracic Volume
Decreased Increased
  • This patient has developed pneumothorax on the left side after a stab wound.
  • It happens when air leaks into the pleural space. 
  • The elastic tendency of the lungs to collapse is exactly equal to the elastic tendency of the thoracic cage to expand under normal conditions.
  • But when air enters pleural space, the pleural pressure becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. Hence, the chest wall will expand, i.e., thoracic volume increases, and lungs will collapse, i.e., lung volume decreases in pneumothorax

Option B:

Lung Volume Thoracic Volume
Decreased Decreased
  • Lung volume is decreased in atelectasis, in which the lung tissue is collapsed, the trachea moves towards the same side, the diaphragm also moves up, and thoracic volume is decreased

Option C:

Lung Volume Thoracic Volume
Increased Decreased
  • In pneumothorax, the lung volume is decreased, and thoracic volume is increased. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Option D:

Lung Volume Thoracic Volume
Decreased No change
  • The lung volume is increased in emphysema, and chronic emphysema also increases the anteroposterior diameter of the chest (barrel-shaped chest.)

questions.text: A 10-month-old child had normal growth and development for the first few months, but growth started deteriorating gradually along with symptoms such as deafness, blindness, atrophied muscle, inability to swallow, and seizures. A cherry red macula was also noticed in both eyes during the fundus examination. Suspecting sphingolipidosis, the physician tested for globosides and gangliosides levels and found that both were increased. Based on this finding, what is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sandhoff s disease

  • The child is exhibiting the symptoms of either Tay–Sachs or Sandhoff s disease, both of which are sphingolipidoses. However, in Tay Sach's disease, only gangliosides will be increased, and globosides degradation should be normal. But in Sandhoff's disease, both globoside and gangliosides will accumulate.

Option B: Tay Sach's Disease:  refer to explanation of A

Option C: Gaucher's disease 

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disease
  • Enzyme deficient – Gluco-cerebrosidase
  • Substrate accumulated: Glucosyl Ceramide
  • C/F
    • No cherry red spots
    • Bony pain, pathological fractures
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • No Mental Retardation

ERT (Enzyme Replacement Therapy) is available.

Option D: Fabry's disease

  • Fabry’s disease is a X-linked recessive disorder characterized by deficiency of alpha galatoceramidase enzyme resulting in accumulation of CeramideTrihexoside or Globotriosyl Ceramide.
  • Patient presents with symptoms such as Triad of peripheral neuropathy, Angiokeratoma and Hypohidrosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the clinic with persistent allergic rhinitis and asthmatic episodes with peripheral hypereosinophilia. Histological findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Churg-Strauss syndrome

  • The above image shows eosinophil-rich vasculitis.

  • Churg-Strauss syndrome is a small-vessel necrotising vasculitis classically associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotising granulomas.

  • Vascular lesions can histologically resemble polyarteritis nodosa or microscopic polyangiitis but are also characteristically associated with granulomas and eosinophils.

Option A: Behçet Disease

  • Behcet disease is a systemic autoimmune vasculitis with an unknown cause.

  • Mucocutaneous symptoms, including recurrent oral and vaginal ulcerations, ocular signs, particularly chronic relapsing uveitis, and systemic vasculitis affecting arteries and veins of all sizes define it.

  • Behcet syndrome and malignant aphthosis are other names for it.

Option C: Kawasaki disease

  • Kawasaki disease is a febrile sickness that occurs in infancy and youth (80% of patients are 4 years old or less).

  • It is linked with arteritis that affects big, medium, and even tiny arteries.

  • Its clinical importance stems mostly from a proclivity for coronary artery involvement, which can result in burst aneurysms or thrombi, leading to acute myocardial infarction.

  • A strawberry tongue is a pathognomic sign of Kawasaki disease.

Option D: Buerger disease

  • Thromboangiitis obliterans, commonly known as Buerger disease, is a persistent, progressive inflammation and thrombosis (clotting) of the hands and feet's small and medium arteries and veins.

  • It is significantly related to the use of tobacco products, particularly smoking, but also smokeless tobacco.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presented with a history of left-sided chest pain of 1-week duration. She had no h/o trauma to her chest and denied mastalgia or discharge from the nipple. She had no systemic symptoms such as fever, loss of appetite, or loss of weight. ECG and ECHO turned out normal. She had no significant past medical or surgical history of note. On examination, a tender area on the left anterolateral part of her lower chest and abdomen with a vertical cord-like swelling just under the skin extending from the lower part of her left breast to the iliac fossa was noted. These findings were compatible with a clinical diagnosis of
questions.solution:
The above clinical features & findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Mondor's disease.

Mondor’s disease

  • aka String phlebitis is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall, although it may also occur in the arm.
  • Frequently involved veins: Lateral thoracic vein > thoracoepigastric vein >superficial epigastric vein.
  • Benign, self-limited disorder.

TREATMENT

  • NSAIDs & application of warm compresses

questions.text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman at 30 weeks of gestation is admitted to the labor room with a BP of 160/110 mmHg, urine albumin 1+ by dipstick. There is no complaint of headache, blurring of vision, epigastric pain, or decreased urine output. NST is reactive. Further management includes all except:

choices.text: Send for urgent CBC, LFT, and RFT
Immediate C section if cervix unfavorable

questions.text: A 32-year-old lethargic male was brought to the emergency department with a history of consumption of some drug. On investigation, he had low calcium, serum creatinine -3.8 mg/dL, raised BUN. On ABG, metabolic acidosis was noted. On urine examination, calcium oxalate crystals were observed. He was treated with 4-methyl pyrazole. What could be the probable drug ingestion leading to the following condition?
questions.solution:
The above history & investigations suggested the diagnosis of Ethylene glycol poisoning.

ETHYLENE GLYCOL

  • It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.
  • It is mainly used as an antifreeze agent and not absorbed through the skin.

SYMPTOMS:

    • Initial symptoms are vomiting, lethargy, ataxia, inebriation, convulsions, and coma.
    • In 12 to 24 hours tachycardia, tachypnoea and circulatory collapse, electrolyte imbalance and metabolic acidosis occur.
    • In one to three days, hypocalcemia, oliguria, tubular necrosis, and renal failure occur. Urine contains crystals of calcium oxalate.
  • FATAL DOSE: 100 ml

TREATMENT:

  1. Gastric lavage.
  2. Activated charcoal.
  3. Ethanol is the same dose as methyl alcohol.
  4. 4-methyl pyrazole →Fomepizole (Alcohol Dehydrogenase inhibitor).
  5. Haemodialysis.
  6. I.v. sodium bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30-weeks gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. The patient's due date was determined by a 7-week ultrasound. Her prenatal course has been unremarkable. She has no complaints of contractions, loss of fluid, or bleeding from the vagina, and her baby is moving well. Examination demonstrates a fetal heart rate of 150 and a fundal height of 27 centimeters, which is the same measurement as that determined 4 weeks ago. This patient's fundal height measurement is most suggestive of which of the following?

choices.text: Inaccurate estimated date of delivery (due date)

questions.solution:
Symphysisfundal height(SFH)measurementis commonly practiced primarily to detect fetalintrauterine growth restriction(IUGR). Serialmeasurementsoffundal heightare commonly used as a screening test forIUGRbut have high rates of false-negative and false-positive predictive values.

Between 20 and 36 weeks of gestation, fundal height should increase approximately 1 cm per week, consistent with gestational age in weeks. A discrepancy may be related to constitutional factors, but a significant discrepancy of more than 2 cm may indicateIUGR and the need for an ultrasound examination.

Fundal height measurement is a portion of the physical examination that should be performed routinely during prenatal care. It is performed by placing a measuring tape on the pubic symphysis and measuring to the top of the fundus. Between the gestational ages of 18 to 34 weeks, there is a rough correlation between weeks of gestation and fundal height in centimeters. For example, a woman at 26 weeks gestation should have a fundal height that is roughly 26 centimeters. This patient is at 30 weeks gestation and has a fundal height of 27 centimeters. Furthermore, and perhaps more importantly, there has been no change in the fundal height over the past four weeks. These findings are concerning for intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

IUGR is a disorder in which the fetus is not growing appropriately. It is most commonly defined as an estimated fetal weight less than the 10th percentile for a given gestational age. Given that this patient's fundal height does not appear to have increased over the past 4 weeks and that it is 3 centimeters less than expected, IUGR is of concern and this patient should be sent for an ultrasound to evaluate the fetal size.

This patient is unlikely to have an inaccurate estimated date of delivery (due date) (choice A) because her due date was determined by a 7-week ultrasound. Ultrasound dating of a pregnancy is more accurate the earlier in pregnancy that it is performed and a 7-week ultrasound is considered excellent for establishing a due date.

Premature labor (choice C) would not be a concern in this patient with no contractions and no other symptoms.

A twin gestation (choice D) should have been seen on the 7-week ultrasound. Furthermore, a fundal height that is less than the gestational age would predict makes twins less likely.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with acute-onset suprapubic pain and inability to pass urine for 2 days. On examination, the patient is in discomfort, neurologically intact, and the abdomen is particularly tender in the suprapubic region. A digital rectal examination reveals a smooth, enlarged prostate. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Bladder outflow obstruction due to prostate cancer
Bladder outflow obstruction due to benign prostatic hypertrophy
Bladder outflow obstruction due to a urethral stricture
Bladder outflow obstruction due to a spinal cord lesion

questions.solution:
The findings of the DRE suggest that this man has bladder outflow obstruction due to prostatic enlargement rather than the other causes mentioned in other options.

From the findings of the DRE, it seems evident that the prostate enlargement is most likely due to benign prostatic hypertrophy rather than prostatic carcinoma, which usually feels ‘craggy and nodular’ on DRE coupled with systemic symptoms such as back pain and weight loss, which may occur as a result of metastatic spread of the primary prostate carcinoma.

- Urethral strictures are uncommon in men and rare in women. They may arise due to recurrent infections of the urinary tract, trauma, or cancer, and can be congenital. Symptoms include dysuria, decreased stream, terminal dribbling, and ‘double stream’ when voiding.

- In addition, acute urinary retention may be caused by a spinal cord lesion which would have produced severe neurological complications such as paraesthesia and paralysis depending on the level of the spinal cord lesion; a history of trauma would also be present.

questions.text: In a child with Tetralogy of Fallot with fever and diarrhoea, which of the following is the surest sign of a cyanotic spell:

choices.text: Arterial oxygen saturation of less than 75%

questions.solution: Cyanotic spell (also known as Tet spell) is a common complication of tetralogy of Fallot in first year of life. It is characterized by worsening of cyanosis (with arterial SpO2 falling below 45-50%), hyperventilation and faint or absent pulmonary ejection systolic murmur. A child with a loud murmur initially, if presents with rapid breathing and cyanosis, absence of murmur is a useful clinical clue for cyanotic spell in that child. Remember: Hepatomegaly, basal crepitations and S3 gallop rhythm are signs of CCF in child

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of exertional chest pain. He first noticed the pain a couple of months ago when he was shoveling snow off his driveway and has since experienced several episodes while doing other strenuous tasks. He describes the pain as a heavy, crushing sensation and says it is relieved with rest. The patient undergoes coronary angiography and is found to have severe stenosis of the right coronary artery and left anterior descending and circumflex arteries. He is referred to a surgeon for coronary artery bypass grafting. During the procedure, a portion of his great saphenous vein is removed and grafted to one of the diseased coronary arteries to bypass its atherosclerotic narrowing. The vein used as a graft during this patient's procedure can be accessed at which of the following sites?

choices.text: At the midline of the popliteal fossa
Just inferior to the anterior superior iliac spine
Just inferolateral to the pubic tubercle
Just superior to the inguinal ligament

questions.solution:
*The site for accessing the great saphenous vein graft is just inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.

When the left anterior descending artery (LAD) alone is occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque, the left internal mammary (thoracic) artery is the preferred vessel for bypass grafting due to superior patency rates.

  • However, when multiple coronary arteries or vessels other than the LAD require revascularization, great saphenous vein grafts are routinely used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old butcher is admitted after stabbing himself with a knife inadvertently. His airway is patent and there are no identifiable hindrances to breathing. His pulse is 110 beats/min, BP is 130/105 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 25 breaths/min. Assuming a body mass of 70 kg, what is the best-estimated volume of blood lost?

choices.text: Impossible to say from given information

questions.solution:
Circulating volume accounts for approximately 7% of body mass. Therefore, a 70 kg adult has a circulating volume of 5 L. This rough guide is less reliable in children, in whom the circulating volume accounts for 8%–9% of body mass, or in obese people, in whom calculation should be based on their ideal body weight to avoid gross overestimation of blood loss.

Once the total volume has been calculated, estimate blood loss by assessing the class of shock.

Class I shock corresponds to a blood loss of up to 15% (750 mL in a 70 kg man).

Class II shock equates to 15%–30% blood loss (750–1500 mL).

class III to 30%–40% (1500–2000 mL).

Class IV shock accounts for blood loss of over 40%.

- Therefore, in this scenario, with the patient in class II shock, the best Answer would be B (1000 mL blood loss)

questions.text: A 36-week preterm female infant is now 4 hours old. She was born via emergency LSCS for breech position after preterm labor. Her mother was given 1.2 g IV benzylpenicillin 3 hours before delivery. She cried soon after birth and her birth weight was 2600 g. In the last hour, the baby has had four episodes where she stopped breathing for >20 seconds, her heart rate dropping to <80 beats per minute, and her oxygen saturation decreased to <70%. She requires firm stimulation by the nursing staff to resolve these episodes. Between episodes her oxygen saturation is normal. She is not currently on any medications. Which one of the following options is the most appropriate next step in the management of her apnoea?

choices.text: Commence caffeine for apnoea of prematurity.
Perform a sepsis work-up and commence IV antibiotics.
Start mask continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)

questions.solution:
• This baby is at risk of sepsis because of maternal PPROM (for which she received antibiotics) and preterm labor. In spite of the intrapartum antibiotics, the baby is now symptomatic. The other measures may be useful in the acute management of apnoea, but the priority should be to treat for possible infection.
  • It would be unusual for apnoea of prematurity to present in a 35-week gestation infant, particularly at 4 hours of age. (It usually presents in a < 34-week preterm and that too after 1- 2 days of life)

questions.text: A small disk of neoprene with metal periphery ensures a gas-tight fit between the cylinder and anesthetic machine yoke in the form of seal (shown in the figure) is called as?
questions.solution:
Bodok seal
A small disk of neoprene with a metal periphery ensures a gas-tight fit between the cylinder and the anesthetic machine yoke in the form of a seal. Under no circumstances, may oil or grease be used as a seal; the pressurized gases give off heat as they are released from the cylinder and may cause explosions if oil is used.
Before attaching a full cylinder to the machine briefly open and close the cylinder valve to clear any dirt from the port. This is called cracking the cylinder.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presented with a history of dyspnea and recurrent bronchitis. On auscultation, a loud systolic murmur was detected. Her clinical examination was otherwise normal. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was done in the patient which showed an incomplete bundle branch block in the precordial lead. This is most consistent with which of the following?

choices.text: A sinus venosus Atrial septal defect with partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
An ostium primum Atrial septal defect

questions.solution:
Many patients with secundum ASDs have an incomplete bundle branch block on their ECG. This is in contradistinction to patients with ostium primum defects, who often have a left axis deviation

An atrial septal defect (ASD) is defined as discontinuity of the interatrial septum that permits direct mixing of the systemic venous and pulmonary venous circulation

ASDs can be classified into three different types

  • ostium secondum type defect(deficiency of septum primum) - most prevalent (80%)
  • ostium primum defects also described as partial or transitional AV canal defect
  • sinus venosus type defects occurs as the result of embryologic malalignment between the superior vena cava or inferior venacava . These defects are not associated with the ovale fossa and are frequently associated with the partial anomalous pulmonary venous return(PAPVR)

ASDs result in an increased pulmonary blood flow secondary to left to right shunting through the defect which in turn causes right ventricular volume overload which leads to right ventricular hypertrophy with elevated right ventricular end-diastolic pressure and relative pulmonary stenosis across the pulmonary valve because it cannot accommodate the increased right ventricular flow

On auscultation, they reveal the prominence of the first heart sound with the fixed splitting of the second heart sound. A diastolic flow murmur across the tricuspid valve and ejection flow murmur across the pulmonary valve may be heard

The electrocardiogram shows right axis deviation with an incomplete bundle branch block. When the right bundle branch block is associated with a leftward or superior axis, an AV canal defect should be strongly suspected

Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD) are a complex constellation of cardiac lesions involving deficiency of the atrial septum, ventricular septum, and A-V valves

questions.text: Four populations had Correlation coefficients of + 0.6, each for weight and Height when plotted together. What would be the Net coefficient of correlation?
questions.solution:
• Generally, different correlation coefficients (r) cannot be averaged directly: as the value of ‘r’ is not a linear function of the magnitude of the relation between 2 variables
  • Average can be taken directly for coefficient of determination (r2)
  • In the given question (and graph), all correlation coefficient are same (+0.6), so their coefficient of determination would also be same (+ 0.62 =+ 0.36 for each distribution)

Hence, they can be averaged to come out to be exactly “+0.6”

Combined correlation coefficient = √ (0.36 + 0.36 + 0.36 + 0.36)/4 = + 0.6

questions.text: Twenty-four hours after colon resection, urine output in a 70-year-old man is 10 mL/h. Blood chemistry analysis reveals sodium, 138 mEq/L; potassium, 6 mEq/L; chloride, 100 mEq/L; bicarbonate, 14 mEq/L. His metabolic abnormality is characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia can manifest by GI or cardiovascular signs.

  • GI symptoms include nausea, vomiting, intestinal colic, and diarrhea.
  • Abdominal distension as a result of paralytic ileus is due to hypokalemia.
  • An ECG is useful to monitor potassium levels. Hyperkalemia is characterized by peaked T waves. ECG changes also include ST-segment depression, widened QRS complex, and heart block. Cardiac arrest occurs in diastole with increasing levels of potassium. Osborne (J) wave is seen in hypothermia.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to thrive. A liver biopsy reveals glycogen with an abnormal, amylopectin-like structure, as shown below:



Which of the following enzymes would most likely be deficient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Branching enzyme

  • The above clinical features & findings are indicative of Anderson’s disease/Amylopectinosis (GSD Type IV) due to deficiency of branching enzyme.
  • In this disease, stored glycogen is abnormal, with long polysaccharide chains having only a few branch points which resemble the amylopectin component of the starch.
  • Other clinical features are hepatosplenomegaly and death from heart or liver failure before age 5.

​​​​​​​Option A: Alpha-amylase

  • Alpha-amylase secreted by the pancreas digests starch into Limit dextrins, maltose, and maltotriose.
  • Increased plasma levels of this enzyme in humans are found in:
    • Salivary trauma
    • Mumps
    • Pancreatitis
    • Kidney failure

Option C: Debranching enzyme

  • The main clinical feature associated with deficiency of debranching enzyme is the accumulation of limit dextrins (glycogen remains having shorter linear chains with very short branch points) in the liver under fasting.
  • In this patient, an amylopectin-like structure is observed, but no limit dextrins were noted.

Option D: Glucose-6-phosphatase

  • The deficiency of this enzyme does not affect the glycogen structure.
  • This enzyme’s deficiency is seen in Von Gierke’s disease.
  • The main clinical feature of this enzyme deficiency is severe fasting hypoglycemia, Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: What treatment is recommended for a 45-year-old male with schizophrenia who developed fever, diarrhea, confusion, high blood pressure, rapid pulse, muscle rigidity, hyperkalemia, and increased creatine kinase after 8 days of haloperidol treatment?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dantrolene

  • The patient has a history of schizophrenia and has recently started using haloperidol. Haloperidol is a first-generation (conventional) antipsychotic that works by competitive blockade of dopamine D2 receptors.
  • The signs and symptoms of generalized muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability (labile blood pressure, diarrhoea, and tachycardia), and altered mental status; associated with antipsychotics are indicative of neuroleptic malignant syndrome. 
  • The neuroleptic malignant syndrome can result in (as in this case) elevation of serum potassium and creatine kinase due to vigorous muscle contraction.
  • The management plan for the neuroleptic malignant syndrome includes:
    • Prompt discontinuation of the antipsychotic drug (haloperidol in this case)
    • Supportive care includes assessing and maintaining the airway, breathing, and circulation.
    • Pharmacotherapy comprises the use of dantrolene. Dantrolene is an antagonist of the Ryanodine receptor and works by preventing the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscle cells. This leads to a decrease in the magnitude of muscle rigidity, and resultantly hyperthermia is inhibited too.

Option A: Diazepam

  • Diazepam belongs to the benzodiazepine class of drugs.
  • Benzodiazepines can help relieve psychomotor agitation in such cases; however, dantrolene is the pharmacotherapy of choice for managing neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option B: Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is used to treat the toxicity of benzodiazepines. It is not used in the management of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: High dose of haloperidol

  • The patient’s current signs and symptoms are already caused by the adverse reaction to haloperidol. So, the management includes discontinuation of this drug.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child with developmental delay was brought with squint & bilateral lens subluxation. After 4 years, he dies of massive stroke. Autopsy reveals middle cerebral artery thrombosis and old renal infracts. Disease course could have been modified by supplement of:
questions.solution:
The given history of developmental delay, lens subluxation & stroke (thrombosis) points to a diagnosis of homocystinuria.

⇒Pyridoxine (Vit B6) is used in the treatment of

  • Homocystinuria,
  • Cystathioninuria,
  • Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy,
  • Vitamin B6–responsive anemia
  • Xanthurenic aciduria.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida, term, severe pre-eclamptic woman on magnesium therapy was posted for emergency lower segment caesarean section under general anaesthesia with rapid sequence induction (RSI). Neuromuscular monitoring with a peripheral nerve stimulator was used, and the maintenance doses were given accordingly during the intraoperative period. At the end of the surgery, when the train of four (TOF) ratio > 0.9, the patient was reversed with Inj. Neostigmine and glycopyrrolate were then extubated. Which of the following anaesthetic shows the absence of fade in TOF response?
questions.solution:
Option A: Succinylcholine

  • Depolarising neuromuscular blockers (Succinylcholine) do not show fade in a train of four response.
  • Non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers (Vecuronium, Mivacurium, Rocuronium) show fade in a train of four response.
  • Single twitch:  Application of a single supramaximal stimulus every 10 seconds. The twitch height falls steadily to zero as the nicotinic postsynaptic receptor occupancy increases from 25% or 80% up to 100%
  • Train of four: Train of four stimulation is the application of four supramaximal stimuli, each similar to the single twitch, administered at 2Hz every 0.5 seconds. The degree of neuromuscular blockade was assessed by calculating the ratio of fourth (T4) and first(T1) measured twitch heights(T4/T1)
  • Post-tetanic count: It describes counting responses to single twitch stimulation following tetanic stimulation of 50Hz or 100Hz for 5 seconds. This method can produce a response at relatively high levels of receptor occupancy under a post-tetanic count of less than 5, indicating profound neuromuscular blockade.
  • Double burst stimulation: It is introduced to remove the manual assessment of fade. This consists of two tetanic bursts at 50Hz each burst is separated by 750milliseconds, two contractions (T1, T2). The ratio of T2/T1 is more sensitive in detecting fade than the train of four ratios.

Option B: Mivacurium

  • Mivacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; it shows a fade of a train of four response.

Option C: Vecuronium

  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; it shows the fade of a train of four responses.

Option D: Rocuronium

  • Rocuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; it shows a fade of a train of four responses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes has an early feeling of fullness when eating. She is often nauseous after a meal and vomits about once a week after eating. Glucose-induced damage to which structure is most likely to explain her gastrointestinal problem?
questions.solution:
• This woman has gastroparesis (also called delayed gastric emptying). This disorder slows or at times even stops the movement of chyme from the stomach to the duodenum.
  • Diabetes is the most common known cause of gastroparesis; it occurs in about 20 percent of persons with type 1 diabetes. The high blood glucose is thought to damage the vagus nerve and thereby delay gastric emptying.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female was claimed to be kidnapped, on interrogation she claims that she is not a minor and left home with the person of her own will. The Court ordered for her age estimation. Given below are the x-ray of the pelvis, wrist, and bilateral elbow. What is her most probable age based on these?
questions.solution:
According to IPC 351, if the age of a person is less than 18 years i.e. if he/she is a minor, it would be a case of kidnapping if she is abducted from lawful guardianship even on her own will.

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 deals with sexual offenses against persons below 18 years of age, who are deemed as children.

Elbow X-Ray findings- All the ossification centers are completely fused so the age is greater than 16 years.

Wrist X-Ray findings- The lower ends of Radius and Ulna are fused so the age is greater than 18 years.

Pelvis X-Ray findings- Ischial tuberosity appears at 16 years and fuses at 21 years. So the age is greater than 21 years as per X-Ray.

questions.text: Following a sudden impact in an accident, the 34-year-old race car driver becomes unconscious and is admitted to the hospital. A CT scan is performed, and a right space-occupying lesion is noted as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acute epidural hematoma

  • The above features & CT- findings are suggestive of Acute epidural hematoma.
  • Acute EDH is associated with high-energy trauma, underlying fracture, and lucid interval.
  • Acute subdural hematomas occur most commonly when violent accelerations or deceleration injuries of the head cause tearing of the bridging veins within the potential subdural space.
  • They generally imply a much more severe injury to the brain itself than in the case of their epidural counterpart.
  • For this reason, they are associated with cerebral contusions in over 30% of cases.

Option A: Corpus callosum injury

  • Corpus callosum injury predominantly occurs in the posterior half of the corpus callosum.
  • Closed head injury due to acceleration or deceleration may cause damage to the brain parenchyma, which is believed to result from shear strain.
  • Closed-head traumas frequently damage the corpus callosum, and the resulting deficits of interhemispheric communication may vary according to the specific position of the lesion within the corpus callosum.
  • Left intentional movement apraxia, agraphia, left tactile anomia, dyslexia, alien hand syndrome, decreased left visual recognition, and left auditory hearing loss are all symptoms of corpus callosum injury, referred to as "corpus callosum syndrome."

Option B: Pituitary apoplexy

  • Apoplexy refers to bleeding into an organ or a reduction in organ blood flow.
  • Pituitary apoplexy is commonly caused by bleeding inside a pituitary's noncancerous (benign) tumor.
  • These tumors are very common and are often not diagnosed.
  • The pituitary is damaged when the tumor suddenly enlarges.

Option C: Acute subdural hematoma

  • A dangerous disorder called subdural hematoma occurs when blood builds up between the skull and the brain's surface. Usually, a head injury is a culprit.
  • One of the signs of a subdural hemorrhage is a headache that does not go away. Being unwell and feeling sick.
  • A head injury usually causes subdural hematomas.
  • Severe head injuries, such as those sustained in vehicle accidents, falls, or violent assaults, frequently result in subdural hemorrhages. In rare instances, minor head injuries can also result in subdural hemorrhages.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is mauled by a black bear while hiking with his family in the Appalachian Mountains. A claw-puncture wound to the skull compressed the underlying brain tissue. Which of the following occurs in response to an increased intracranial pressure?

choices.text: Blood pressure and heart rate decrease.
Blood pressure and heart rate increase
Blood pressure and heart rate remain constant.
Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases.

questions.solution:
An increased intracranial pressure compresses the cerebral vessels, thereby reducing cerebral blood flow. The increase in intracranial pressure stimulates the vasomotor center and produces an increased systemic blood pressure that may lead to a restoration of cerebral blood flow.

The increased blood pressure induces bradycardia mediated by the baroreceptor reflex. This response to increased intracranial pressure is part of Cushing triad, which includes hypertension, bradycardia, and respiratory depression

Ref Ganong 24th p574-577

questions.text:
With reference to Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) being used on vaccine vials, which of the following statements is/are correct?

It gives information about heat exposure over a period of time
It directly indicates vaccine potency

Select the answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
The VVM does not directly measure vaccine potency but it gives information about the main factor that affects potency i.e. heat exposure over a period of time.

A vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is a label containing a heat-sensitive material that is placed on a vaccine vial to register cumulative heat exposure over time. The combined effects of time and temperature cause the inner square of the VVM to darken, gradually and irreversibly. A direct relationship exists between the rate of color change and temperature:

  • The lower the temperature, the slower the color change.
  • The higher the temperature, the faster the color change. The VVM is a circle with a small square inside it. It can be printed on a product label, attached to the cap of a vaccine vial or tube, or attached to the neck of an ampoule.

questions.text: A 79-year-old male in the ICU experiences sudden onset tachycardia and chest pain. He then becomes unconscious. The rhythm on ECG is as shown below. What is your management?
questions.solution:
The above ecg shows ventricular tachycardia. The Patient shows symptoms of unstable tachyarrythmia.
The recommended management for this patient is synchronised cardioversion.(4)

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with sudden visual loss affecting the right temporal region. Ultrasound of the globe demonstrated right-sided retinal detachment with a well-defined flat echogenic mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ocular melanoma

  • Choroidal melanoma is adults' most common primary intraocular malignancy and accounts for 80% of all uveal melanomas.
  • The incidence of this tumor increases with age.
  • Clinical presentation may range from no symptoms over various visual disturbances to visual loss.
  • Ultrasound is an excellent modality for examining the globe and can visualize small plaque-like or discoid uveal melanoma with a thickness of less than 3 mm, which are usually difficult to assess on CT or MRI.
  • Typical USG Features include hypo-to-isoechoic "collar button" or "mushroom" shaped lobulated mass with internal vascularity.

Option A: Choroidal metastases

  • Choroidal metastases are the most frequent malignant intraocular tumor. In most cases, they arise after identifying the primary tumor and are associated with the involvement of other organs.
  • Less frequently, the ocular lesion may be the first presentation of a primary tumor or relapse of a primary disseminated tumor.
  • Enhanced choroid imaging allows a better understanding and precise diagnosis of choroidal metastases.
  • If the primary remains unknown, tumor biopsy may help identify the primary and guide treatment.
  • To date, fractionated radiotherapy remains the treatment of choice for choroidal metastases.

Option B: Orbital hematoma

  • Orbital hematomas may occur spontaneously due to vascular anomalies, or they may be induced by trauma or occur following paranasal sinus surgery.
  • The retrobulbar hematoma requires special attention because its potential optic nerve compression may compromise vision or cause blindness.
  • Orbital hematoma has been described as a rare complication of trans-nasal endoscopic sinus surgery (<0.4% cases).
  • Other causes were .trauma, vascular malformation, orbital neoplastic or non-neoplastic lesions, bleeding disorders, and barotrauma during anesthesia.

Option D: Ocular hemangioma

  • A hemangioma can grow red to the red-purple raised lesion on the skin and sometimes get very large.
  • When hemangiomas grow on the eyelids, the eye surface, or the eye socket, they can interrupt the normal development of vision. Hemangiomas can affect vision in several ways.
  • These conditions can be life-threatening if they are large or affect a child's airway or another organ.
  • A hemangioma can also be serious if it has uncontrollable bleeding.
  • Where a child's growth is located may cause physical problems.

questions.text: A G2P1 female at 35 weeks experiences uterine contractions. No fetal distress is seen and membranes are not ruptured. Which of the following is to be done?
questions.solution:
The patient is having uterine contractions at 35 weeks of pregnancy.

At 35 weeks:

There is no role of Betamethasone (corticosteroid).”Current evidence supports the administration of a single course of antenatal corticosteroids between 24-34 weeks to enhance fetal lung maturation.

Tocolytic therapy: It is given for short-time use so that corticosteroids can act. Since at 35 weeks, there is no role of corticosteroid, So, therefore, no role of Tocolytic.

Cervical cerclage – no role at 35 weeks. Done before 32 weeks.

*Vaginal/rectal swab culture should be sent to detect group B streptococcus

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the department of Anaesthesiology. You are observing a procedure being done by an Anaesthetist (shown below). Identify the procedure:
questions.solution:
• Conduction anesthesia in which small nerves are not anesthetized individually,as in nerve block anesthesia , but instead are blocked en masse by local anesthetic solution injected to form a barrier proximal to operative site.
  • In the field block, anesthetic is infiltrated to the subcutaneous area surrounding the operative field. The needle is inserted at two points, and anesthetic solution is injected along four lines (walls) that surround the area to be anesthetized. The shape of the anesthetic field can be modified by changing the number and direction of the anesthetic walls.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man visits his physician because his chest hurts when he eats, especially when he eats meat. He also belches excessively and has heartburn. His wife says he has bad breath. A radiograph shows a dilated esophagus. Which pressure tracing shown in the figure was most likely taken at the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) of this patient before and after swallowing (indicated by the arrow)? [The dotted line represents a pressure of 0 mm Hg]
questions.solution:
Achalasia is a condition in which the LES fails to relax during swallowing. As a result, food swallowed into the esophagus fails to pass from the esophagus into the stomach.

  • Trace C shows a high, positive pressure that fails to decrease after swallowing, which is indicative of achalasia.
  • Trace A shows a normal pressure tracing at the level of the LES, reflecting typical receptive relaxation in response to the food bolus.
  • Trace E is similar to trace C, but the pressures are subatmospheric. Subatmospheric pressures occur only in the esophagus where it passes through the chest cavity.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man developed neck and left arm pain. He noted paresthesias in the left index and long fingers. He was found to have weakness of the left triceps muscle and a diminished left triceps jerk. His left-sided disc herniation is most likely to be at:-
questions.solution:
DISCUSSION:

This patient has all of the neurologic components of the most common cervical disc syndrome, that caused by a herniation at the C6–C7 level with compression of the C7 nerve root.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with progressive loss of voice, numbness, and loss of taste on the back part of her tongue. MRI reveals a dural meningioma compressing nerves exiting the skull. Through which opening do these nerves leave the skull?
questions.solution:
Option D: Jugular foramen

  • The jugular foramen is a cavity formed by the anteriorly petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone posteriorly.
  • Its major function is to act as a conduit for essential structures to pass through.
  • The foramina exist lateral to the occipital condyles when viewing the skull as inferior to superior from an extracranial aspect.
  • Additionally, it sits directly posterior to the carotid canal. The external acoustic meatus, which resides within the temporal bone, is lateral and superior to the jugular foramen.
  • Following Structure Passes through this foramen: Mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve, Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery, Lateral petrosal nerve, and Emissary's vein.

Option A: Foramen spinosum

  • The foramen spinosum is a foramen in the sphenoid bone of the skull. It connects the middle cranial fossa to the infratemporal fossa. It is posterolateral to the foramen ovale and anterior to the sphenoidal spine.
  • The foramen spinosum permits the passage of the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and the meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve.

Option B: Foramen rotundum

  • The foramen rotundum is a circular hole in the sphenoid bone of the skull.
  • It connects the middle cranial fossa and the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • It allows for the passage of the maxillary nerve (V2), a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Option C: Internal auditory meatus

  • The internal auditory canal (IAC), also referred to as the internal acoustic meatus, lies in the temporal bone and exists between the inner ear and posterior cranial fossa.
  • It includes the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII), facial nerve (CN VII), the labyrinthine artery, and the vestibular ganglion.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old girl presenting with recurrent episodes of bulky stools, abdominal pain, early satiety, and poor growth, which investigation is most reliable for making a specific diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Small intestinal biopsy

  • A small intestinal biopsy is diagnostic in this case. Small intestinal biopsy changes can be categorized as mild, moderate, or severe based on architectural abnormalities, which may help determine the diagnosis. The biopsy results for some small intestine illnesses characterized by diarrhoea or malabsorption may be distinct and help identify a particular diagnosis, like coeliac or cystic fibrosis.

Option B: Barium studies

  • A barium study of the GI tract is usually performed to diagnose GI tract abnormalities, such as tumours, ulcers, and other inflammatory disorders, polyps, hernias, and strictures, not for malabsorption syndromes.

Option C: 72 hours of faecal fat estimation

  • For fat malabsorption, faecal fat estimation is done in 24 hours. If the test is positive, testing continues to a 72-hour faecal fat excretion study. Faecal fat is quantified from a single specimen. It is the gold standard for diagnosing steatorrhea.
  • Sudan III stain, a sensitive procedure used on a spot stool sample.

Option D: Urinary D-xylose test

  • D-Xylose is a monosaccharide that does not require enzymes for digestion before absorption. Its absorption requires an intact mucosa only.
  • In normal individuals, a 25 g oral dose of D-xylose will be absorbed and excreted in the urine at approximately 4.5 g in 5 hours. Reduced urinary excretion of D-xylose is seen in small intestinal bacterial overgrowth and Whipple's disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male visits the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers, generalized weakness, fatigue, loss of weight, and cough for the last two weeks. He has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse during the previous few months. Cervical lymphadenopathy is found on physical examination. Viral markers are done, and the HIV test is positive. Which of the following may be the first indication of clinical immunodeficiency in HIV-infected patients?
questions.solution:
Option D: Herpes Zoster

  • Reactivation syndrome of varicella-zoster virus (shingles) indicates a modest decline in immune function and may be the first indication of clinical immunodeficiency.
  • In a child with healed chicken pox, the virus may remain dormant in trigeminal ganglia, which can reactivate later in life.
  • Reactivation of herpes zoster is seen in several patients with HIV infection.
  • Presents as Unilateral, grouped painful vesicles along a dermatome.
  • Valacyclovir, acyclovir, or famciclovir is the treatment of choice.

Option A: Vitiligo

  • Depigmented/ White Lesions due to the absence of Melanocytes.
  • Autoimmune condition (Antibodies destroy melanocytes).
  • No established association with HIV infection.

Option B: Lichen planus

  • Characterized by pruritic, purple, planar, polygonal, papules, and plaques
  • It has no established association with HIV infection

Option C: Trichotillomania

  • Characterized by patchy hair loss secondary to recurrent, uncontrollable hair pulling
  • Often associated with stress
  • No association is seen with HIV infection

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who is a case of Gas gangrene due to Clostridium perfringens infection treated with hyperbaric oxygen therapy with 2.5 atmospheric pressures. After 5 sittings, rapid control of infection associated with toxaemia was achieved and the culture showed devoid of C.perfringens. This hyperbaric oxygen therapy also indicated in-
questions.solution:
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy uses a pressurized chamber to expose the patient to oxygen tensions exceeding ambient barometric pressure (at sea level the ambient pressure is 760 mm Hg).

Indications for Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy

- Gas bubble disease

  • Decompression sickness (the “bends”)
  • Gas embolism

- Poisoning

  • Carbon monoxide, cyanide, carbon tetrachloride, hydrogen sulphide

- Infections

  • Clostridial myonecrosis
  • Other soft tissue necrotizing infections
  • Intracranial abscess
  • Mucormycosis
  • Refractory chronic osteomyelitis

- Acute Ischemia

  • Crush injury
  • compromised skin flaps
  • Central retinal artery and vein occlusion

- Chronic Ischemia

  • Radiation necrosis(Soft tissue, radiation cystitis and osteoradionecrosis)
  • Ischemic ulcers including diabetic ulcers

- Acute hypoxia

  • Exceptional blood loss anemia (when transfusion delayed or unavailable)
  • Support of oxygenation during therapeutic lung lavage

- Burns, Brown recluse spider bite, Idiopathic sudden sensory neural hearing loss

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for an annual physical check-up. He is tall and has a bulging, “bird-like” chest. The boy’s joints are hypermobile with long and tapered fingers. His father suffered an aortic aneurysm at a young age. A mutation in which of the following genes is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
FBN1 codes for fibrillin protein. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue, which is the material between cells of the body that gives the tissues form and strength. Connective tissue is found all over the body and multiple organ systems may be affected in individuals with Marfan syndrome.

  • The heart and blood vessels (cardiovascular), skeletal, and eye (ocular) systems are most often affected.
  • Major symptoms include overgrowth of the long bones of the arms and legs, abnormal side-to-side curvature of the spine (scoliosis), indentation or protrusion of the chest wall (pectus deformity), dislocation of the lenses of the eyes (ectopia lentis), nearsightedness (myopia), widening (aneurysm) and tear (dissection) of the main artery that carries blood away from the heart (aorta), floppiness of the mitral valve (mitral valve prolapse) and backward flow of blood through the aortic and mitral valves (aortic and mitral regurgitation).
  • The specific symptoms and the severity of Marfan syndrome vary greatly from person to person. Marfan syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait, meaning that only one abnormal copy of the Marfan gene inherited from one parent is sufficient to have the condition.
  • Defects or deletions (pathogenic variants) of the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene have been shown to cause Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old carpenter was brought to you with a history of fall from the roof. Physical examination revealed flattened lateral longitudinal arch of the foot from fracture and displacement of the keystone for the arch. Which of the following bones is damaged?
questions.solution:
CHOICE EXPLANATION & ELIMINATION REASON
1 Forms lateral arch
2 Forms medial arch
3 Forms medial arch
4 Forms medial arch

Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY

PROBABLE QUESTIONS

  • Lateral longitudinal arch – calcaneum, cuboid, fourth and fifth metatarsal bone

questions.text:
ASSERTION - Inverted uterus causes postpartum haemorrhage
REASON - Inverted uterus causes a local coagulopathy reaction to the uterus and endometrium

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true
Both A and R is false

questions.solution:
The assertion is true, but the reason is false.

*Inverted uterus leads to inability for an adequate myometrial contraction effect. An inverted uterus makes it impossible for the uterus to establish its normal tone, and to contract. Thus, the myometrial fibers do not exert their normal tourniquet effect on the spiral arteries. The endometrial placental bed pours out blood, which previously had been perfusing the intervillous space. Thus, uterine atony is the most common reason for hemorrhage in the inverted uterus. The muscle of the uterus and the vasculature is seldom damaged.

- Replacing the uterus to its normal position and assisting tonicity of the uterus will alleviate the bleeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old solicitor presents to the urology outpatients department with a 6-month history of abnormal angulated penis on erection. This has made sexual intercourse particularly difficult and painful and has been affecting his relationship with his wife. After further questioning, a diagnosis of Peyronie’s disease is offered. All of the following statements regarding Peyronie’s disease are true, except:

choices.text: It is a connective tissue disorder of unknown origin
It is the result of a gene mutation on chromosome 6
Surgical treatment is considered only 1 year after initial presentation

questions.solution:
*It is the result of a gene mutation on chromosome 5.

Peyronie’s disease is an eponymously named connective tissue disorder of unknown origin, resulting in the growth of fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea and the corpus cavernosum. The disease affects approximately 1% of mainly middle-aged men, causing the penis to curve abnormally on erection (at the point at which fibrous plaques are present), and resulting in pain. The presence of pain and abnormal penile curvature can make sexual intercourse difficult and lead to erectile dysfunction. The condition is also associated with Dupuytren’s and plantar fascial contractures.

Treatment is initially conservative for 1 year to allow the disease process and pain to stabilize. ESWL can be used to soften or destroy the penile plaque, but there haven’t been any long-term follow-up studies of this procedure.

Surgical management is generally considered after 1 year especially if the condition is causing sexual dysfunction. Three main procedures are used:

  • Nesbit’s operation – Tunica albuginea on the opposite side of the offending plaque is excised, leading to return of normal curvature but also penile shortening.
  • Plaque excision and patching – Can lead to softer erections.
  • Implantation of penile prosthesis – Straightens penis in men with pre-existing erectile dysfunction

questions.text: Mr. Ramesh, a business man has taken multiple bank loans from a nationalized bank and unable to make payments. He has been brought for psychiatric evaluation as recently he has been denying any memory of taking loans from the bank. Interestingly, all other memory functioning is pretty intact. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Option A: Dissociative Amnesia

  • Commonest clinical type of dissociative disorder.
  • Occurs mostly in late adolescence and young adults.
  • Severe psychological trauma, the patient temporarily and unconsciously shuts down the memory of the traumatic event
  • Circumscribed loss of traumatic memory is seen in these individuals
  • The other memories are intact and this cannot be explained by normal forgetting

Option B: Dissociative fugue

  • Loss of memory for some personal autobiographical information combined with unexpected and sudden travel.
  • The travel is unexpected but is to a place with an emotional significance.
  • May involve confusion about identity or assumption of a new identity

Option C: Dissociative Identity Disorder

  • Presence of 2 or more distinct personality identities, each having a unique name, personal history and characteristics
  • Usually unaware of each other's existence

Option D: Dissociative Autonomic Dysfunction

  • Motor, sensory or cognitive deficit
  • Lack of concern or indifference to symptoms

Learning Objective

  • Dissociation is disruption in normally integrated functions of memory, identity, perception, consciousness and motor behaviour. It usually has a sudden onset and is associated with a psychological stressor.
  • Treatment
    • Supportive psychotherapy, cognitive therapy, hypnosis.
    • Identify trauma related cognitive distortions and help the individual cope with adaptive behaviours
    • Drug assisted interview could be beneficial to elicit information- abreaction (not recommended in children)

questions.text:
A 30-years-old third gravida, who has a 3-years-old child and had undergone an MTP 1 year ago, has presented with 30-weeks of gestation. She complains of having had vaginal bleeding 2 hours ago. She has not received any antenatal care. On examination, her pulse is 78 beats per minute and the BP is 102/58 mmHg. She has moderate pallor, her abdomen is soft, and the fetal heart rate is 130 beats per minute. The most appropriate management will be:

Ultrasonographic evaluation
Watch for labor
Hospitalization and bed rest
Speculum examination of vagina and cervix
Intravenous fluid drip

Select the appropriate treatment using the code given below:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is antepartum haemorrhage.

  • As she is multipara, she has no antenatal care and also a history of MTP, so she is at a high risk for placenta previa hence ultrasound for localization of placenta should be done.
  • She needs to be given bed rest. And as blood pressure and fetal heart are below normal, IV fluids are to be given. We cannot wait and watch because if it is a case of placenta previa it will cost her life, and it is better to localize placenta before doing vaginal examination.

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy is brought to his primary care physician for evaluation of oral patches. A review of his medical record indicates a history of recurrent otitis media, pneumonia, chronic diarrhoea and failure to thrive. Family history is non-contributory. Physical examination demonstrates a malnourished child who appears small for his age. Oropharyngeal examination demonstrates scrapable white patches on the tongue but is otherwise unremarkable. Serum electrophoresis reveals low immunoglobulin levels, and a chest x-ray shows an absent thymic shadow.Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Adenosine deaminase

  • SCID is the most severe form of primary immunodeficiency and may result from an X-linked recessive defect in the IL-2R gamma chain or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in ADA deficiency. This disorder results in deficient B-cell and T-cells, causing failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, thrush, and recurrent infections., This severe form of primary immunodeficiency may result from an X-linked recessive defect in the IL-2R gamma chain (most common) or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in adenosine deaminase (ADA ) deficiency.

 

Option A: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase is important for intracellular bacterial killing via the catalyzation of hypochlorite from hydrogen peroxide and chloride. Deficiency of this enzyme does present with recurrent Candida infections, but failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and recurrent pneumonia are atypical.

 

Option B: NADPH oxidase

  • A deficiency of NADPH oxidase occurs in chronic granulomatous disease, which results in an inability of phagocytes to produce hydrogen peroxide in their lysosomes. Recurrent abscesses from catalase-positive organisms are a classic clinical feature. Failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and oral thrush are atypical of this condition.

 

Option C: Pyruvate kinase

  • A deficiency of pyruvate kinase is a common cause of chronic hemolytic anaemia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old morbidly obese diabetic woman underwent a gastric bypass about 12 hours ago. The operation was technically difficult but finally went well. You are called because she now has a temperature of 99.2 F, pulse of 134, and some pain in her incision and her back. She looks well; the incision is clean, and her examination is otherwise negative. A bolus of 500 ml of dextrose/lactated Ringer's did not change her vital signs, except that her pulse rose to 140 without an increase in urine output. Your next step should be:

choices.text: Obtain white cell count, differential count, and electrolyte values
Call the operating room and inform them that you need to re-explore for a leak

questions.solution:
Morbidly obese patients are malnourished and brittle and have little resistance. Serious life-threatening infections may soil the peritoneal cavity without producing any sign except a persistently high pulse rate.

The usual tests listed in A, B, and C, should be done, but the most likely explanation for a continued high pulse is soiling in the area of the surgery due to either a leak or contamination and the development of sepsis. Because of the unreliability of clinical evaluation, the indications for re-exploration are very liberal, and this approach has saved a number of lives. The risk of such an exploration is small, whereas failure to contain the infection with lavage and drainage may be followed by surprisingly rapid death.

questions.text: A 20-month-old male infant presented with developmental delay, seizures, and eczema. His urine has a characteristic tom cat urine smell, and blood analysis indicated organic acidemia. The patient is advised to take biotin supplementation to treat which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple carboxylase/biotinidase deficiency

  • Autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in holocarboxylase synthase or biotinidase deficiency.
  • These are required to generate the active form of biotin required for carboxylation reactions (see fig).

Clinical features:-

  • Metabolic ketoacidosis
  • Diffuse rash
  • Alopecia
  • Seizures
  • Intellectual disability

Option B: Keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme for branch-chain dehydrogenase, the enzyme that catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-keto acids derived from leucine, isoleucine, and valine, three essential amino acids.

Option C: Transketolase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme of transketolase.

Option D: Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency

  • TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate), not biotin, is the coenzyme of Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency.

questions.text: A 29-year-old married male presents to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent chronic cough with expectoration for the past 10-12 years. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze and right basal crackles are audible, with heart sounds best heard on the right side of the chest. CT chest revealed dextrocardia, and nodular opacities in bilateral lung fields suggest bronchiectasis. He also gives a history of not having children despite being married for the last 4 years. Which of the following could be the probable cause of infertility in patients with the above syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option C: Asthenospermia

  • This patient’s clinical history & features are highly suggestive of Kartagener's syndrome.
  • It is a rare ciliopathic, autosomal recessive genetic disorder that affects the cilia in the lungs and other organs.
  • It is a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia. 50% of patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome.
  • Around 90% of individuals with kartageners have ultrastructural defects affecting protein(s) in the outer or inner dynein arms.
  • Kartagener syndrome is described as the triad of
    • Situs Inversus.
    • Bronchiectasis.
    • Either nasal polyps or recurrent sinusitis.
  • Other features include telecanthus, infertility in males, and subfertility in females.
  • Asthenospermia or poor sperm motility is due to missing dynein arms, which is the basic defect of Kartagener’s syndrome.
  • Symptoms of Kartagener’s syndrome include:
    • Respiratory distress in neonates
    • Recurrent respiratory tract infections
    • Bronchiectasis, situs inversus
    • Infertility and heterotaxy in approximately 50%
  • It is sometimes diagnosed at birth or most often discovered in early childhood.
  • There is no cure for Kartagener’s syndrome.

Option A: Oligospermia

  • Oligospermia refers to low sperm count.
  • It can be due to infection, genetics, hormones, environmental toxins, etc.
  • Kartagener syndrome most commonly affects sperm motility.

Option B: Blockage of the epididymis

  • Blockage of the epididymis can be due to infection, inflammation, scrotal trauma, and genetics.
  • It is seen in young syndrome, a rare inherited syndrome similar to Kartagener syndrome.

Option D: Undescended testis

  • It is also known as cryptorchidism.
  • It is not associated with Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: An 11-month-old child with a congenital renal disease presents to the hospital. Ophthalmologic examination done revealed the finding as shown below. Which of the following statements is false. w.r.t. the given condition?

choices.text: It is a slowly progressive degenerative condition
Deposition occurs in descements membrane of cornea ,typically in interpalpebral zone

questions.solution:
The image shows ‘BAND SHAPED KERATOPATHY’

OPTION 4: FALSE — Deposition occurs in BOWMAN’S MEMBRANE NOT in Descemet's membrane

Band Shaped Keratopathy is a slowly progressive degenerative condition that involves deposition of calcium at the level of Bowman's membrane, typically in the interpalpebral zone beginning as a gray-white opacity nasally and temporally progressing centrally in a band-shaped pattern. Initially, patients remain asymptomatic initially which can progress as the deposits cross the visual axis and affect visual acuity. Erosion of the lesion may lead to painful recurrent corneal erosions.

Causes of Band Shaped Keratopathy:

  • Chronic Ocular Diseases
    • Chronic uveitis
    • Interstitial keratitis
    • Long-standing corneal edema or keratitis
    • Phthisis bulbi
  • Silicone oil in an aphakic eye
  • Idiopathic
  • Miscellaneous causes
    • Hypercalcemia (associated with renal failure)
    • Hyperphosphatemia without hypercalcemia
    • Chronic mercury exposure
    • Primary hereditary band keratopathy

Management of Band Shaped Keratopathy:

  • Management of the underlying cause by identification and appropriate systemic treatment
  • Lubricant (artificial tear) eye drops and ointments to smoothen the surface and may also improve the visual complaints
  • A bandage contact lens may also provide benefit
  • Calcium Chelation under topical anesthesia using chelating agents like disodium EDTA
  • Superficial corneal scarring can be managed by Excimer laser Phototherapeutic Keratectomy (PTK)

questions.text: Which of the following psychosocial stages is associated with virtue of ‘Hope’?
questions.solution:
Psychosocial stage Virtue associated with the stage
Trust vs. mistrust Hope
Autonomy vs. shame and doubt Will
Initiative vs. guilt Purpose
Industry vs. inferiority Competence
Identity vs. role confusion Fidelity
Intimacy vs. isolation Love
Generativity vs. stagnation Care
Integrity vs. despair Wisdom

Note: Erik Erikson is the person who gave the psychosocial stages of development.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old woman has relapsing/remitting multiple sclerosis. She has previously experienced two attacks of disease that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids, with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she can only walk with a rolling walker for about 100 m. An initial antibody test shows that she is negative for reactivity to the J.C. virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following drug causes a maximum reduction in the appearance of new lesions and change in disease severity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Natalizumab

Treatment of Multiple Sclerosis-

  • An acute attack of optic neuritis = IV methylprednisolone
  • Natalizumab:
    • Highly effective in reducing attack rate
    • S/E = J.C. virus (John Cunningham virus) activation leading to P.M.F. (Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy)- worsening of neurological features.
  • Ocrelizumab = acts by attacking mature B cells, which expresses CD 20. Is allowed for management of P.P.M.S
Drugs are given in MS:
HIGHLY EFFECTIVE Moderately effective
  • Natalizumab
  • Ocrelizumab
  • I.F.N. ß
  • Glatiramer
  • Fingolimod
  • Dimethyl Fumarate

Option B: Glatiramer

  • Glatiramer is used but is moderately effective for multiple sclerosis

Option C: Interferon beta la

  • Interferon beta 1a is used in the treatment  of multiple sclerosis but  is not as effective as natalizumab

Option D: Interferon beta lb

  • Interferon beta 1b is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis but is not as effective  as natalizumab

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN):
1. Immunosuppressive therapy is effective
2. PSGN develops one to three weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis
3. PSGN develops two to six weeks after impetigo
4. The classic presentation is acute nephritis
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.solution:
The above statements 2,3 & 4 are correct.

Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN):-

  • Occurs due to Group A (β-hemolytic) Streptococci of which type 15 is nephritogenic.
  • The latent period following pharyngeal infection due to Streptococci M types 1, 3, 4, 12, 25, 18 and 49, is 7 to 14 days 8 to 11 days following cutaneous infection] impetigo due to Streptococci M types 2, 49, 55, 57, and 60, is 3 to 4 weeks
  • Mainly occurs in children of 2 and 12 years of age
  • C/F:-Subclinical infection more common (4 times) and Classical presentation with acute nephritic syndrome is hematuria (100%), edema (80% 90%), and hypertension (60% 80%) with or without oliguria (10% 20%).
  • T/T-Edema responds to diuretics, and salt restriction, hypertension can be treated by antihypertensive.
  • Prognosis-Mostly spontaneous recovery within 1 to 2 weeks. Prognosis is excellent in children; Complete recovery in 95% cases.

Bad prognostic indicators are late age of onset, sporadic disease, massive proteinuria, sustained hypertension, and presence of crescents on light microscopy.

questions.text:
With reference to Le Fort I fracture, consider the following statements:

Fracture line separates the alveolus and palate from the facial skeleton
Fracture line passes from the pyriform aperture
Fracture line runs posteriorly to include pterygoid plates
Fracture line passes through the orbit

which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.solution:
• Le Fort classified fractures according to varying degrees of force applied to the cadaver.

Le Fort I

  • It separates the alveolus and palate from facial skeletal above.
  • The fracture line runs through the point of weakness from the nasal piriform aperture through the lateral and medial walls of the maxillary sinus, running posteriorly to include lateral part of pterygoid plates.

Le Fort II

  • Pyramid in shape.
  • Involves orbit, running through the bridge of nose and ethmoid in which cribriform plate may be fractured, leading to a dural tear and CSF rhinorrhea.
  • Continues to the medial part of the infraorbital rim and often through the infraorbital foramen.
  • Orbit floor is always involved.
  • It continues posteriorly through the lateral wall of the maxillary antrum and to the pterygoid plate at the back. Le Fort III
  • Separates facial skeletal from the base of skull.
  • The fracture line runs high through the nasal bridge, septum, and ethmoids and irregularly through the bone of the orbit and frontozygomatic suture.
  • Zygomatic arch fracture and facial skeleton is separated from bones above at a high level through the lateral wall of maxillary sinus and pterygoid plate.

questions.text: In a newborn with severe respiratory distress after an emergency lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) under maternal spinal anesthesia, what is the appropriate size of the endotracheal tube for intubation?
questions.solution:
Option B: 3.5 mm

  • In the case mentioned above, the baby is a newborn, and in this scenario, the most suitable size of an endotracheal tube is 3.0-3.5mm.
  • The appropriate size of an endotracheal tube in a normal-term newborn is 3.0-3.5mm.

Guidelines for selection of Endotracheal Tube in Terms of appropriate internal Diameter (ID)

Age Internal Diameter (mm)
1. Premature or small for gestational age 2.5 – 3.0 mm
2. Normal term newborn 3.0-3.5 mm
3. Six months to 2 years 4.0 – 4.5 mm
4. Greater than 2 years  

5. Penlington’s formula

                             < 6.5 years

 

                             > 6.5 years

6. (Anteroposterior diameter of distal joint of the fifth finger) – (2.2 mm) = outside diameter of endotracheal tube*
*Based on data from Fukuoka et al.39

Guidelines for proper depth of insertion of endotracheal tubes in pediatric patients, from the level of the anterior gum line

Weight/Age Oral Nasal
1. 1, 2 and 3 Kg 7, 8, 9 cm 1. Crown-heel length x 0.21 cm
2. Newborn 9.5 cm 2. Crown-heel length x 0.16 + 2.5 cm
3. 6 months 10-5 – 11 cm  
4. Greater than 1 year

or 

 

4.  

Option A: 2.5 mm

  • A 2.5mm endotracheal tube size is indicated in premature babies (before full term) or babies who are small for gestational age.

Option C: 4.5 mm

  • The most frequently used endotracheal tube size in 18 to 23 months old babies is 4.5mm.
  • It is not used in newborns under 4 months of age.

Option D: 5.5 mm

  • A 5.5 mm endotracheal tube size is indicated in children of 4 years of age.
  • It cannot be used in a newborn baby.

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally because its raining outside. How much would he score on an insight scale?
questions.solution:
In such patient, who is having the awareness of being sick, but is attributing it to external or physical factors would be given a score of 3 on an insight scale.

Insight scale:-(Scores)

1.Complete denial of illness

2.Slightawareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time

3.Awareness of being sick but is attributed to external or physical factors

4.Intellectual insight-awareness of being ill, and that the symptoms are due to on particular irrational feelingsand thoughts

5.Emotional insight-the highest level of insight intellectual insight with making significant changes in future behaviour

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with episodes of obtundation, somnolence, and tachycardia. An insulinoma is suspected based on a random serum glucose test value of 38 mg/dl. Which of the following statements is/are true?

choices.text: The most important diagnostic study for insulinoma is an oral glucose tolerance test.
It may be helpful to perform ERCP in an effort to localize the tumor.
Most patients with insulinoma present with extensive disease, rendering them only rarely resectable or curable.
Preoperative evaluation in patients with presumed insulinoma involves confirming elevated C-peptide or proinsulin levels and screening for anti-insulin antibodies.

questions.solution:
Insulinoma is the most common endocrine tumor of the pancreas.

An important component of the preoperative evaluation in patients with presumed insulinoma involves confirming elevated C-peptide or proinsulin levels and screening for anti-insulin antibodies.

Insulinoma is associated with Whipple's triad, which consists of

(1) symptoms of hypoglycemia at fasting;

(2) documentation of blood glucose levels of less than 50 mg. per dl.; and

(3) relief of symptoms following administration of glucose.

The most reliable method for diagnosing insulinomas is fasting monitoring. Neither an oral nor an intravenous glucose tolerance test is indicated in the majority of patients being evaluated for insulinoma. Support for the diagnosis of insulinoma can come from documenting elevated C peptide and proinsulin levels. Screening for anti-insulin antibodies is indicated to rule out the possibility of surreptitious insulin administration. Tumor localization is typically performed with CT, endoscopic ultrasonography, or angiography. ERCP is not indicated for evaluation of most pancreatic endocrine tumors, as the tumors only rarely communicate with the main pancreatic duct system. As many as 90% of patients with insulinoma have benign solitary pancreatic adenomas amenable to surgical cure.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of fever and respiratory distress for 2 days. His temperature is 100.7 F (38.20C), pulse is 144/min, respiratory rate is 45/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. He is tachycardic with a III/VI holosystolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. Peripheral pulses are present and capillary refill is three seconds. His liver is palpated three centimeters below the costal margin. A chest radiograph is shown below:
    
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The CXR shows an increased CT ratio with findings of CHF leading to hepatomegaly.
  • Viral Myocarditis typically presents as a flu-like illness characterized by fever, anorexia, lethargy, and irritability followed by respiratory distress from acute heart failure.
  • A holosystolic murmur may be identified secondary to dilated ventricle and the resulting functional mitral regurgitation. Hepatomegaly can develop due to passive congestion. Other features of heart failure include fatigue, tachypnea, tachycardia, and decreased perfusion.

Since modified Jones criteria for rheumatic fever are not satisfied and neither AHA guidelines for Kawasaki disease are fulfilled, choice B and Choice D are ruled out.

questions.text: A 68 years old female patient is brought to the emergency department had a heart attack 4 hrs ago, her blood pressure has decreased continuously, and now the patient manifests with cardiogenic shock. Which of the following would be the most beneficial therapy?

choices.text: Placing tourniquets on all four limbs

questions.solution:
• Coronary thrombosis leads to decreased blood supply to myocardial cells due to which weakening of cardiac muscle occurs resulting in cardiogenic shock.
  • Cardiogenic shock can cause low cardiac output and low diastolic pressure results in decreased strength of cardiac muscles.
  • Therefore, either blood volume expander or vasoconstrictors are necessary to increase arterial diastolic pressure.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his mother is concerned about a birthmark on his face that she would like removed for cosmetic reasons. The mother states that the lesion has been growing in size and has not changed in color. Physical examination shows a well-developed, well-nourished active child.
