A smooth, dark lesion with demarcated borders, measuring 5 cm in greatest width is identified on the bridge of the nose. She insists that it be removed because it is located in a conspicuous region and when they go out, people stare at him and his classmates tease him. Which of the following conditions best describes this lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient has a benign congenital nevus, which is a circumscribed light-brown-to-black plaque with associated hair growth. Histologically, the nevus cells grow deep into the dermis and along with hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and neurovascular structures.

Lesions can be surgically excised or laser. Larger, giant nevi can cover significant areas of the arm and/or trunk.

Other options:

- A blue nevus is a deep intradermal nevus in which clusters of nevus cells extend into the reticular dermis and subcutaneous tissue. They have a blue hue due to the Tyndall effect, where light wavelength scatters due to melanin within the dermis. They are not associated with hair growth and do not grow around dermal structures.

- Café au lait spots are associated predominantly with neurofibromatosis type 1. They are small, light-brown macules on the skin. They are not associated with hair growth within the macule.

- Malignant melanoma can have hereditary or acquired causes. The child is too young to have developed malignant melanoma and you should consider a benign condition first. Malignant melanomas are not associated with hair growth.

questions.text: 5 years ago, a 36-year-old male had a dilated cardiomyopathy for which he underwent cardiac transplant surgery. He was doing well post-transplant but a week ago, he developed progressive shortness of breath which aggravated on exertion. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was done, which revealed mid and apical anterior hypokinesia. What shall be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV).

→Aggressive complication of cardiac allografts

→Characteristic: Proliferative thickening of the vascular intima initiated as a diffuse endothelialitis as a consequence of ischemic-reperfusion injury during the transplant process and also immunological insults.

→Usually silent, so asymptomatic

→ Rx

  • Definitive therapy - Retransplantation
  • Drugs: Statins, antihypertensive agents, and anti-CMV agents

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with history of decreased urine output, cola colored urine and swelling of the face & hands of 2 days duration. He is hypertensive, has a puffy face and pitting edema of the lower limbs. He has history of skin lesions 4 weeks earlier. A diagnosis of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is made. C3 levels are likely to return to normal in?
questions.solution:
C3 levels are likely to return to normal in- 8 weeks According to Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition and 21st edition, C3 level normalises in 6-8 weeks & according to O.P. Ghai Essential pediatrics 9th edition, its 8-12 weeks. So the single best answer for above question is 8 weeks > 6 weeks.

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

It is a classic example of the acute nephritic syndrome characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency.

PSGN follows infection of the throat or skin by certain “nephritogenic” strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. (Throat serotypes - M1, M4, M25, and some strains of M12 and skin serotype - M49) Poststreptococcal GN usually affects school-age children (5-12 years of age) and is uncommon below 3 years of age.

Lab Diagnosis of PSGN:

Antistreptolysin O titer is commonly increased after a pharyngeal infection but rarely elevated after streptococcal skin infections.

Best single antibody to document cutaneous streptococcal infection is anti deoxyribonuclease (DNase) B level

The serum C3 level is significantly decreased in >90% of patients, and returns to normal 6-8 wk after onset. (Some authors say that it takes 8-12 weeks for C3 levels to come back to normal) C4 is most often normal.

Serum CH50 is commonly depressed A biopsy is rarely indicated when: renal function is severely impaired beyond 7-10 days serum C3 remains depressed beyond 12 weeks Patient with features of a systemic illness Management of PSGN involves: Symptomatic & supportive therapy (treating the acute effects of renal insufficiency and hypertension)

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a travel history to Southern Minnesota is brought to the hospital's ER by his brother. The brother said that the man had a 2-day history of fever, headache, and vomiting, but today he appeared confused. He is confused by some of the simple questions you ask him. His spinal tap was clear with 75% PMNs and a head CT was normal. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are the most consistent with West Nile neurological disease, a rare complication of West Nile virus infections.

West Nile virus:

  • West Nile virus is the leading cause of arboviral encephalitis.
  • Birds, particularly crows are natural hosts.
  • The virus is normally transmitted by mosquito bites but can be transferred by blood transfusions, breastfeeding, and through the placenta.
  • It causes asymptomatic disease in 80% of those infected, but 20% develop West Nile fever, and less than 1% develop West Nile neurological disease (WNND), which is more likely to occur in individuals older than 60 years of age.

questions.text:
Which of the following are renal complications of radiological investigations?



A
Contrast nephrotoxicity


B
Cholesterol atheroembolism


C
Nephrogenic sclerosing fibrosis of the skin
questions.solution:
Contrast nephrotoxicity is a complication of iodinated contrast. Gadolinium is MRI contrast and in renal insufficiency leads to NSF.

Catheter angiographic procedures can lead to cholesterol atheroembolism.

  • Atheroembolic Renal Disease has a variable but temporal relationship to the performance of invasive vascular procedures and pharmacologic treatment with thrombolytic/anticoagulant agents.
  • The clinical symptoms may develop immediately after the vascular procedure or can evolve slowly over a period of weeks or months.
  • Lack of awareness of this disease among nonrenal physicians, the variable clinical presentation, and the infrequency of obtaining biopsy specimens often lead to an underestimation of the true incidence of AERD as a complication of invasive vascular procedures.

questions.text: A patient after 1 month of getting vaccinated presented to the hospital with excessive bruising and bleeding, purplish spots, and a rash. The diagnosis of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) was made by the physician. ITP is a complication observed with which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
Option A: MMR

  • MMR can lead to ITP causing serum platelet count to go as low as 50,000/microL leading to bruising and/or bleeding.
  • Usually, it is mild & self-limiting.
  • Occasionally may need steroids or platelets.
  • Similar to drug-induced ITP, post-vaccination ITP develops when antibodies against platelet antigens such as GP Ib/IX, GP Ia/IIa, and GP VI cross-react after immunization.
  • The MMR vaccination is thought to induce ITP through a similar mechanism.

Other options

Option B: Rotavirus vaccine

  • The rotavirus vaccine does not lead to ITP.
  • The adverse effect of the rotavirus vaccine is intussusception.

Option C: Hepatitis B vaccine 

  • Adverse effects of the Hep B vaccine include hypersensitivity, and shock.
  • Hepatitis B vaccine in newborns: 3 doses- (6, 10, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at home or (0, 6, 14 weeks) if the child is delivered at an institute(Dose: 0.5 ml each).

Option D: Influenza vaccine

  • Killed influenza vaccine causes reactions such as Anaphylaxis, Guillain barre syndrome, and Oculo-respiratory syndrome.
  • It does not cause ITP.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was hit on the side of the head with a baseball bat during practice. Boy was conscious in the beginning. A laceration with a palpable bone fragment was found in the wound. After 5 hours the boy became unconscious and later died. Most likely the cause of death is :
questions.solution:
The death of the patient occurred because of extradural hemorrhage

EXTRADURAL HEMORRHAGE

  • A blow over the lateral side of the head can fracture temporal bone and can injure the middle meningeal artery which will cause extradural hemorrhage and increases intracranial pressure which will produce symptoms.
  • usually, it leads to unconsciousness, but in some cases, consciousness may not be lost.
  • As the bleeding continues, the intracranial pressure increases further and can lead to coma and death.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with a neck injury. A cervical collar was applied on site. On further investigation, there is a stable burst fracture of the C1 vertebra. What is the mechanism of injury in this case?
questions.solution:
• Jefferson fracture is burst fracture of ring of atlas (C1) vertebrae
  • Burst fracture occurs due to vertical compression force.
  • Whiplash injury - Most cervical spine fractures occur predominantly at two levels - at the level of C2 or at C6 or C7

Management of burst fractures

  • Stable burst fracture: In minimal anterior wedging and when the fracture is stable (posterior ligament complex intact), with no neurological deficits, conservative treatment is followed. Bed rest until acute symptoms settle, followed by a thoracolumbar brace (TLSO) or body cast for about 12 weeks.
  • Unstable burst fracture: Operative treatment is done in cases of neurological injury, disruption of the posterior ligamentous complex (PLC), and if there is more than 50% canal compromise on CT. Posterior pedicle screw fixation is the standard treatment for PLC disruption.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is associated with the picture given below?
questions.solution:
Rorschach Test:

  • If you see an image which is symmetrical which can made of ink blots, it’s most likely a question on Rorschach test.
  • It’s one of the important image based question in psychiatry.
  • It is a test for personality assessment.
  • HERMANN RORSCHACH (swiss psychiatrist) in 1910 produced set of inkblots, some black and white and some multi-coloured.
  • It is used to determine thought disorders.
  • Especially when the subjects are reluctant to share their thinking processes.

Thematic Apperception Test:

  • It is also a test for personality assessment.
  • Developed by Henry A Murray and his harvard colleague Christiana D Morgan in 1935.
  • It is based on Murrays theory of needs – it is designed to ferret out people’s basic needs by having them to tell stories
  • PERCEPTION : Processing of sensory input, organizing & interpreting it to produce a meaningful experience of the outside world (DSM).
  • APPERCEPTION – Readiness to perceive in certain ways based on prior experiences.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with acute onset of suprapubic pain and inability to pass urine for 2 days. On examination, the patient is in discomfort, neurologically intact, and the abdomen is particularly tender in the suprapubic region. A digital rectal examination reveals a smooth, enlarged prostate. Select the most appropriate course of action to take in managing the patient?

choices.text: Ask the urology registrar to see the patient
Obtain blood for urea and electrolytes sampling
Request an abdominal plain film radiograph

questions.solution:
*Prompt urinary catheterization is the most appropriate course of action here. This will relieve the discomfort and prevent the risk of acute renal failure.

Urethral catheterization is attempted first; if unsuccessful, suprapubic catheterization is carried out. At some centers, administering parenteral antibiotics (e.g. intramuscular gentamicin) 15–20 minutes before catheterization is encouraged (in elderly patients with acute urinary retention) to decrease the risk of the patient developing a urinary tract infection.

An abdominal plain film radiograph would not be informative in this case and obtaining blood for urea and electrolytes is important (to check renal function) but should be done once the patient is catheterized.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

Registration of birth, even if the child is born in a hospital, is essentially the responsibility of parents only.
At present, the registration of birth has to be done not more than 15 days after the birth.

Which of these statements is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Both statements are incorrect.

The Central Births and Deaths Registration Act, 1969 came into force on 1st April 1970. This act fixes responsibility for reporting birth and death to the public (parent, relative, etc.,), to report events occurring in their households, Head of hospital or nursing homes, hotels, jails, or dharmshalas are to report incidence occurring in such places to the concerned registrar.

The time limit for registering births or deaths is 21 days all over India. Of late there is a provision of late fee.

questions.text: To be most effective in contraception, a diaphragm coated with a spermicidal agent should be left in place at least how many hours after intercourse?
questions.solution:
- The use of a diaphragm coated with a spermicidal agent is an effective method of contraception. For the spermicidal agent to be most effective, the diaphragm should be left in place for at least 6 hours after intercourse.
- After 6 hours have elapsed, the diaphragm can be removed when it is most convenient to do so but should not be left in place for a prolonged period of time.

questions.text: A patient had met with an accident and he is not able to abduct his right arm and can not lift it. On examination, tenderness felt near the right upper arm. X-ray showed a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. The muscle that was paralyzed was?
questions.solution: The best answer here is deltoid ( axillary nerve). Since it is not mentioned, so we choose supraspinatus ( suprascapular nerve).

questions.text: An 18-years-old girl presents to the office with complaints of nasal obstruction for the last 1 month. Her mother reports that the discharge is foul-smelling. On examination, excessive crusting and a widened nasal cavity are noticed. Which of the following is not true about her condition?

choices.text: Stratified squamous epithelium is replaced by ciliated columnar epithelium
25% glucose in glycerin is used for treatment

questions.solution:
Option B: Stratified squamous epithelium is replaced by ciliated columnar epithelium

  • This patient with nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge, and the picture showing excessive crusting of the nose with widened nasal cavity most likely have atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis:

  • Klebsiella ozaena is an organism that is found to be commonly associated with atrophic rhinitis.
  • It is more common in females.
  • The disease usually starts at puberty and involves females more than males; the crusting and fetor associated with the disease tend to cease after menopause; these factors have raised the possibility of the disease being an endocrinal disorder.
  • The main symptoms are foul-smelling discharge, nasal crusts, epistaxis, and nasal obstructions.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Treatment Alkaline nasal douching, 25% glucose in glycerin, Fe, vitamin D, antibiotics, and estrogen spray.

Option A: Caused by klebsiella ozaena

  • Atrophic rhinitis is caused by klebsiella ozaena.
  • It is the wrong option because, in question, the untrue statement has been asked.

Option C: 25% glucose in glycerin is used for treatment

  • Glucose 25% glycerin is used in the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.
  • It is the wrong option because, in question, the untrue statement has been asked.

Option D: Common in females than males

  • Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females.
  • It is the wrong option because, in question, the untrue statement has been asked.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought by his mother to the paediatrician. The mother states that he has a lump on the right side of the abdomen, which she noticed while changing the clothes of her child. Ultrasound revealed it to be a solid mass. On examination, his right arm and leg were found to be longer. The birth history is normal. The vitals are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Wilm’s tumour

  • In the above-given case, the sign and symptoms of the right abdominal lump and right upper and lower longer extremities are suggestive of the diagnosis of Wilm’s tumour.
  • It is also called nephroblastoma.
  • It is most common in preschool children.
  • An asymptomatic abdominal mass is palpable on examination.
  • Beckwith Weidman syndrome associated with Wilms tumour.
  • In Beckwith-Wiedeman syndrome, visceromegaly (liver, kidney, pancreas), hemihypertrophy (right arm and leg tend to be longer), and macroglossia are present.
  • Some other syndromes are associated with Nephroblastoma.
  •  WAGR syndrome: Wilm's tumour, Aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  •  Denys Drash syndrome:  Early-onset renal failure with renal mesangial sclerosis, gonadal dysgenesis
  • Fanconi anaemia.

Option B: Neuroblastoma

  • It is the most common extracranial (abdominal) tumour in childhood
  • Neuroblastomas release catecholamine, which causes increased sweating and hypertension; it also produces vasoactive intestinal peptides, which cause secretory diarrhoea.
  • The patient presents with fever, Failure to thrive, pain in bone, Bluish Subcutaneous nodules, and proptosis in metastatic form.

Option C: Mesoblastic Nephroma

  • It is the most common benign solid renal tumour in neonates.
  • It presents as polyhydramnios, hydrops, and preterm delivery

Option D: Angiomyolipoma

  • It is a benign kidney tumour which is made up of vascular and smooth muscle and fat.
  • It presents with flank pain, palpable tender mass and gross hematuria.

questions.text: A 60-years-old female presents with C/O dizziness from the last 1-day despite good sleep. Dizziness is constant, mild, and vertiginous. Aural symptoms not present; there is no associated tinnitus, hearing loss, ear fullness. The patient is a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia. Smoking history is also positive. Head impulse sign is negative. Dix-Hallpike maneuver done that exacerbated her dizziness with no nystagmus seen. Which of the following is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
• Dizziness includes lightheadedness, imbalance, vertigo.
  • Duration of symptoms is important as brief episodes of dizziness include benign paroxysmal vertigo & orthostatic hypotension. Long-lasting dizziness can be divided into central and peripheral diseases like seen in conditions like Meniere disease, vestibular migraine, TIA.
  • Aural symptoms suggest a peripheral cause. Neurologic findings suggest a central cause.
  • The absence of a head impulse sign in a patient with acute vertigo suggests a central cause of her dizziness.
  • The patient has multiple risk factors for stroke that include her H/O hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking history. Thus, MRI Brain is the next most appropriate step done in this patient
  • Dix-Hallpike maneuver done that exacerbated her dizziness, no nystagmus was observed. The critical finding is transient upbeat nystagmus and not subjective experience of dizziness.

OTHER OPTIONS:

OPTION A: As clinical presentation is not consistent with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), the Epley maneuver not done.

OPTION D: Meclizine that is used in Vestibular suppressant therapy is not appropriate in this case

questions.text: Mr.Denver, a 32-year-old man who presented to you with unexplained pancreatitis 2 weeks ago. Imaging of his pancreas showed diffuse pancreatic enlargement. No past history of any alcohol intake and did not have any gallstones on imaging. Interestingly, on examination, he also has marked lacrimal gland and submandibular gland enlargement. The biopsy of his submandibular gland is pictured is shown below. The cells pictured in the figure stained strongly positive for IgG4, CD19, and CD138. Which of the following is the appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history, features, and biopsy findings are suggestive of IgG4 related disease. The appropriate treatment would be the initiation of 40 mg/d of prednisone, with tapering to discontinuation or maintenance doses of 5 mg/d within 2 or 3 months.

IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a newly recognized constellation of fibro-inflammatory disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates rich in IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, particularly T cells, associated with fibrosis and obliterative phlebitis.

On Histopathology:-

1. Infiltration of Ig G4 plasma cell into salivary gland

2. Storiform fibrosis

3. Obliterative phlebitis

Clinical Features:

1. Middle age Male

2. Isolated submandibular enlargement / orbital pseudotumor.

3. Allergic rhinitis, nasal polyps

4. Lungs: Pseudotumor

5. Riedel's thyroiditis

6. Retroperitoneal fibrosis

7. Autoimmune pancreatitis (Sausage shaped pancreas)

8. Aortitis

Treatment

  • Generally, begin with 40 mg/d of prednisone, with tapering to discontinuation or maintenance doses of 5 mg/d within 2 or 3 months.
  • Rituximab

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with severe mental retardation, mousy odor in body fluids, hypo-pigmentation. The patient has frequent episodes of seizures & aggressive behavior. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Untreated PKU (Phenylketonuria) >> Phenylketonuria

Note: PKU can be treated if diagnosed early hence need to mark 4, not 1.

  • This is a clinical picture of PKU (Phenylketonuria) with mental retardation.
  • These patients have a mousy or musty odor due to excess phenyl-acetate.
  • Hypopigmentation occurs as tyrosine not formed, which is responsible for making pigment Melanin. PKU can be treated if diagnosed early.

questions.text: An old man enters the hospital with myocardial infarction and noted to have a severe ventricular arrhythmia. The antiarrhythmic drug chosen has a narrow therapeutic window. The minimum toxic plasma concentration is 1.5 times the minimum therapeutic plasma concentration. The half-life is 6 hrs. It is essential to maintain the plasma concentration above the minimum therapeutic level to prevent a possible lethal arrhythmia. Of the following, the most appropriate dosing regimen would be:
questions.solution:
• When a drug is administered less frequently, it produces marked variation in the plasma concentrations. In this question, the drug has a half-life of 6 hours. If we repeat the dose at 6 hourly intervals, there will be a 100% variation in the plasma concentration.

• More frequent dosing will minimize the variation between maximum and minimum plasma concentrations. As the margin of safety of this drug (given in the question) is very low (maximum tolerable concentration is only 1.5 times the effective concentration), constant i.v. infusion is the best route.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increased urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On Prostate examination, swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are Characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except :

choices.text: Enlargement of lateral lobes of prostate

questions.solution:
Radiological features of BPH:

  • ‘Slit-like’ elongated and compressed urethra
  • Smooth filling defect/ indentation in bladder floor
  • Periurethral and subvesical enlargement is very pronounced may produce a rounded defect in floor mimicking Foley’s balloon.
  • Floor of bladder elevated and trigone pushed upwards, with distal ureteral ‘J’ or ‘Fish Hook’ deformity.
  • Trabeculations and distension of bladder
  • Bladder pseudodiverticuli and calculi
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter may occur.

On the IVU study, the enlarged prostate gland (P) elevates the bladder floor and causes a J-hooking (fish-hooking) deformity of the distal ureters (arrow).

questions.text:
A patient came to ENT OPD with complaints of earache, tinnitus, sensation of blocked ear. On examination, impacted wax is seen and the following procedure is performed.

Which of the following statement is true regarding the procedure?

choices.text: Ear pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and cold water is delivered along posteriosuperior wall of eac.
Ear pinna is pulled upwards and forwards and cold water is delivered along anteriosuperior wall of eac.
Ear pinna is pulled upwards and forwards and water at body temperature is delivered along anterosuperior wall of eac.
Ear pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and water at body temperature is delivered along posteriosuperior wall of eac.

questions.solution:
• Pinna is pulled upwards, backward, and laterally so that the cartilaginous and bony EAC lie in a straight line and the tympanic membrane is visible.
  • Then water boiled and cooled to body temperature is delivered to the posterosuperior part of EAC, such that the pressure of water built up deeper to the canal, expels the wax out.
  • Cold and Hot water is avoided, as it would stimulate the labyrinth and cause vertigo.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache and projectile vomiting along with altered sensorium. The following picture was observed on India ink staining. What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
Cryptococcus neoformans/European Blastomycosis

  • Encapsulated yeast.
  • Polysaccharide capsules composed of mannose, xylose, and glucuronic acid.
  • Transmitted by inhalation.
  • CNS cryptococcosis - Subacute or chronic meningitis and meningoencephalitis
  • Specimen - CSF, sputum, pus, and brain biopsy tissue.
  • In India ink preparation of CSF, capsule (clear halo around the yeast cell) can be demonstrated in 25–50% of patients with cryptococcal meningitis.
  • Amphotericin B is the drug of choice.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate initial management step for a 50-year-old woman with a 1 cm unilateral invasive carcinoma of the vulva, without stromal invasion or lymph node spread?

choices.text: Wide excision and Sentinel lymph node biopsy
Radical vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy

questions.solution:
Option C: Wide excision and Sentinel lymph node biopsy

  • The patient appears to have vulvar cancer with Stage 1A with the unifocal lateral lesion.
  • Since the patient has stage IA vulvar lesion, wide local excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy is the most appropriate answer.

Vulvar Carcinoma:

Staging and Management:

 

STAGE 1 1A

 

Limited to vulva/perineum

Size<=2cm stromal invasion <=1mm

 Wide local excision + sentinel lymph node study.

 
1B

 

 Size >2cm stromal invasion >1mm

 

 Radical local excision plus · B/L LAD for central lesion.

Radical local excision plus · U/L LAD for lateral lesion (>2cm from midline).
STAGE 2

 

 Any size, Spreads to lower 1/3 urethra, lower 1/3 vagina, anus

 

 Early: radical excision/ radical vulvectomy plus B/L LAD.

 

Advanced: radiation + surgery + LAD
STAGE 3

 

 Positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes

 

 Radiation + surgery + LAD.

 

STAGE 4A

4B

The upper urethra, upper vagina, bladder, rectum, pelvis sidewall

Distant metastasis, Pelvic or other lymph nodes

 Radiation + surgery + LAD.

 

 

LAD= lymphadenectomy

 

  • Radical local excision: Excision of the entire tumour with at least 1 cm grossly negative margin and extended down to inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm.
  • Sentinel lymph node studies: Reliable and suitable in early-stage disease with unifocal lesions less than 4 cm and clinically negative lymph nodes on groin examination and imaging.

 

 

Option A: Chemotherapy

  • It is the treatment of choice in more advanced stages of vulvar cancer.

Option B: Radiation therapy

  • Radiation therapy is employed in advanced stages of vulvar cancer along with lymphadenectomy.

Option D: Radical vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy

  • Vulvectomy can be performed in cases where carcinoma has the urethra and lower vagina, and anus.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will predispose to the following cardiac rhythm shown?
questions.solution:
• The ECG shows broad complex tachycardia with variable amplitude and is called as polymorphic VT.

Causes of QT Prolongation andTorsade de PointesVentricular Tachycardia (VT)

 Electrolyte abnormalities:

  • Hypokalemia, Hypomagnesemia, Hypocalcemia

 Drugs:

 Antiarrhythmic drugs

  • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
  • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade VT is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant

 Antibiotics

  • Macrolides: Erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin
  • Fluroquinolones: Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin,
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
  • Clindamycin,Pentamidine,Chloroquine
  • Antifungals: Ketoconazole, itraconazole
  • Antivirals: Amantadine

 Antipsychotics

  • Haloperidol, phenothiazines, thioridazine, trifluoperazine, sertindole, zimeldine, ziprasidone
  • Tricyclic and tetracyclic antidepressants

 Antihistamines (histamine 1-receptor antagonists)

  • Terfenadine, astemizole, diphenhydramine, hydroxyzine
  • Cholinergic antagonists: Cisapride, organophosphates
  • Citrate(massive blood transfusions)
  • Cocaine
  • Fluoxetine(in conjunction with other drugs that prolong QT)

 Cardiac conditions-Myocardial ischemia and infarction, Myocarditis, Marked bradycardia, Stress cardiomyopathy

 Endocrine disorders-Hypothyroidism, Hyperparathyroidism, Pheochromocytoma, Hyperaldosteronism

 Intracranial disorders-Subarachnoid hemorrhage, Thalamic hematoma, Cerebrovascular accident, Encephalitis, Head injury

 Nutritional disorders-Anorexia Nervosa, Starvation, Liquid protein diets, Gastroplasty and ileojejunal bypass, Celiac disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the ER with watery, non-bloody diarrhoea and generalized abdominal pain, which has progressively worsened since it began 2 days ago. He has no known co-morbid but was admitted to the medical ward a week ago with pneumonia, for which he was given IV antibiotics. On examination, he has dry mucous membranes and sunken eyes with abdominal tenderness. His vitals signs are BP=110/70mmg, HP=88/min, Temperature=101F, RR=18/min. The doctor decides to perform an endoscopy, as shown in the image below. Which of the following organism caused this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clostridium difficile

  • The patient in question has antibiotic-associated pseudomembranous colitis- yellowish plaque-like lesions in the colon caused by colonization with Clostridium difficile after his hospital stay.
  • C. difficile is a spore-forming gram-positive obligate anaerobe that is normally present in the colon of up to 3% of the general population but doesn’t cause disease due to competition with normal flora. After prolonged antibiotic use, the normal flora is diminished, which enables C. difficile to flourish and cause symptoms, e.g. fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain.
  • Risk factors include antibiotic use (usually taken in the last 2 months), cancer, chemotherapy, and enteral feeding.
  • Investigations include testing for exotoxins in stool via ELISA, PCR for genes coding for the exotoxins, and colonoscopy.
  • Treatment includes oral metronidazole or vancomycin faecal transplant from the healthy donor via NG or enema.

Option A: S. Aureus

  • S. aureus is a non spore forming a gram positive cocci.
  • It causes food poisoning via an enterotoxin that is performed in improperly stored foods, hence has a short incubation period (1-8hrs)
  • Vomiting is typically more prominent than diarrhoea in gastroenteritis caused by S. aureus.
  • Other diseases caused by S. aureus include skin and soft tissue infections, septicemia, toxic shock syndrome and endocarditis.

Option C: Clostridium perferingens

  • C. perferingens is a spore-forming gram-positive rod that causes gas gangrene and food poisoning
  • Diagnosis: C. perferingens is cultured anaerobically and identified by sugar fermentation reactions
  • Food poisoning: Heat-resistant spores can contaminate food and cause diarrhoea via enterotoxins; the incubation period is 8-16hrs. It causes watery diarrhoea with cramps that resolve in 24hrs usually without treatment.

Option D: Pseudomonas

  • Gram-negative rods, strict aerobes
  • P. aeruginosa usually causes infections in immune-compromised hosts. It is the most common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
  • Other diseases caused by pseudomonas include UTIs, cellulitis in burn patients, malignant otitis externa in diabetics, and chronic respiratory tract infections in patients with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A known case of syphilis is unable to walk with eyes closed and walks with stamping the foot on the ground. Which tract is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
It affects the posterior column in the spinal cord which carries vibration sense, joint position sense, and fine touch.

  • With Loss of vibration sense, the person is unable to feel the floor while walking. In order to feel the floor, the person hits his foot hard on the floor resulting in a stamping gait.
  • Loss of proprioception or joint position sense leads to swaying when he closes his eyes. This is known as Romberg's sign +ve

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presented to the emergency with pain within and behind the right ear. A preliminary diagnosis of otitis externa was made. He is a known case of diabetes mellitus. Gram staining of the exudates show gram-negative rods, and the sample was sent for culture and sensitivity. What should be the best treatment for this patient pending the result of the culture?

choices.text: Analgesics should be prescribed, but antibiotics should be withheld pending microbiological results
Oral cefaclor should be prescribed together with analgesics, and the patient should be sent home
The patient should be hospitalized, and treatment should start with IV vancomycin
The Patient should be hospitalized, and treatment should start with gentamicin plus piperacillin

questions.solution:
Option D: The Patient should be hospitalized, and treatment should start with gentamicin plus ticarcillin

  • A diabetic patient with otitis externa is in serious danger of the spread of infection to the meninges and middle ear.
  • Gram-negative rods may point towards Pseudomonas infection.
  • Its early manifestations resemble diffuse otitis externa, but there is excruciating pain and the appearance of granulations in the ear canal. Facial paralysis is common. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen, causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Anteriorly, the infection spreads to the temporomandibular fossa, posteriorly to the mastoid, and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.
  • Diagnosis: Severe otalgia in an elderly diabetic patient with granulation tissue in the external ear canal at its cartilaginous–bony junction should alert the physician of necrotizing otitis externa/ malignant otitis externa.
  • CT scan may show bony destruction but is often not helpful.
  • Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells and is indicative of soft tissue infection. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment.
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.
  • Aminoglycoside plus wider spectrum penicillin is appropriate and is used against many pseudomonas strains.

Option A: Analgesics should be prescribed, but antibiotics should be withheld pending microbiological results

  • Malignant otitis media is an emergency, and antibiotics should be given as soon as possible.

Option B: Oral cefaclor should be prescribed together with analgesics, and the patient should be sent home

  • In malignant otitis externa, the patient should be hospitalized, and intravenous antibiotics should be given.

Option C: The patient should be hospitalized, and treatment should start with imipenem-cilastatin

  • Imipenem-cilastatin does not cover the pseudomonas. Therefore, it is not the drug of choice for malignant otitis externa.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who is a known case of bronchial asthma comes with a respiratory rate of 48/min, cannot speak 2 words, occasional wheezes, a temperature is 36.8 C and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient has seasonal allergies to ragweed and is also allergic to peanuts. His family history is significant for asthma in his grandfather. You give 3 doses of salbutamol nebulization, and then he started to speak a sentence but oxygen saturation (SaO2) falls to 85%. What is the most likely cause of the drop in oxygen saturation SaO2?

choices.text: V/P mismatch with dead space ventilation

questions.solution:
The most likely cause of the drop in oxygen saturation (SaO2) in this case is V/P (Ventilation/Perfusion) mismatch with dead space ventilation.

Here's an explanation of the options:

  1. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition characterized by the collapse of the laryngeal structures during inspiration, leading to stridor and breathing difficulties. While it can affect airway patency, it is less likely to cause sudden drops in oxygen saturation in a patient with a known history of asthma.

  2. Alveolar hypoventilation: Alveolar hypoventilation occurs when there is inadequate ventilation of the alveoli, resulting in increased carbon dioxide (CO2) levels and decreased oxygen (O2) levels in the blood. It is not typically associated with a sudden drop in SaO2 in a patient actively receiving treatment for an asthma exacerbation.

  3. V/P Mismatch with Dead Space Ventilation: In patients with asthma, especially during an exacerbation, there can be regions of the lung with inadequate ventilation (V) relative to blood flow (perfusion, P), leading to V/P mismatch. This can result in oxygen not effectively entering the bloodstream, causing a drop in SaO2. Additionally, dead space ventilation, where ventilation occurs but without effective gas exchange, can further contribute to the mismatch and decreased SaO2.

  4. Pneumonia: Pneumonia can cause a drop in oxygen saturation, but it is less likely in this case because the patient's symptoms and history are more consistent with an asthma exacerbation, and the drop in SaO2 occurred after treatment with salbutamol nebulization.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with c/o dry cough and blackish red, streaky hemoptysis daily. There was no history of fever, chest pain, syncope, orthopnea, pedal oedema, abdomen pain, jaundice, oliguria, facial puffiness, nocturia, generalized swelling, joint pains, rashes, or sore throat. He gave a history of eating in a Chinese restaurant very often with the consumption of crabs on being asked leading Questions. What is the probable causative agent in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Paragonimus westermani

  • Paragonimiasis (Lung fluke) is one of the most important food-borne parasitic zoonoses after eating an infected raw or undercooked crab or crayfish. It is also known as endemic hemoptysis.

  • Host:

    • First intermediate host- snail

  • 2nd intermediate host – crab

  • In crabs, metacercaria larva, a cyst-like stage, is seen.

Life cycle:

  • Crab/Cray water Fish with Metacercariae → Eaten by man → Excystation in Duodenum → Larvae released → Penetrates intestinal layers → Penetrates diaphragm → Penetrates Rt. Lung capsule → Enters into Rt. Lung (mostly) → Forms cysts → Erosions → Red Brown sputum  (Endemic Hemoptysis).

 

Symptoms:

  • The acute phase (invasion and migration) may be marked by diarrhoea and abdominal pain. This may be followed several days later by fever, chest pain, and fatigue. During the chronic phase, pulmonary manifestations include dry cough productive with rusty-coloured or blood-tinged sputum on exertion.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Sputum examination: Identification of paragonimus eggs in sputum

  • Stool examination: sometimes eggs are present in the stool.

  • Biopsy for Subcutaneous type

  • CT for brain type

  • Immunological tests for reference.

Treatment:

  • Praziquantel is the drug of choice.

  • In rare cases of Paragonimiasis with brain involvement, a short course of corticosteroids may be given with the Praziquantel to help reduce the inflammatory response around dying flukes.

Option A: Diphyllobothrium latum

  • D. latum is also called fish tapeworm. Infections are acquired by eating raw or undercooked fish.

  • Asymptomatic but sometimes causes complications that include intestinal obstruction and gall bladder disease caused by migration of proglottids. D. Latium causes B12 deficiency in humans leading to megaloblastic or pernicious anaemia.

  • Treat with vitamin B12 supplementations along with antiparasitics such as niclosamide or Praziquantel.

Option B: Pneumocystis jirovecii

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus that causes serious infection. Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in a person with weakened immunity, i.e., AIDS patients.

  • Symptoms of PCP can develop over several days or weeks and include fever, cough, dyspnea, chest pain, chills, and tiredness.

  • Treatment: trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX).

Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis

  • Strongyloidiasis is a disease caused by a nematode or a roundworm.

  • Asymptomatic. Those who do develop symptoms often have non-specific or generalized complaints. Some people develop abdominal pain, bloating, heartburn, intermittent episodes of diarrhoea and constipation, a dry cough, and skin rashes.

  • Strongyloides infection may be diagnosed by seeing larvae in the stool when examined under the microscope.

  • Treatment: Ivermectin and albendazole.

questions.text: Which of the following features will be encountered in a person with the given karyotype:

choices.text: Gynecomastia with long and thin limbs

questions.solution:
• Klinefelter syndrome is best defined as male hypogonadism that occurs when there are two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. It is one of the most frequent forms of genetic disease involving the sex chromosomes as well as one of the most common causes of hypogonadism in the male. The incidence of this condition is approximately 1 in 660 live male births. Klinefelter syndrome can rarely be diagnosed before puberty, particularly because the testicular abnormality does not develop before early puberty.
  • Most patients have a distinctive body habitus with an increase in length between the soles and the pubic bone, which creates the appearance of an elongated body. Also characteristic are eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long legs; small atrophic testes often associated with a small penis; and lack of such secondary male characteristics as deep voice, beard, and male distribution of pubic hair. Gynecomastia may be present. The mean IQ is somewhat lower than normal, but mental retardation is uncommon. There is an increased incidence of type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome that gives rise to insulin resistance.
  • Curiously, mitral valve prolapse is seen in about 50% of adults with Klinefelter syndrome. There is also an increased incidence of osteoporosis and fractures due to sex hormonal imbalance

questions.text: A woman has her shortest cycle of 26 days and the longest cycle of 31 days. Calculate her unsafe period using the Rhythm method.
questions.solution:
Option A: 8-2O

Rhythm method:

  • It is also known as the calendar method / safe period method / fertile period method.
  • Unsafe period = (Shortest cycle- 18 days) to (longest cycle- 11 days).
  • Given shortest cycle = 26 days; longest cycle = 31 days
  • Unsafe period = (26-18) to (31-11) days = 8-20 days

Other options

Option B: 9-20

  • This options is incorrect.

Option C: Both

  • Option A (8-20 days) is the unsafe period according to the rhythm method.

Option D: None of the above

  • This is not the appropriate answer to the above-given question.

questions.text:
Assertion (A) – Ripasudil (Rho-kinase inhibitors) can be used to decrease intraocular pressure in glaucoma
Reason (R) – It increases aqueous outflow by reversing structural and functional damage at the trabecular meshwork

choices.text: Both A & R are true and R is correct explanation of A
Both A & R are true but R is not correct explanation of A
A is true R is false
A is false R is false

questions.solution:
Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors may provide a new way to treat glaucoma.

  • This class of drugs is thought to increase aqueous outflow by reversing structural and functional damage at the trabecular meshwork, and the vasodilator effect of some ROCK inhibitors reduces Episcleral venous pressure.
  • Ripasudil in clinical use is solely a ROCK inhibitor Netarsudil lowers IOP by inhibiting both ROCK and the norepinephrine transporter (NET). The former enhances trabecular outflow and reduces Episcleral venous pressure, while the latter decreases aqueous production.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening tachycardia and heat intolerance over the last month. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. Physical examination shows a tender neck mass. Fine needle aspiration shows a heavy lymphocytic infiltrate with multinucleated giant cells, and follicular disruption. He returns after one month, because of lethargy, cold intolerance, and a 2.7 kg (6 lb) weight gain. Thyroid function test performed on the second visit shows serum triiodothyronine (T3) of 85 ng/dL and serum thyroxine (T4) of 3.5 μg/dL. Which of the following most likely contributed to the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has subacute granulomatous Thyroiditis caused by a viral infection

  • Also known as de Quervain thyroiditis

Symptoms: Tender neck mass and multinucleated giant cells on pathology (suggestive of granulomatous inflammation)

  • Initial phase: Inflammation results in the destruction of thyroid follicles and inappropriate release of preformed thyroid hormone, causing hyperthyroidism

*Hyperthyroid symptoms: heat intolerance, tachycardia, palpitations, sweating, diarrhea, and hyperreflexia

  • Late phase: Loss of thyroid follicles results in a hypothyroid state.

*Hypothyroid symptoms: lethargy, cold intolerance, constipation, weight gain, and hyporeflexia. Most patients subsequently recover normal thyroid function.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came to your OPD for smoking cessation. She was diagnosed with depression 2 years ago and took SSRI for 6 months. She is off medication for 1.5 years & now is mentally healthy. She started smoking at the age of 25 years & she tried quitting on her own using nicotine gums several times but she is unable to sustain abstinence for more than 1 month. What would be the best recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
The answer is D - Counseling + Varenicline

A comprehensive approach with advice, pharmacological assistance & counseling increases the cessation success.

At every medical visit, all patients should be asked whether they smoke, how much they smoke, and whether they are interested in quitting. ·

Pharmacologic therapy- Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) or varenicline

  • NRTs- transdermal patches, nasal inhaler, gum, oral inhaler, or lozenges.
  • Varenicline- partial agonist of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor

Counseling:

  • Physician/medical personnel counseling
  • Intensive individual counseling
  • Telephone counseling

Effective Pharmacologic Interventions for smoking cessation:

First-line therapies (Number in brackets indicates efficacy):

1. Nicotine gum (1.5)

2. Nicotine patch (1.9)

3. Nicotine nasal inhaler (2.7)

4. Nicotine oral inhaler (2.5)

5. Nicotine lozenges (2.0)

6. Bupropion (2.1)

7. Varenicline (2.7)

Second-line therapies

1. Clonidine (2.1)

2. Nortriptyline (3.2)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male CIA employee presents with a 3-week history of a tumor in the scrotum. The patient has a known history of diabetes controlled by diet. There is minimal discomfort. On examination, the lesion is located posteriorly and does not transilluminate to light. Both testes are clinically normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Adenomatoid is the most common tumor of the epididymis.

- The epididymis is posterior, and a cyst of the epididymis transilluminates to light.

- A hydrocele also transilluminates, but it is anterior to the testis. A cyst of the testis is a remnant of the proximal part of the para-mesonephros (Müller’s) duct. In the presence of a normal FSH, a testicular biopsy would most likely confirm normal sperm formation

questions.text:
Consider the following disorders:

Sydenham’s chorea
Migraine
Mania
Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Valproic acid is used in which of the above disorders?
questions.solution: Valproic acid is used in acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), bipolar disorder, epilepsy, headache, migraine prevention, myoclonus, peripheral neuropathy, status epilepticus, stress disorders, Sydenham’s chorea, and tardive syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with acute onset of substernal chest pain that began abruptly 30 minutes ago. He reports the pain radiating to his neck and right arm. He has otherwise been in good health. On physical examination, he is diaphoretic and tachypnoeic. His BP is 102/48 mmHg and his heart rate is 112 bpm, regular rhythm but is tachycardiac. A 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. His lungs have bilateral rales at the bases. The ECG demonstrates 4 mm of ST elevation in the anterior leads. In the past, he was hospitalized for some problem with his heart when he was 4 years old. His mother, who accompanies him, reports that he received aspirin and γ- globulin as treatment. Since that time, he has required intermittent follow-up with echocardiography. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s acute coronary syndrome?

choices.text: Dissection of the aortic root and left coronary ostia
Presence of a myocardial bridge overlying the left anterior descending artery
Thrombosis of a coronary artery aneurysm

questions.solution:
Option C: Thrombosis of a coronary artery aneurysm

  • The most likely cause of acute coronary syndrome in this patient is thrombosis of a coronary artery aneurysm in an individual with a past history of Kawasaki disease.

  • Kawasaki disease:

    • It is an acute multi-system disease that primarily presents in children <5 years of age.

    • It predominantly occurs in Japan.

    • Cardiovascular complications include transient coronary dilatation, myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial infarction, peripheral vascular insufficiency, and gangrene.

    • Although the causative trigger is unknown, it has been associated with Mycoplasma and HIV infection.

  • Clinical Feature:
    • Conjunctivitis (Non-exudative)
    • Rash (Polymorphous Non-vesicular rash)
    • Edema of hands/feet.
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy
    • Mucosal involvement
  • Treatment:
    • Early treatment (within 7–10 days of onset) with IV immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin decreases the risk of developing coronary aneurysms
    • Complications of persistent coronary artery aneurysms include rupture, thrombosis and recanalization, and stenosis at the outflow area.

Option A: Aortic root dissection & left coronary Ostia

  • A dangerous ailment known as an aortic dissection develops when the body's main artery's inner layer tears (aorta).
  • Blood flows through the tear, dividing the aorta's inner and middle layers (dissect). Aortic dissection is often deadly if the blood goes through the outside aortic wall.
  • Most cases of aortic dissection are in men between 60 and 70.
  • This condition typically presents with severe chest pain and is associated with tearing or ripping pain. The ECG findings and murmur are not consistent with aortic dissection.

Option B: Myocardial bridge presence, overlying the left anterior descending artery

  • The muscle that covers the intramyocardial part of the epicardial coronary artery is known as a myocardial bridge (MB) (referred to as a tunneled artery).
  • Although MBs can occur in any epicardial artery, the left anterior descending artery is the most affected.
  • In most patients, a myocardial bridge is not treated if it is not causing any symptoms.
  • Medicines such as beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are usually the first line of treatment in patients with symptoms.
  • Myocardial bridges are usually benign and do not typically cause acute coronary syndrome unless there are other complicating factors, which are not evident in this case.

Option D: Vasospasm following cocaine ingestion

  • Coronary vasospasm and sudden cardiac death are frequently reported complications of cocaine abuse.
  • The increased concentration of catecholamines peripherally causes stimulation of both α and β adrenergic receptors.
  • This stimulation can cause coronary artery vasospasm and decreased oxygenated blood supply to the cardiac muscle, leading to myocardial ischemia and acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
  • Patients with acute cocaine toxicity may require urgent treatment for tachycardia, dysrhythmia, hypertension, and coronary vasospasm.
  • While cocaine use can lead to coronary vasospasm and acute coronary syndrome, the patient's history of Kawasaki disease and the findings on ECG and physical examination are more indicative of thrombosis in the context of coronary artery aneurysms.

questions.text: An investigator is attempting to develop a blood test to diagnose sporadic Creutzfeld-Jacob disease. After performing a comprehensive tissue analysis, she has identified two amino acid sequences on the affected proteins that are highly consistent across samples. She then creates antibodies that are highly specific to those amino acid sequences and is interested in using those antibodies to identify similar sequences in individuals suspected of having CJD. Which of the following tests would be most helpful in identifying these individuals?
questions.solution:
• The western blot is a commonly used diagnostic technique that detects disease-specific proteins using antibodies targeted to those proteins.
  • This investigator is attempting to diagnose a disease (CJD) based on the presence of a specific amino acid sequence on a specific protein.
  • The ideal test in this case would be a western blot.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man develops acute pancreatitis due to alcohol abuse. Hyperamylasemia resolves by the third day after admission. By the eighth hospital day, the patient is noted to have recurrent fever (38.5°C), progressive leukocytosis (18,500 WBC/mm3), and tachypnea. Which of the following is the most appropriate management as the next step?

choices.text: CT guided aspiration of peripancreatic fluid collections
ERCP with sphincterotomy and placement of biliary stent

questions.solution:
The common causes of pancreatic abscesses are infected pancreatic pseudocysts and necrotizing pancreatitis. The diagnosis is suggested by persistent fever, leukocytosis, and a palpable abdominal mass. Bacteremia and systemic toxicity are late clinical features.

Percutaneous aspiration with positive cultures is the definitive preoperative test, facilitated by CT scanning or ultrasound guidance to suspicious peripancreatic fluid collections.

When diagnosed, the treatment of choice is wide surgical débridement with the removal of all infected and revitalized tissues. Generous drainage is mandatory. One of the major sources of morbidity and mortality in this situation is the late development of mycotic visceral pseudoaneurysms, particularly involving splenic circulation. These may be complex management problems, requiring angiographic embolization or other innovative treatment strategies.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with bloody nasal discharge, orbital swelling, and pain. Culture of periorbital pus showing branching septate hyphae in LPCB mount. Which of the following is the most probable organism involved –
questions.solution:
Option 1, 2, 3, 4

1. Hint is branching septate hyphae.

2. Aspergillus species are molds.

- They have septate hyphae that form V-shaped dichotomous branches. The Aspergillus species are identified by

  • (a) Their morphological features,
  • (b) The pattern of conidiophore development, and
  • (c) The color of the conidia.

- The presence of septate hyphae that branch at 45° angles is the typical feature of Aspergillus species hyphae. The hyphae in tissues are best demonstrated with silver stains. The walls of the hyphae are more or less parallel, unlike those of Mucor and Rhizopus, which are more or less irregular.

3. Mucor and Rhizopus have broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

4. Candida (GPOBYC) is a yeast like fungi.

questions.text: A 28- year old lady has asymptomatic dome-shaped small lesions on her face for the last 2 months. She has a 2-year-old son with similar lesions as shown in the image below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The lesions noted in this child are typical Dome-shaped, umbilicated papules, seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a cutaneous poxvirus infection characterized by papules.

  • Lesions measure 2–5 mm in diameter and are pearly, flesh-colored, and umbilicated, with a characteristic dimple at the center.
  • A relative lack of inflammation and necrosis distinguishes these proliferative lesions from other poxvirus lesions.
  • Lesions may be found—single or in clusters—anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles and may be associated with an eczematous rash.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a history of recent subclinical hepatitis C infection presents with a pruritic rash and mouth pain for the past week. On examination, lesions on his wrists, ankles, and scalp that were shiny, violaceous, sharply demarcated, and confluent papules containing fine white lines in a lacy pattern on their surfaces are noted. Erosion on the left buccal mucosa with the same fine white reticulation is also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lichen planus

The classic description of lichen planus:

  • "5 P's": Purple, Polygonal, Pruritic, and Planar Papules and Wickham's striae (the characteristic light grey or white lines or dots seen on the surface of lichen planus).
  • It affects middle-aged adults and may be associated with hepatitis C infection and/or drug exposure

Option A: Erythema multiforme

  • The rash of Erythema multiforme typically involves the extremities, palms, and soles and may consist of erythematous or purpuric plaques and bullae with central clearing.
  • Painful lesions are typical, though pruritus can be present as well.
  • Mucous membrane involvement is common.

Option B: Hypersensitivity vasculitis

  • Hypersensitivity vasculitis is typically drug-induced but may also result from hepatitis B or C infection.
  • It manifests as palpable purpura, and skin biopsy shows a leukocytoclastic vasculitis.

Option D: Viral exanthema

  • Viral exanthema rashes of widely varying morphology, common in children, typically more erythematous and macular, as opposed to the violaceous and papular lesions in lichen planus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old cricket player presented to OPD with complaints of headache and palpitations. O/E - He has a standing BP 190/100 mm Hg and sitting BP-180/100 mm Hg. He also has an irregularly irregular rhythm, double apical impulse, and bilateral basal crepitations. But no murmurs could be auscultated and heart rate could not be determined. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Condition Features
Left atrial Myxoma More common in a young female with symptoms of myxoma platypnea and low cardiac output since the tumor limits the blood flow into the left ventricle.
Mitral regurgitation Ruled out as no murmur was auscultated in the patient
Cor pulmonale Ruled out as primary lung disease or findings of RVF are absent
LVH

Points in favor of diagnosis:

  1. Hypertension can lead to LVH causing double apical impulse.
  2. HTN can lead to diastolic dysfunction and impacts the atria leading to atrial fibrillation and irregular pulse
  3. Basal crepitations can be explained by atrial fibrillation.
  4. BP changes in standing and supine position are normal (less than equal to 10mm Hg)

questions.text: A 61-year-old female patient presents to your clinic due to sudden episodes of left-sided facial pain for the last two days. She states that the pain feels like a 'sharp stabbing' and is a 9/10 in terms of intensity. The pain lasts about 5-10 seconds and then dissipates rapidly. The pain is often brought on by talking and cold wind. Her past medical history is significant for depression and type 2 D.M. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Trigeminal neuralgia

  • Trigeminal neuralgia is excruciating pain and needles sensations in lips, gums, cheeks, or chin.
  • Occurs spontaneously or with chewing, speaking, or smiling.
  • Presence of trigger zone (face, lips, tongue).
  • Provoked by the cold wind, brushing, or washing face.
  • Female > male.
  • Sudden in onset, persist for weeks to months and remits spontaneously.
  • The treatment for trigeminal neuralgia is anticonvulsant carbamazepine

Option A: Giant cell arteritis

  • Ruled out as it presents with jaw claudication or U/L headache, or temporal headache.

Option B: SUNCT syndrome

  • Ruled out is associated with conjunctival injection and tearing, so red eye should be present in the question.

Option D: Paroxysmal Hemicrania

  • Throbbing and stabbing pain at the temporal and orbit area
  • Duration 2-30 min
  • No alcohol or cutaneous trigger
  • Have autonomic and migrainous features
  • Respond well to Indomethacin.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child who has had frequent ear infections is found to have reduced immunoglobulin levels and is unresponsive to vaccination with tetanus toxoid. However, the child has normal skin test reactivity (delayed redness and induration) to a common environmental antigen. Which cell lineage is not functioning normally?
questions.solution:
• The presence of normal skin test reactivity, which is T cell–mediated, indicates normal function of macrophages and other antigen-presenting cells, helper T cells, and cytotoxic T cells.

This information, and the reduction in antibody production, localizes the defect to the B-cell lineage.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man undergoes CT scan study of the abdomen for unexplained abdominal distension. Low attenuation intraperitoneal collections with enhancing septae are demonstrated. There is scalloping of the liver border and omental thickening as shown below. Which one of the following is most likely to be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient would be Cystadenocarcinoma of the appendix (pseudomyxoma peritonei)

CT findings of pseudomyxoma peritonei include

  • Scalloping on the liver margin by peritoneal implants and septations, probably representing margins of mucinous nodules.
  • The abdominal distension is secondary to the accumulation of large quantities of gelatinous ascites.
  • It is most commonly caused by cystadenocarcinoma of the appendix in males and cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary in females.
  • Surgical debulking and intraperitoneal chemotherapy may be offered as a treatment.
  • Bowel obstruction is a frequent complication that may necessitate surgery.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents to OPD with an inability to focus on close objects over the previous few hours. However, she reports that she can see distant objects. On examination, she can move her eyes normally. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged in such a condition?

choices.text: Oculomotor nerve and long ciliary nerve
Short ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

questions.solution:
Option C: Short ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

  • Damage to parasympathetic ciliary ganglion and parasympathetic fibers in the short ciliary nerve impairs the ability to focus on close objects (accommodation). The short ciliary nerves innervate the orbit around the eye and are branches of the ciliary ganglion. Parasympathetic and sympathetic nerve fibers supply the ciliary muscle, iris, and cornea. Any damage to the short ciliary nerve can lead to loss of the pupillary light reflex or mydriasis.
  • The short ciliary nerves branch from the nasociliary nerve in the intraoral space through the ciliary ganglion. Together with long ciliary nerves, they innervate the entire globe, excluding the conjunctiva.

 

Option A: Ciliary ganglion and oculomotor nerve

  • These functions’ inability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. Because the patient can move her eyeballs normally, the oculomotor nerve is not damaged even if this nerve contains preganglionic parasympathetic fibers.
  • The ability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. Because the patient can move his eyeballs normally, the oculomotor nerve is not even damaged if this nerve contains.
  • The patient can see distant objects clearly because the long ciliary nerve carries sympathetic fibers to the dilator papillae. Damage to parasympathetic ciliary ganglion and parasympathetic fibers in the short ciliary nerve impairs the ability to focus on close objects (accommodation).

Option B: Oculomotor nerve and long Ciliary nerve

  • The ability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. The patient can see distant objects clearly because the long ciliary nerve carries sympathetic fibers to the dilator papillae.

Option D: Oculomotor and trochlear nerve

  • These nerves’ ability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. If the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves have any damage, it will affect the movement of the eyeball.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man develops jaundice and is demonstrated to have a 2.5cm mass in the pancreatic head by computed tomography. There are no signs of unresectability on CT examination. Fine needle aspiration cytology is positive for adenocarcinoma. Which of the following intraoperative findings would indicate unresectability?

choices.text: Fibrotic reaction in the body and tail of the pancreas
Microscopic tumor cells in peripancreatic lymph nodes on frozen section
Inability to develop an avascular plane anterior to the superior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
During the performance of pancreaticoduodenectomy, the lesser sac is opened widely through the gastrocolic omentum. This maneuver allows inspection of the body and tail of the gland to determine the extent of the tumor involvement and allows examination of lymph nodes along the superior and inferior body of the pancreas and around the celiac axis. Enlarged nodes in these areas should undergo biopsy and be submitted for frozen-section examination since tumor in these areas is beyond the bounds of standard pancreaticoduodenectomy and constitutes a contraindication to resection.

If there is no evidence of lymphadenopathy, a dissection between the anterior surface of the portal vein and the posterior surface of the neck of the pancreas is performed. Ordinarily, only thin areolar tissue lies between the pancreas and the portal vein, and communication behind the neck of the pancreas can be established.

*If there is hard tissue intervening and such communication cannot be established, this implies invasion of the anterior surface of the portal vein and signals unresectability by standard methods.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of a painful genital lesion and bleeding. Physical examination reveals an exophytic, ulcerated 1-cm polypoid mass near the external end of the urethra. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
(b) Caruncle

- This polypoid inflammatory lesion near the female urethral meatus elicits pain and bleeding.
- It occurs exclusively in women, most frequently after menopause.

Urethral caruncle presents as an exophytic, often ulcerated, polypoid mass of 1 to 2 cm in diameter.

- Microscopically, the lesion exhibits acutely and chronically inflamed granulation tissue and ulceration and hyperplasia of transitional cell or squamous epithelium. The other choices do not typically involve the urethral meatus.

questions.text: A 4½-year-old girl always had to wear warm socks even in the summer season. On physical examination, it was noticed that she had high blood pressure and her femoral pulse was weak as compared to radial and carotid pulse. A chest radiograph showed remarkable notching of ribs along their lower borders as shown below. This is likely to be due to
questions.solution:
Hypertension with weak femoral pulses and inferior rib nothing is highly suggestive of aortic coarctation.

Pulseless disease, Raynaud’s phenomena, and femoral artery thrombosis will not cause rib notching, neither present with hypertension at this age.

Coarctation Of The Aorta

· It is a congenital aortic narrowing in the region of the isthmus and may present in the neonate or remain undetected well into adult life.

· About 80% of patients are male.

· Hypertension is common, femoral pulses are usually delayed and weakened compared with the carotid and arm pulses.

· A post-ductal coarctation of aorta with PDA and reversal of shunt is associated with differential cyanosis involving the upper limbs only.

· One of the striking features in older children and adults is collateral circulation around the obstruction, the main collateral route being internal mammary arteries with retrograde flow to aorta below the coarctation through the intercostal arteries 3–9, the inferior epigastric arteries, scapular, and various mediastinal arteries.

· Rib notching (bilateral but asymmetric, and best seen on inferior aspects of posterior thirds of the upper ribs, sparing first two) usually takes several years to develop and is caused by pressure erosion of adjacent ribs by enlarged tortuous intercostal arteries. So, rib notching is rare in young children, even in severe coarctation.

Takayasu’saortoarteritis (Pulseless disease)

  • It is primary arteritis of unknown cause, first described by a Japanese ophthalmologist, Takayasu.
  • It commonly affects the aorta, the brachiocephalic branches, and pulmonary arteries.
  • The most commonly affected artery being the subclavian artery.
  • It is most common in young Asian women (M: F = 1:10).
  • The collateral circulation around the stenosis and occlusions may be seen and this is a rare cause of rib notching.

questions.text: A 72-year-old white male complains of difficulty reading fine print and fatigue after prolonged reading. O/E multiple, confluent soft drusen over the macula are present. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ARMD(age-related macular degeneration)-

Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), also called senile macular degeneration, is a bilateral disease of persons 59 years of age or older. It is a leading cause of blindness in developed countries,

Clinical types

1)Non-exudative or Dry ARMD. responsible for 90 percent of cases.

  • causes mild to moderate, gradual loss of vision. Patients complain of distorted vision, difficulty in reading due to central shadowing. '
  • characterized by the occurrence of drusens (colloid bodies), pale areas of retinal pigment epithelium atrophy, and irregular or clustered pigmentation that appear as small discrete, yellowish-white, slightly elevated spots.
  • In later stages, there occurs enlargement of the atrophic areas within which the larger choroidal vessels may become visible (geographic atrophy).

2) Exudative ARMD. It is also called wet or neovascular ARMD.

  • responsible for only 10 percent cases of ARMD
  • associated with comparatively rapidly progressive marked loss of vision.
  • May eventually scar with or without intervention, treatment reduces the extent of scarring and helps keep macula dry and preserve some vision

Typically, the course of exudative ARMD rapidly passes through many stages. These include:

  • Stage of drusen formation,
  • Stage of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment,
  • Stage of choroidal neovascularisation (CNV)
  • Stage of hemorrhagic detachment of RPE,
  • Stage of hemorrhagic detachment of the neurosensory retina, and
  • Stage of disciform (scarring) macular degeneration.

questions.text:
Read the case given & mark the statements as True/False by using the options given below.
A 5 yrs old child was taken for surgery. During induction of general anaesthesia, when mask ventilation, there was no chest movement and there was marked tracheal tug. The patient would be managed by
1. Checking that airway is clear of obstruction or any potential irritant
2. Increasing concentration of oxygen
3. Deepening the anaesthesia by increasing sevoflurane concentration
4. Suxamethonium IV may be given
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is larygospasm .

It is managed by

i. removing any triggering stimulation;

ii. ensuring a clear larynx, that is, checking for blood or stomach contents;

iii. relieving any possible supra-glottic component to the airway obstruction;

iv. application of CPAP with 100% oxygen.

v. Paralyzing with IV succinylcholine

questions.text: A patient presents with pulsatile tinnitus and deafness. An endoscopic picture of his tympanic membrane is given below. The red swelling blanches on pressure with pneumatic speculum. All are true about it except:

choices.text: Fluctuating conductive type of hearing loss is seen

questions.solution:
Clinical description and endoscopic picture are suggestive of Glomus.

  • Since the jugular bulb is related to the floor of the middle ear, this tumor comes into the middle ear from the floor leading to progressive conductive hearing loss

questions.text: For the annual cardiology visit of a 68-year-old woman, given an ECG report showing a net deflection of -1.2 millivolts in standard limb lead I and +1.2 millivolts in standard limb lead II, What will be the mean electrical axis of her QRS?
questions.solution:
Option D: + 120 degrees

  • The mean electrical axis is the principal vector of ventricular depolarisation. It denotes the sum of all the depolarisation waves that are occurring simultaneously.
  • The mean electrical axis mainly points toward the left ventricle, the larger of the two ventricles.
  • Clinical significance of ECG :
  • The MEA is used mainly to assist in assessing ventricular enlargement and recognising intraventricular conduction defects.
  • The net deflection of the QRS wave plotted on lead I am −1.2 millivolts, and lead II is +1.2 millivolts. Therefore, the absolute value of the deflection remains the same.
  • Therefore, the mean electrical axis must be exactly halfway between these two leads, which is halfway between the lead II axis of 60 degrees and the lead I negative axis of 180 degrees, which provides a value of 120 degrees.

questions.text: An analytic tool that depicts the entire spectrum of movement of pregnant women to a number of facilities for want of care before they succumbed to fatality is known as?
questions.solution:
Minerva (Mortality in India established through Verbal Autopsies)

  • Online death coding platform at AIIMS-Delhi
  • The platform enables physicians to review the verbal autopsy form and enter the cause of death in the form of a standard international code sitting at their office.
  • The system has been necessitated by the fact that most deaths in India, especially in rural areas are not medically certified.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presented to the emergency with acute appendicitis. He is to be taken up for emergency appendectomy. On preoperative evaluation, you as the anaesthetist find out that he had undergone a balloon angioplasty 15 days ago and is taking aspirin 75 mg. What is your further course of action?

choices.text: Stop aspirin for at least 3 days before taking the patient up for surgery
Wait for another 2 weeks before taking the patient for surgery as he has history of balloon angioplasty
Take the patient up for surgery
Ask the surgeon to manage conservatively as the patient is not fit for anaesthesia

questions.solution: The patient can be taken up for surgery, since it (Time since PCI) has been >14days.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy young adult male presents with multiple, irregular, painless, non-itchy spots of brownish pigmentation on right lower leg for almost a year. There is no history of trauma. His physical examination is otherwise normal and the routine lab results are normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Schamberg’s disease [syn. progressive pigmented purpuric dermatosis]

  • This uncommon eruption is most common in young adult males but may occur at any age including childhood. Familial incidence has been reported.
  • The lesions are most frequent on the lower limbs but may occur anywhere on the body, including the palms, and maybe few in number or very extensive.
  • They consist of irregular plaques of orange or brown pigmentation due to haemosiderin, with characteristic ‘cayenne pepper’ spots appearing within and at the edge of old lesions.
  • Slight changes in the epidermis may occur. There are usually no symptoms, although there may be some slight itching. The eruption is characteristically very chronic and may persist for many years.

-Lichen aureus [syn. lichen purpuricus]

  • This is a more localized, more intensely purpuric but often asymptomatic eruption that may have rather lichenoid morphology.
  • Young adults and children are often affected, on the body, limbs, or even face. The lesions are often solitary and may be yellowish, golden, rust-colored, or purple.
  • They may resemble a bruise, and hence must be distinguished from non-accidental injury in children, but may persist for a few years. Histologically, lichen aureus is distinguished from other pigmented purpuric dermatoses by a lack of epidermal component and in some cases a Grenz zone.

-Purpura annularis telangiectodes [syn. Majocchi’s disease]

  • This eruption occurs especially in adolescents and young adults of either sex but may occur at any age, and maybe familial.
  • Exercise may have been a provoking factor in one case. The clinical features are distinctive and described in its name.
  • Lesions occur at any site, often in the absence of venous stasis, and maybe few in number or very numerous.
