  • They consist of small plaques 1–3 cm across that is usually annular from their onset. Lesions consist of telangiectases and haemosiderin staining of the skin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with flaccid bullae on an erythematous base and erosions over the oral mucous membrane. The blisters developed painful erosions on rupture. What would be the most likely finding on an immunofluorescent examination of the skin biopsy of this patient?

choices.text: Linear IgA deposition in dermoepidermal junction
Linear IgG deposition in dermoepidermal junction
Fish net IgG deposition in epidermis
Granular deposits of IgA in dermal papillae

questions.solution:
• Clinical history like flaccid bullae, oral mucosal involvement, tendency to rupture and erode, is suggestive of pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • The Immunofluorescent examination finding in Pemphigus Vulgaris is the deposition of lgG3 & C3 in intercellular space giving a fish-net pattern.

questions.text: On examination, a 34 weeks pregnant lady was found to be HBsAg. What is the management for neonate delivered by Hep B + patient?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin followed by vaccine 6 month later

questions.solution:
Hepatitis B vaccine + Immunoglobulin should be given to a neonate born to mother who is HBsAg positive.

  • The simultaneous administration of HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine is more efficacious than HBIG alone.
  • HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine.
  • This combined procedure is ideal both

- for prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain hepatitis B virus, and

- for prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is being treated for pulmonary emphysema. He is admitted with labored breathing at rest with marked use of accessory muscles. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed:
pH 7.33
PaCO2 64 mm Hg
PaO2 50 mm Hg
HCO3 34 mEq/L
What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Since the patient with emphysema presents with respiratory distress and muscle fatigue, on clinical grounds he is probably having respiratory acidosis.

  • pH of blood =7.33, interpretation is acidosis
  • pCO2 is 64 mm Hg (average of 40 mmHg), interpretation is increased pCO2 which explains the acidosis.
  • HCO3 is increased and indicates compensation (N = 22-26 mEq).
  • The diagnosis is compensated respiratory acidosis. The next step is to find out acute versus chronic compensation.
  • The rule to be followed for acute compensation is for every 10 mm Hg rise of pCO2, HCO3 rises by 1 mEq.
  • The rule to be followed for chronic compensation is for every 10 mmHg rise of pC02, HC03 rises by 4mEq or more.
  • Since the rule mentioned just above this statement is mathematically satisfied, the diagnosis is chronic compensated respiratory acidosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about osteoporosis?

Z score measures the bone mineral density compared to Age, race, and sex-matched individuals
Raised ALP and normal calcium is seen
Strontium ranelate acts by inhibiting resorption as well as stimulation of the formation of bone
Denosumab acts by decreasing the resorption of bone
questions.solution:
Option A- Z score and t-score are measured by using DEXA scan and helps in the diagnosis of osteoporosis.

Z- score: compares the patients with that of adults of the same age, race, and sex.

T-score: It shows how much higher or lower your bone density is than that of a healthy 30-year-old, the age when bones are at their strongest.

· T-score of -1.0 or above = normal bone density

· T-score between -1.0 and -2.5 = low bone density, or osteopenia

· T-score of -2.5 or lower = osteoporosis

Option B- Osteoporosis- Normal ALP, normal calcium, normal phosphate levels

Options C, D-

Drugs used for osteoporosis
Inhibit resorption Stimulate formation

Bisphosphonates

Denosumab

Calcitonin

SERM

Gallium nitrate

Teriparatide

Calcium

Calcitriol

Fluorides

STRONTIUM RANELATE is the only drug acting via both mechanisms.

questions.text: A medical officer is examining the genitalia of a 23-year-old college student who has filed a complaint against a fellow student. She alleges that she was invited by him on the pretext of meeting his family but was raped at the hotel they were staying in.Which area will be described by the doctor in her report, when she examines the triangular space bounded by the clitoris above, hymen below, and the labia minora laterally?
questions.solution:
Option B: Vestibule

  • The Vestibule is the triangular surface that extends from the clitoris above to the anterior margin of the hymen below, and laterally to the labia minora.

Option A: Fossa navicularis

  • The depression between the fourchette and the vaginal orifice is called fossa navicularis.

Option C: Fourchette

  • The lower portions of labia minora fuse in the midline and form a fold called fourchette.

Option D: Vulva

  • The vulva includes the mons veneris (pad of fat lying in front of the pubis), clitoris, labia majora and minora, Vestibule, hymen, and urethral opening.

questions.text: At this stage of delivery (shown in the video clip), what could be the complication and its management?

choices.text: Deep Transverse arrest - Manual rotation & forceps extraction

questions.solution:
Option C: Shoulder dystocia - McRobert's manoeuvre

The steps of delivery shown in the video clip are delivery by extension, external rotation, and lateral flexion.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when the foetal shoulders fail to deliver spontaneously after the head has been delivered due to the impaction of the anterior shoulder against the pubic bone. McRoberts manoeuvre is employed for the management of shoulder dystocia.

Steps in the management of shoulder dystocia:

  • Call for help
  • Apply suprapubic pressure to disengage the anterior shoulder
  • Flex the mother's legs over the abdomen, i.e. McRobert's manoeuvre
  • Rotate the posterior shoulder and attempt delivery of the posterior shoulder, i.e. Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre
  • Push the delivered foetal head back into the delivery canal in preparation for a caesarean section, i.e. Zavanelli's restitution
  • Apply modest downward traction to the posterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal sacrum) or upward traction to the anterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal symphysis) with the patient on her hands and knees, i.e. Gaskin manoeuvre
  • A generous episiotomy should always be made to allow manipulations
  • There is no role for fundal pressure.

Option A: Shoulder dystocia - Fundal Pressure

  • There is no role of fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia. Rather suprapubic pressure is applied in the initial stages of management.
  • The purpose of suprapubic pressure is to abduct the anterior foetal shoulder and reduce the foetal bi-acromial diameter. From the foetal back toward the front, pressure is delivered downward or rolling on the suprapubic area.

Option B: Deep Transverse arrest - Manual rotation forceps extraction

  • When the head is deeply embedded in the cavity, the sagittal suture is positioned in the transverse bi-spinous diameter, and the head is still not descending even after 0.5 or 1 hour following full cervical dilatation, deep, transverse arrest (DTA) has occurred.
  • It might be the result of the oblique OPP's incomplete anterior rotation, or it could be caused by the common occipital transverse position of the normal mechanism of labour not rotating.
  • Manual rotation forceps extraction is DTA's most commonly employed vaginal delivery method.

Option D : Shoulder dystocia : Gaskin's manouvre

  • Gaskin's manoeuvre involves applying gentle downward traction to the posterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal sacrum) or upward traction to the anterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal symphysis) with the patient on her hands and knees
  • It may be performed for shoulder dystocia, however Mc.Roberts manouvre is performed first

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is given by intravenous infusion, is very short-acting and acts via G protein-coupled receptors?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fenoldopam

  • The above case suggestive of Hypertensive emergency because of end organ damage.
  • Fenoldopam is a peripheral arteriolar dilator used for hypertensive emergencies and postoperative hypertension. It acts primarily as an agonist of dopamine D1 receptors which are G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), resulting in the dilation of peripheral arteries and natriuresis.
  • Fenoldopam is rapidly metabolized, primarily by conjugation, and it is very short-acting.
  • Its half-life is 10 minutes.
  • The drug is administered by continuous intravenous infusion.

Option B: Hydralazine

  • It is a direct-acting vasodilator which exerts its effects principally on the arterioles.
  • It is used to treat severe hypertension but is not a first-line therapy for essential hypertension.
  • Hydralazine is often used to treat hypertension in pregnancy.
  • It acts by releasing NO, which acts on intracellular guanylate cyclase. These do not act on GPCRs.

 

Option C: Metoprolol

  • It is a selective β₁ receptor blocker used to treat chest pain due to poor blood flow to the heart, high blood pressure, and many other conditions which involve abnormal tachycardia.
  • By working on the beta-1 receptor of the cardiac muscle cells, it yields both a chronotropic and inotropic effect.
  • Common side effects include trouble sleeping, feeling faint, feeling tired, and abdominal discomfort.

 

Option D: Nitroprusside

  • Sodium nitroprusside is intravenously infused in acute hypertensive crises.
  • Nitric oxide can reduce both total peripheral resistance (TPR) and venous return (VR), thus decreasing both afterload and preload. So it can be used in congestive heart failure, as this combination of effects can act to increase cardiac output.
  • It acts by releasing NO, which acts on intracellular guanylate cyclase. These do not act on GPCRs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old married nullipara undergoes laparoscopic cystectomy for an ovarian cyst which on histopathology reveals ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma. What should be the next management?

choices.text: Serial Ca125 measurement and follow up

questions.solution:
Here the patient is 25 years old nullipara and the cystectomy sample shows serous cystadenocarcinoma - Probably the disease is limited to the ovary removed, hence to be called stage Ia.

Doing an oophorectomy here will suffice as the patient is young and nullipara. The next step is to follow the patient with regular CA 125 estimations. Though the levels of CA 125 are not specific, but in this condition where the follow-up is after a known cause, there is ample sensitivity.

“Fertility preservation in early-stage ovarian cancer - The uterus and the contralateral ovary can be preserved in women with stage Ia, grade 1 to 2 disease who desire to preserve fertility. The conditions of the women should be monitored carefully with routine periodic pelvic examination and determinations of serum CA 125 levels.

questions.text: Observe the procedure shown below carefully. What is the name of the procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown above is Mid-tracheostomy.

Tracheostomy

  • A Mid tracheostomy is the preferred one and is done through the II or III ring and would entail the division of the thyroid isthmus or its retraction upwards or downwards to expose this part of the trachea.
  • A high tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal rings). It violates the first ring of trachea. Tracheostomy at this site can cause perichondritis of the cricoids cartilage and subglottic stenosis and is always avoided. The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx because in such cases, the total larynx anyway would ultimately be removed and a fresh tracheostome made in a clean area lower down.
  • A low tracheostomy is done below the level of the isthmus. The trachea is deep at this level and close to several large vessels; also there are difficulties with tracheostomy tube which impinges on suprasternal notch.

Cricothyroidotomy or laryngotomy or mini tracheostomy. This is a procedure for opening the airway through the cricothyroid membrane. The patient’s head and neck are extended, lower border of thyroid cartilage and cricoids ring are identified. Skin in this area is incised vertically and then cricothyroid membrane cut with a transverse incision. This space can be kept open with a small tracheostomy tube or by inserting the handle of the knife and turning it at right angles if the tube is not available. It is essential to perform an orderly tracheostomy as soon as possible because perichondritis, subglottic edema, and laryngeal stenosis can follow prolonged laryngotomy.

questions.text: A wheelchair-bound 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fatigue and shortness of breath. Physical examination shows he has clusters of bright red blood vessels on the sclera of both eyes. A chest x-ray reveals a large mediastinal mass, which is subsequently identified as non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms, involving a tumor suppressor gene, is most likely defective in this patient’s cells?
questions.solution:
This patient possesses the traits associated with ataxia-telangiectasia, including telangiectasias of the skin and eyes, variable immunodeficiency, and progressive ataxia. Most patients are wheelchair-bound by adolescence.

  • The gene responsible for the disease is called ATM and is classified as a *tumor suppressor gene* that encodes a DNA-dependent protein kinase localized mainly to the nucleus.
  • This kinase is involved in the process that is responsible for recognizing double-strand DNA breaks and initiating the appropriate repair mechanisms.
  • With the mutation of ATM, cells have increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation, and exhibit defective DNA repair associated with frequent chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Therefore, these individuals should avoid unnecessary x-ray exposures. The incidence of malignancy is high, especially lymphoreticular malignancies (Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas and leukemias).

Unresolved DNA replication errors can lead to mismatched base pairs.

These mismatches are normally identified by a protein complex that can recognize the bulge in the DNA molecule that is created by the mismatched bases. Once identified, the mismatch is then repaired by a separate complex with exonuclease activity. A mutation in one or more of these genes ultimately leads to an accumulation of DNA mutations due to the inability to eliminate the mismatches. Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome) is a disease caused by mutations in genes involved in mismatch repair, including MSH2 and MLH. These individuals have an increased risk of colorectal cancers and endometrial cancers.

During DNA replication, if the DNA polymerase inserts the incorrect nucleotide, it has the ability to correct the error. This process is known as DNA polymerase proofreading (choice B) and is due to the polymerase’s 3’ to 5' exonuclease activity. Mutations that affect the proofreading function of DNA polymerase are associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancers.

questions.text: A mother brings her 1 year old ; incompletely immunised child to hospital with a complaint of cough and sounds from chest since yesterday. Based on history and examination, you diagnose the child as having Acute bronchiolitis. All of the following are true about the condition except :

choices.text: Presence of hyper inflated chest on X-Ray
Antibiotics and moist oxygen are used for treatment

questions.solution:
Rx is mainly supportive as no role of antibiotics as it’s a viral infection.

Acute Bronchiolitis:

  • Age group 6 months to 2 years.
  • MC agent is RSV
  • Clinical features: Viral prodrome followed by tachypnea, retractions and hypoxemia, wheeze and crepitations heard on examination
  • Chest X-ray: Hyperinflated chest
  • Treatment: Moist Oxygen
  • In immunocompromised children and those on ventialtor: Nebulized Ribavirin is indicated

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of epigastric pain, worsened with ingestion of food. Physical examination is normal. Upper abdominal ultrasonography is unremarkable. Contrast radiography shown below reveals a 2 cm ulcer in the gastric fundus along the lesser curvature.

Therapy with omeprazole 20 mg per day is begun but symptoms persist 3 weeks later. Which of the following would be appropriate management?

choices.text: Increase in omeprazole dose to 40 mg per day
Addition of sucralfate 1 gm every 8 hours

questions.solution:
About 5% of ulcers appearing radiographically benign are malignant. Gastroscopy is the most reliable method of distinguishing benign and malignant gastric ulcer, with an accuracy of more than 97% if multiple biopsies and brushings for cytology are performed.

Clinical features prompting early endoscopic evaluation include major weight loss, symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction, a palpable abdominal mass, and stool hemoccult positivity or blood loss anemia.

Endoscopic features that suggest malignancy include an exophytic mass, abnormal or disrupted mucosal folds, necrotic ulcer crater, bleeding from the edge of the ulcer crater, a stepwise depression of the ulcer edge, heaped-up margins, or small extensions of the ulcer that blur a portion of the ulcer wall.

If initial biopsies do not demonstrate malignant cells but the endoscopic appearance strongly suggests that underlying the ulcer is a carcinoma, repeat endoscopy with deeper biopsies should be undertaken.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought with c/o progressive weakness & difficulty getting up as shown in the below videography. He also showed pseudohypertrophy (enlarging) of the muscles of the tongue, calves, buttocks, and shoulders. Family history revealed a X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. What is the MC type of mutation leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
The characteristic pattern of awkward walking, stepping, or running along with pseudohypertrophy and X-linked recessive inheritance indicate that it is a case of Duchene Muscular dystrophy (DMD) which occur due to deletion of exon in DMD gene at Xp2 locus.

As a result the remaining exons are not able to join in proper frame causing a Frameshift mutation.

This gene encodes dystrophin- sarcolemmal Protein necessary for proper muscle formation.

C/f :

  • progressive weakness
  • difficulty in getting up

Option b and d) In transversion and transition mutation one base is changed to other but there is no addition or deletion of extra genetic material.

Inversion: alteration in the position of genes within the same chromosomes. Two Types: Paracentric and Pericentric. Para- exchange on the same side of centromere. Peri- exchange on the different side of centromere. Again there is no deletion or insertion.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of abdominal cramps, vomiting, a low-grade fever, and 10 to 12 episodes of non-bloody diarrhea per day. She recently returned from a 1-week vacation in Mexico and says that she primarily ate salads during her stay. Her temperature is 38.4ºC (101.1ºF), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 119/78 mm Hg, and respiration rate is 16/min. She has diffuse abdominal tenderness with no evidence of guarding or rebound tenderness. A stool sample shows the presence of fecal leukocytes. Stool culture results are pending. The physician decides to prescribe an antimicrobial. Which of the following drugs should the patient receive as an empiric treatment?
questions.solution:
When individuals travel from one country to another that has marked differences in climate and sanitation standards, the risk for the development of traveler's diarrhea is dramatically increased. This type of diarrhea is most likely to develop within 2 to 10 days* after ingesting local water and/or eating fresh fruits and vegetables (such as a fresh salad) that could have been "washed off" with the local water.

Traveler's diarrhea is often accompanied by the appearance of approximately 10 or more episodes of diarrhea per day, as well as severe abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and a mild fever. Depending on the causative bacteria, blood and/or fecal leukocytes may be present. The absence of blood in the stool helps to rule out organisms such as EHEC and amebiasis.

Most cases of traveler's diarrhea are caused by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), Shigella species, and Campylobacter jejuni.

Note: Both Shigella species and C. jejuni can cause bloody diarrhea. The primary treatment for travelers’ diarrhea is supportive care; however, antibiotics are used in more severe cases. The most commonly used agents to treat traveler's diarrhea are azithromycin or the fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin, and norfloxacin. They are often used because of the widespread resistance of E. coli to other antibacterials.

None of the other answer choice agents are indicated for the treatment of traveler's diarrhea

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy receives a deep laceration over his right eyebrow playing ice hockey. The wound is cleaned and sutured. Which of the following describes the principal function of macrophages that are present in the wound 24 to 48 hours after the injury?
questions.solution:
• Macrophages arrive at the site of injury shortly after neutrophils, but they persist in the wound for days longer.
  • Macrophages remove debris and orchestrate the formation of granulation tissue by releasing cytokines and chemoattractants.

None of the other choices are functions of tissue macrophages. For example, plasma cells produce antibodies (choice A), and myofibroblasts mediate wound contraction.

Diagnosis: Laceration

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of vaginal itching, discharge, and pain during intercourse. She has had 3 different sexual partners over the past 2 years. As part of the workup, the doctor did a wet mount of vaginal secretions that showed flagellated organisms with "twitching motility". Identify the organism
questions.solution:
Certainly, based on the clinical presentation and the description of flagellated organisms with "twitching motility" in the wet mount, the most likely organism responsible for these symptoms is Trichomonas vaginalis.

Correct options:

  1. Trichomonas vaginalis: This is the correct answer. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. It commonly presents with symptoms like vaginal itching, frothy discharge, and pain during intercourse. The characteristic "twitching motility" is due to its flagellated nature, which can be observed under a microscope.

Other Options:

  • Candida albicans: Candida is a yeast that can cause vaginal infections known as yeast infections or candidiasis. However, it does not exhibit flagellated motility. Symptoms include itching, white cottage cheese-like discharge, and pain during intercourse.

  • Gardnerella vaginalis: Gardnerella vaginalis is associated with bacterial vaginosis, a common vaginal infection. It causes a fishy-smelling discharge. However, it is a bacterium and does not exhibit flagellated motility.

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacterium responsible for gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection. It can cause vaginal discharge and discomfort, but it does not exhibit flagellated motility.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of swelling in the left inguinal region for the last 3 months. There is no history of chronic cough or constipation. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 140/90mmHg, a regular pulse rate of 90 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. On examination, a test is performed, as shown in the figure. Which of the following is correct about its anatomical relations?

choices.text: The neck of the sac lies medial to inferior epigastric vessels
The neck of the sac lies over the inferior epigastric vessel
Contents lie within a covering of the spermatic cord
Swelling enters through the superficial inguinal ring

questions.solution:
Option C: Contents lie within a covering of the spermatic cord

  • The image above shows an inguinal scrotal swelling with a positive cough impulse. On occlusion of the deep inguinal ring, the cough impulse becomes absent. So, this is a case of an indirect inguinal hernia.
  • An indirect hernia occurs when abdominal contents protrude through the internal inguinal ring and into the inguinal canal. It occurs due to the failure of the processus vaginalis to close.
  • The contents lie within the covering of the spermatic cord.
  • Indirect inguinal hernia is more common in the younger age group than a direct inguinal hernia, which is more common in the elderly.
  • It is more common on the right side in 1st decade. But in 2nd decade, the incidence is equal on both sides. While hernia is bilateral in 30% of cases.
  • The standard treatment for indirect inguinal hernias in adults is mesh repair.

Option A: The neck of the sac lies medial to inferior epigastric vessels

  • In the case of an indirect inguinal hernia, the neck of the inguinal sac is narrow.
  • It lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels. 

Option B: The neck of the sac lies over inferior epigastric vessels

  • In the case of an indirect inguinal hernia, the inguinal sac lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels.

Option D: Swelling enters through the superficial inguinal ring

  • In the case of an indirect inguinal hernia, the swelling enters via the deep inguinal ring, inguinal canal and then superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy suffering from congenital deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by an ischemic forearm exercise test by squeezing a rubber ball. This patient would exhibit which one of the following as compared to a normal person performing the same test?

choices.text: Increased blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.solution:
Option D: Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Normal or low blood lactate and increased blood ammonia after an ischemic exercise test suggest a defect in the conversion of glycogen (glucose) to lactate.
  • This is observed in the case of McArdle's disease, which occurs due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme such that glycogen cannot be converted to glucose and further to lactate in exercising muscle.
  • Hence, relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise compared to a normal individual.
  • Another thing that happens is that due to a lack of energy and ATP, muscle cells get damaged. Hence myoglobin will be released in urine, causing myoglobinuria.
  • Definitive diagnosis of this disease can be done by:
    • Enzymatic assay in muscle tissue
    • Mutation analysis of the myophosphorylase gene
  • Abnormal exercise response also occurs with
    • Deficiencies of muscle phosphofructokinase
    • Deficiencies of the debranching enzyme (when the test is done after fasting).

Option A: Exercise endurance

  • Any type of glycogen storage disease in muscles causes exercise intolerance and muscle cramps due to a lack of stored muscle glycogen utilization.
  • So, in McArdle’s disease also, there is no chance of developing exercise endurance.

Option B: Increased  blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • Muscle cells can take glucose from the blood during exercise, but muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose due to a lack of a glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.
  • So, there can’t be any increased blood glucose in the blood vein of exercising forearm; rather, it will show decreased blood glucose

Option C: Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

  • In glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, free glucose is not generated
  • Hence no lactate is formed due to a lack of glucose
  • Therefore, the blood level of lactate falls.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented to you with complaints of cough and dyspnoea. Chest x-ray demonstrates patchy areas of consolidation. Histopathological examination is shown below. Based on the findings, what is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Histologically, cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is characterized by the presence of polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue (Masson bodies) within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and often bronchioles.

questions.text: By 2022, every rural person in the country will have access to ___ lpcd within their household premises or at a horizontal or vertical distance of not more than ___ meters from their household without barriers of social or financial discrimination:
questions.solution:
Option D: 70 and 50

  • Every rural person in the country will have access to 70 lpcd within their household premises or at a horizontal or vertical distance of not more than 50 meters from their household without barriers of social financial discrimination.

questions.text: A 13-year-old presents with a 3-month history of a painful left knee. There is no preceding history of trauma. An AP left knee x-ray demonstrates a well-defined lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim in the center of the tibial epiphysis. A subsequent CT of the region demonstrates that the cortex is intact and the lesion is confined to the epiphysis. MRI shows that the lesion is high signal on STIR and T2 weighted images with surrounding marrow edema and fluid-fluid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chondroblastoma is a cartilaginous tumor containing characteristic multiple calcium deposits. It is the most common benign tumor of the epiphysis or epiphysoid bones of children and adolescents. Bones around the knee are commonly affected. Radiologically, there is a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by a zone of sclerosis. Areas of calcification within the tumor substance give rise to a mottled appearance. Treatment is by curettage and bone grafting.

Other options:

-GCT (OSTEOCLASTOMA) is seen commonly in the age group of 20-40 years i.e., after epiphyseal fusion. The bones affected commonly are those around the knee i.e., lower-end of the femur and upper end of the tibia. The Lower-end of the radius is another common site. The tumor is located at the epiphysis. It often reaches almost up to the joint surface.

Following are some of the characteristic radiological features of GCT:

• A solitary, maybe loculated, lytic lesion.• Eccentric location, often subchondral. • Expansion of the overlying cortex (expansile). • 'Soap-bubble' appearance - the tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving rise to a loculated appearance. • No calcification within the tumor. • None or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor. • Cortex may be thinned out, or perforated at places. • Tumour usually does not enter the adjacent joint.

-SIMPLE BONE CYST is the only true cyst of the bone, different from other lesions, which though appear clear 'cyst-like on X-ray, are actually osteolytic, sometimes solid lesions. It occurs in children and adolescents. The ends of the long bones are the favorite sites; the commonest being the upper end of the humerus. X-rays show a well-defined, lobulated, radiolucent zone in the metaphysis or diaphysis of a bone. The cyst is known to undergo spontaneous healing, particularly after a fracture. One or two injections of methylprednisolone into the cyst results in healing. Some cases need curettage and bone grafting.

-ANEURYSMAL BONE CYST is a benign bone lesion occurring in a wide age group and affects almost any bone. It consists of a blood-filled space enclosed in a shell, ballooning up the overlying cortex - hence its name. It is common between 10-40 years of age. Common sites are the long bones, usually at their ends.

Typical radiological fractures are as follows:

• Eccentric well-defined radiolucent area. • Expansion of the overlying cortex. • Trabeculation within the substance of the tumor. Treatment is by curettage and bone grafting.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy has vitamin D refractory rickets. Investigations revealed calcium – 9 mg/dL, phosphate – 2.4 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase – 1040 IU/L. Parathyroid and bicarbonate levels are normal. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• In this question, calcium levels are normal (range: 9 – 10 mg/dL). However, phosphate is low (normal range: 3 – 4.5 mg/dL) and alkaline phosphatase is high (normal range: up to 120 IU/L).
  • Among the given options, hypophosphatemic rickets and proximal RTA (renal tubular acidosis) are the possibilities (both are associated with low phosphate)
  • However, RTA is associated with low bicarbonate, but in the question, bicarbonate levels are mentioned as normal.
  • Hence we are left with hypophosphatemic rickets which is the answer.

questions.text: You are called to the emergency room to see a 5-year-old child who has been vomiting for two days. She is thin, pale, lethargic, and febrile (102.4°F). She has a respiratory rate of 39 beats per minute (bpm) and a diffusely tender, rigid abdomen without localizing signs. You should:-

choices.text: Order an abdominal/pelvic CT scan with oral contrast to clarify the diagnosis
Realize that her omentum is likely to “wall off” and contain the infection
Order a barium enema to rule out intussusception
Take her immediately to the operating room for abdominal exploration

questions.solution:
Conditions other than appendicitis, such as mesenteric adenitis, could possibly present like this; but this child’s pale countenance and tachypnea suggest impending septic shock.

While a 10–20-mL/kg fluid bolus and antibiotics should be rapidly administered; this child clearly has an acute surgical abdomen and requires urgent exploration. The thicker adult omentum will frequently contain a perforated appendix, creating an abscess. A young child’s omentum is typically thin and flimsy and perforation usually leads rapidly to diffuse peritonitis.

- Barium enema to rule out intussusception, which would be unlikely in a child this old, is contraindicated in the presence of peritoneal signs. If further imaging were desired, USG is fast, generally well-tolerated, and can be quite revealing in thin, young children. CAT scanning would involve radiation exposure, which can be difficult to read in which this child would likely vomit up.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of clumsiness in her hands while working in the kitchen for the past 1 year. She recently burned her hands on the stove without experiencing any pain. Neurologic examination reveals bilateral weakness of the shoulder girdles, arms, and hands, as well as a loss of pain and temperature sensation covering the shoulder and upper limb in a cape-like distribution. Severe atrophy is present in the intrinsic muscles of the hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Syringomyelia

  • Syringomyelia is a developmental cavity of the cervical cord that may enlarge and produce progressive myelopathy
  • CAUSES
    • >50% of cases are associated with Chiari type 1 malformations
  • CLINICAL FEATURES
    • The presentation is a central cord syndrome consisting of a regional dissociated sensory loss (loss of pain and temperature sensation with sparing of touch and vibration) and areflexic weakness in the upper limbs.
    • The sensory deficit has a distribution that is "suspended" over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands.
    • Muscle wasting in the lower neck, shoulders, arms, and hands with asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms reflects the expansion of the cavity in the grey matter of the cord.
    • As the cavity enlarges and compresses the long tracts, spasticity, and weakness of the legs, bladder and bowel dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome appear.
    • Extension of the syrinx into the medulla, syringobulbia, causes palatal or vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, horizontal or vertical nystagmus, episodic dizziness or vertigo, and tongue weakness with atrophy.
  • DIAGNOSIS
    • MRI accurately identifies developmental and acquired syrinx cavities and their associated spinal cord enlargement
  • TREATMENT
    • Treatment of syringomyelia is generally unsatisfactory. The Chiari tonsillar herniation may be decompressed, generally by suboccipital craniectomy, upper cervical laminectomy, and placement of a dural graft.

Option A: ALS

  • ALS is a pure motor syndrome with U.M.N. and L.M.N. symptoms

Option B: Subacute combined degeneration

  • Subacute combined degeneration includes both sensory and motor deficits. It occurs due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency

Option D:Tabes dorsalis

  • Tabes dorsalis is a pure sensory syndrome (neurosyphilis). The patient can experience sensory ataxia when his eyes are closed

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with chronic cough for more than 2 months. Examine the X-ray carefully. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows cystic lesion suggesting aspergilloma (fungal ball)

  • Aspergillomas, typically appear as rounded or ovoid soft-tissue attenuating masses located in a surrounding cavity and outlined by a crescent of air. Altering the position of the patient usually demonstrates that the mass is mobile, thus confirming the diagnosis.
  • Monod sign simply describes air that surrounds a mycetoma (most commonly an aspergilloma) in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis is a collective term used to refer to a number of conditions caused by infection with a fungus of the Aspergillus species (usually Aspergillus fumigatus).
  • There are a number of recognized pulmonary forms-Each form has specific clinical and radiological features.
  • Aspergilloma (saprophytic/noninvasive aspergillosis): the most common form seen radiographically shows Monod sign.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) shows characteristic finger in glove opacities* and central bronchiectasis*.
  • Invasive Aspergillosis –present with ground-glass attenuation surrounding the lesion called halo sign.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of anxiety and fear over losing her job. She states that, she is late to work every day because before she leaves for work she repeatedly checks all the faucets and the stove. She also returns from her car several times before leaving to ensure that her doors and windows are locked. She was previously treated with fluoxetine for her condition; however, seemed to show no clinical improvement. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)

Both tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are effective in treating this disorder.
Clomipramine, a TCA, inhibits both 5-HT and NE reuptake. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, sertraline, and citalopram are the treatment of choice for OCD; however, the TCA clomipramine is generally used in the treatment of OCD unresponsive to an SSRI (as with this patient).

None of the other answer choices listed constitute effective therapy for this disorder.

questions.text: A previously healthy 21-year-old woman has a profuse, malodorous vaginal discharge. Examination shows a greenish-gray "frothy" discharge with a "fishy" odor and petechial lesions on the cervix. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Her temperature is 37.5 C (99.4 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 16/min. Microscopic evaluation of the discharge is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
- This patient has trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is caused by a motile, flagellated protozoan, Trichomonas vaginalis. The symptoms include a copious, malodorous ("fishy"), greenish-gray, "frothy" discharge.
- The vulvar and vaginal epithelium may be erythematous and edematous. Colposcopy may reveal petechial cervical lesions ("strawberry cervix"). A wet mount of the discharge often reveals motile trichomonads and polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs). The treatment is metronidazole. Simultaneous treatment of the sexual partner reduces the risk of reinfection.
- "Clue cells" vaginal squamous epithelial cells coated with coccobacillary organisms are seen in bacterial vaginosis. The symptoms include a moderate amount of malodorous ("fishy"), white to gray, homogeneous vaginal discharge. An amine ("fishy") odor is present after mixing vaginal secretions with KOH. This is often called a positive whiff test. Saline preparations of the discharge reveal the "clue cells". The treatment is metronidazole. Simultaneous treatment of the sexual partner has not been shown to reduce recurrence.
- Gram-negative diplococci are an indication of Neisseria gonorrhoeae. N. gonorrhoeae causes a mucopurulent cervical discharge in acute cervicitis and can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID is characterized by lower abdominal pain, fever, and cervical motion tenderness. Diagnosis is often made by Gram's stain of cervical secretions revealing gram-negative diplococci and polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Treatment is ceftriaxone IM once and doxycycline or azithromycin. The 2 latter drugs are given since concomitant chlamydial infection is common.

questions.text:
Match the following substances with their common names:




A. LSD
B. Abrus precatorius
C. Cocaine
D. Capsaicin


1. White lady
2. Purple haze
3. Hunan hand
4. Ratti
questions.solution:
• Purple haze is commonly used as a street name for a potent form of cannabis.It is also used as a street name for LSD.
  • The common name for abrus precatorius plant is ' gunjaa' or 'ratti'.
  • White lady is the street name for both cocaine as well as heroin due to white powder like appearance. (read heroin as heroine and think of lady )
  • Hunan hand syndrome,is a form of painful contact dermatitis, which is usually seen in people with continuous and prolonged exposure to chili peppers. The main ingredient in chili peppers is capsaicin. (think of burning feeling in HAND because of chilli )

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the urology clinic for follow-up of an undescended right testicle discovered in the newborn nursery. Examination shows the absence of a palpable right testis in the scrotal sac. However, a round mass is palpated superior to the scrotum in the inguinal canal. Orchiopexy is recommended to the family. During this procedure, the malposition testis will most likely be pulled through a physiologic opening in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Testicles develop in the fetal abdomen during organogenesis Between 8 weeks and full term, each testis descends from the abdomen into the inguinal canal through the deep inguinal ring, which is an opening in the transversalis fascia bounded laterally by the transversus abdominis muscle and medially by the inferior epigastric vessels. Each testis then passes anteromedially through the canal and enters the scrotum via the superficial inguinal ring, which is a physiologic opening in the external oblique muscle aponeurosis above the pubic tubercle.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of one or both testes to descend to the scrotum before birth which occurs, more commonly in preterm neonates. It is associated with a significantly increased risk of testicular cancer and infertility. A testis that is palpable in the inguinal canal typically descends spontaneously by age 6 months. Testes that have not descended by this point are unlikely to do so and require surgical intervention (i.e. Orchiopexy).

In this case, the patient's undescended testicle is lodged within the inguinal canal and must be mobilized through the superficial inguinal ring and stitched into place in the scrotum.

(OptionA) the conjoint tendon is the common tendon of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles. It forms part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

(Option C) The femoral ring is a physiologic opening between the abdominal cavity and the femoral canal. It transmits lymphatic vessels but not the spermatic cord.

(Option D) The internal oblique muscle aponeurosis contributes to the formation of the conjoint tendon and rectus muscle sheath in addition the premaster muscle originates from the internal oblique muscle itself.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presented with histologically proved endometrial hyperplasia 2 years back. At present, she has complaints of excessive bleeding PV and CT scan shows a mass lesion in the uterus. The endometrial biopsy was taken which is shown below. Based on the histological features, Identify the type of tumor:
questions.solution:
Endometrioid adenocarcinomas demonstrate glandular growth patterns resembling normal endometrial epithelium.

There are three histologic grades:

  1. well-differentiated (grade 1), composed almost entirely of well-formed glands;
  2. moderately differentiated (grade 2), showing well-formed glands mixed with areas composed of solid sheets of cells, which by definition make up 50% or less of the tumor; and
  3. poorly differentiated (grade 3), characterized by greater than 50% solid growth pattern. 

*Well-differentiated tumors may be distinguished from hyperplasias by lack of intervening stroma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, headache and vomiting for 1 week. He had recently gone diving during his vacation. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. His CSF on wet mount microscopy revealed a motile unicellular microorganism. What is the most likely organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Naegleria fowleri

  • This is a case of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting.
  • The most likely organism is Naegleria fowleri:
  1. Acute and fulminating primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is caused by Naegleria fowleri.
  2. Clinical features of N. fowleri are typical of meningitis with rhinitis. The key to diagnosis is clinical suspicion based on the recent history of swimming or diving in warm waters.

Other Options:

Option B: Acanthamoeba castellani

  • Acanthamoeba species have been isolated as etiologic agents in Acanthamoeba keratitis, A. castellanii, and A. polyphagia.

Option C: E.histolytica

  •  E. Histolytica usually causes diseases such as granulomatous amebic encephalitis and ulcerative keratitis.

Option D: Ent. Coli

  • E. histolytica and Entamoeba coli do not cause meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: In a 28-year-old woman with endometriosis, what is considered the gold standard investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A :

  • The patient has presented with infertility, menorrhagia and a fixed pelvic mass. There can be 2 main diagnoses here, Endometriosis and Tuberculosis.
  • Menorrhagia is common with early tubercular endometritis but in this question, there is a history of an abdominal mass and its likely a chronic presentation.
  • Endometriosis is a condition of estrogen access and is frequently associated with menorrhagia.
  • A laparoscopy is the best tool to diagnose endometriosis and also to take biopsies to confirm/rule out Tuberculosis

Option B : Tubal microsurgery is done in patient with infertility with diagnosed tubal factor.

Option C : Anti-tubercular drugs are given for pelvic TB, which is less likely the case here as explained above, also the first step here would be to diagnose the pathology by laparoscopy

Option D : Hysterectomy is not an option here as she is a case of infertility with an uncertain diagnosis. Only in women with complete family history and those not responding to medical treatment with severe symptoms, are treated with hysterectomy as a last resort.

questions.text: As part of an experiment, radiolabelled ATP is injected into skeletal muscle. During muscle contraction, the radiolabelled ATP enters into the sarcomere. Which of the following activity will happen caused by the attachment of ATP?

choices.text: Detachment of myosin head from actin
Displacement of tropomyosin causes exposure of active sites on actin

questions.solution:
• Detachment of myosin head from actin. In skeletal and cardiac muscles, attachment of ATP causes detachment of myosin head from actin.
  • Hydrolysis of ATP causes a conformational change that resets the myosin head into a “high energy, high affinity” state and if calcium is available and active sites on actin are exposed, it will bind with the next active site on actin.

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut while using this instrument except:

choices.text: Transverse perineal branch of pudendal vessels and nerves

questions.solution:
The given image shows Busch’s Episiotomy Scissors

  • Length 16cm
  • Sterilized by glutaraldehyde (Cidex)
  • The shape allows easy introduction into the vagina and prevents erratic cutting
  • The angle prevents butting of the instrument against the patient’s buttocks

4 types of incisions:

  • Midline
  • Mediolateral (most common)
  • Lateral
  • J shaped

Structures cut

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Fascia covering the muscles
  • Transverse perineal branch of pudendal vessels and nerves

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of the onset of fainting spells. A heart murmur is heard on auscultation of the heart. An echocardiogram shows a primum type atrial septal defect. Failure of which of the following processes is the most likely cause of these findings in this patient?

choices.text: Ostium primum formation within the septum primum
Ostium secundum formation within the septum primum
Septum primum fusion with the endocardial cushions
Septum primum fusion with the septum secundum

questions.solution: • • The septum primum, the first interatrial septum, develops by growing from the cranial end of the embryonic atrium towards the endocardial pillows. This space that exists between the two atria during this time is the ostium primum. As the septum primum continues to grow towards the endocardial pad, the ostium primum becomes smaller. When the septum primum grows completely and fuses with the endocardial cushions, the ostium primum closes. • When the septum primum cannot fully fuse with the endocardial cushions, a persistent ostium primum, known as a primum-type atrial septal defect, develops. The endocardial pillows are also involved in the formation of the mitral and tricuspid valves and part of the interventricular septum.For this reason, ostium primum atrial septal defects (ASD) are often associated with a malformation of these structures. • Also keep in mind that ostium primum defects are often associated with Down syndrome

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Her symptoms started soon after a road traffic accident 6 months ago. The blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg with no postural drop. The daily urinary output is 6-8 liter. Investigation showed Na = 130 mEq/L, K = 3.5 mEq/L urea = 15 mg/dl, creatinine-0.8mg/dL, sugar = 65 mg/dl. The plasma osmolality = 268 mosm/L and urine osmolality = 45 mosm/L. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In the setting of RTA followed by polyuria and polydipsia the probable diagnosis points to a vasopressin-related cause. This is further enhanced by mention of normal BP and 8 liters of urine per day.

Lab interpretation of data given in the question

Sodium Low (normal)=135-145 mEq/dl
Potassium Normal (normal = 3.5-5.5 mEq/dl)
Plasma osmolality Low (285-295 mosm)
Urine osmolality Low (100-900 mosm)
Urea Normal (15-40 mg%)

Interpretation

  1. In DI, urine osmolality is low while plasma osmolality is high. Thus choices A and B are ruled out.
  2. Resolving ATN is ruled out on clinical grounds and given the normal renal function parameters
  3. The clinical information plus lab picture points to the diagnosis of psychogenic polydipsia (low serum and urine osmolality).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has developed increased facial hair and acne for the last 5 months. She has noticed deepening of her voice and clitoris enlargement. On physical examination her height is 170 cm, weight is 95kg, BP=130/75 with abdominal obesity. There is no evidence of striae or bruising. All of the following would be important steps in the clinical assessment of the patient, except?
questions.solution:
• The clinical history is of hirsutism and development of virilization process due to changes in voice.
  • Virilisation indicates ovarian or adrenal source of DHEAS.
  • Hormonal evaluation of testosterone and DHEAS hence becomes logical.
  • Family history is important as in some families’ hirsutism can be seen.
  • USG for ovary evaluation is an insensitive test for diagnosis as polycystic ovaries can be found without any androgen excess or females can have androgen excess while ovaries are normal.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with a flat red rash on the face and upper trunk and an erythematous rash on the knuckles and in the shape of a V on the neck and anterior chest. She also complains of muscle weakness with difficulty getting out of a chair and combing her hair. Laboratory findings include increased creatine phosphokinase, positive antinuclear antibody, and anti-Mi2 dermatomyositis-specific antibodies. In addition to oral prednisone, physical therapy is ordered with the goal of improving muscle strength, and thus able to perform activities of daily living. How does repetitive stimulation of a skeletal muscle fiber cause an increase in contractile strength?

choices.text: By increasing the concentration of calcium in the myoplasm
By increasing the duration of cross-bridge cycling
By increasing the magnitude of the end-plate potential
By increasing the number of muscle myofibrils generating tension

questions.solution:
Each time a skeletal muscle fiber is stimulated by an α-motoneuron

⇓

Ca2+ is released from its SR to fully activate all the troponin within the muscle.

⇓

Every cross-bridge can contribute to the generation of tension.

  • However, the transmission of force from the cross bridges to the tendon does not occur until the series elastic component (SEC) of the muscle is stretched.
  • Repetitive firing increases the amount of SEC stretch by maintaining cross-bridge cycling for a longer period of time.
  • Repetitive firing increases neither the concentration of Ca2+ within the myoplasm, the number of myofibrils that are activated, nor the magnitude of the end-plate potential.
  • Because all of the cross-bridges are activated each time a skeletal muscle fiber is activated, an increase in Ca2+ concentration would have no effect on muscle strength.
  • The skin findings, along with limitation in rising from a seated position or combing hair, are suggestive of proximal muscle weakness, characteristic of dermatomyositis

questions.text: A 25-years-old male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, there is a pelvic fracture and blood at the urethral meatus. All of the following are true about the patient except:

choices.text: Anterior urethra is the most likely site of injury
Retrograde urethrography should be done after the patient is stabilized
Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the retrograde urethrographyis normal
Rectal examination may reveal a large perineal hematoma

questions.solution:
The urethra is not a common source of urologic trauma and injury due to external violence accounts for approximately 4% of all genitourinary injuries.

Broadly the urethra is divided into the anterior and posterior segments

  • The anterior segment of the urethra most commonly injured is the bulbar urethra which accounts for 85% of urethral injuries. The male anterior urethra may be injured at the time of penile injury
  • Approximately 3% to 6% of posterior urethral injuries are associated with pelvic fracture, the so-called pelvic fracture urethral injury

The classic triad is :

  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Inability to void urine
  • Palpably distended bladder

Perineal or butterfly hematoma occurs due to the rupture of Buck fascia. On digital rectal examination, a high riding prostate may be noted

In patients with suspected urethral injury, retrograde urethrography should be performed before the insertion of a Foley catheter. Extravasation of contrast material occurs when continuity of the urethra has been lost because of the injury

Posterior urethral injuries should be managed with suprapubic catheter insertion rather than by instrumentation of the traumatized urethra with risk of further injury.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child was posted for herniotomy under caudal anaesthesia. The child was positioned in the left lateral position, and the area was painted and draped. The anesthesiologist used a 22G needle to enter the caudal canal through the sacral hiatus. While performing, they got a distinct pop entering the caudal canal and gave 1ml/kg of 0.25% bupivacaine. What structure was pierced when they got the pop?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sacrococcygeal membrane

  • The sacrococcygeal membrane is the structure that provides resistance when penetrating the caudal canal.
  • Caudal anesthesia is commonly used in pediatric anesthesia and is especially beneficial when a sacral anesthetic distribution is needed (e.g., perineal, anal, and rectal procedures).
  • The sacral hiatus must be identified for caudal anesthesia. The sacrococcygeal ligament (a ligamentum flavum extension) covers the sacral gap between the two sacral cornua. To help find the cornua, locate the posterior superior iliac spines and approximate the placement of the sacral hiatus by utilizing the line between them as one side of an equilateral triangle.
  • After identifying the sacral hiatus, the palpating hand's index and middle fingers are placed on the sacral cornua, and the caudal needle (or Tuohy needle if a catheter is implanted) is inserted at an angle of roughly 45 degrees to the sacrum. When the needle advances, the resistance to needle insertion should reduce as the needle reaches the caudal canal. The needle is then redirected to reduce the insertion angle relative to the skin's surface.

Option A: Obturator foramen

  • Obturator nerve blocks (ONB) are commonly used to prevent sudden thigh adduction during transurethral resection of bladder tumour (TURBT), to provide optimal analgesia for knee surgery, to treat chronic hip pain, and to improve persistent hip adductor spasticity in patients with paraplegia, multiple sclerosis, or cerebral palsy.
  • The traditional method is making three successive needle movements until the tip of the needle is positioned above the top of the obturator foramen, where the nerve flows before dividing into two terminal branches. The skin is punctured perpendicularly with a 22-gauge, 8-cm-long needle, and the needle is advanced until it makes contact with the inferior border of the superior pubic branch at a depth of 2-4 cm.
  • The needle can be guided 45 degrees laterally to the obturator foramen after establishing contact with the pubic branch.

Option C: Dura mater

  • The dura mater is punctured during spinal anesthesia.
  • The drug is administered into the subarachnoid space in spinal anesthesia, combining with CSF to produce a thick and homogeneous level block.
  • Layers are pierced in the following sequence for spinal anesthesia are Skin→ Subcutaneous fascia → Supraspinatus ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Dura meter→ Arachnoid mater → Subarachnoid space (return of CSF)

​​​​​​​Option D: Ligamentum flavum

  • Ligamentum flavum is pierced in both spinal and epidural anesthesia. 
  • In the case of epidural anesthesia, the needle is stopped there, but in spinal anesthesia, the needle is advanced and pierces the dura and arachnoid mater until it reaches the subarachnoid space.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A child is found to have 5 to 7 hypopigmented birthmarks (all about 1-2 cm). Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is suspected and confirmed by genetic testing. Which of the following is useful as a part of the recommended clinical management for patients with TS?
questions.solution:
• Patients with tuberous sclerosis (TS) may have seizures, mental retardation, adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), shagreen patch, hypomelanotic macules, periungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipomas, and cardiac rhabdomyomas.
  • These patients have an increased incidence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant-cell astrocytomas (SEGA). Hence, MRI study of the brain is essential in all patients with TS.
  • Patients frequently require anticonvulsants for seizures.
  • SEGAs do not always require therapeutic intervention, but the most effective therapy is with the mTOR inhibitors sirolimus or everolimus, which often decrease seizures as well as SEGA size.

questions.text: A 2 months old child who was born by normal delivery to a primigravida lady, presented with hoarseness and below finding on laryngoscopy. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Caused by human papilloma DNA virus (type 6 and 11)
13-cis-retionic acid has no used in the management
Presents with hoarseness and respiratory difficulty

questions.solution:
Juvenile papillomatosis (Respiratory papillomatosis)

  • Most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children
  • Caused by human papilloma DNA virus type 6 and 11.
  • Affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus.
  • Affect supraglottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea, and bronchi.
  • Children who had tracheostomy are at a higher incidence
  • Presents with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment

    • Microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament.
    • Interferon-alpha-2a
    • 13-cis-retinoic acid
  • Recurrence is common

ADULT – onset papilloma :

  • Single
  • Smaller in size
  • Less aggressive
  • Does not recur after surgical removal
  • Treatment is the same as for the juvenile type

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe daytime sleepiness and random episodes of falling asleep during the day for short periods. When he wakes up from these episodes, he feels refreshed. He sleeps 6–7 hours at night. He reports that sometimes he cannot move for a few minutes when he first wakes up in the morning. Last week, he suddenly "lost control" of his legs and neck for about 30 seconds after his classmate had told him a joke. An analysis of this patient's cerebrospinal fluid is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon shown here is Cataplexy.

  • Cataplexy is a sudden loss of muscle tone due to which patient can even fall. It is seen in Narcolepsy
  • Catalepsy and catatonia is seen in schizophrenia

HOW TO REMEMBER :lexy is with lepsy. catap-lexy is seen in narco-lepsy.

questions.text: Different tests can help to diagnose nerve lesions. A card test involves measuring the ability of the patient to hold a card between the fingers, as shown below. The nerve evaluated by this method is most likely to be injured at which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Option D: Medial epicondyle (humerus) fracture

  • The structure tested in this image is injured in a Medial epicondyle (humerus) fracture.

Card test:

  • Fracture of medial epicondyle humerus may be associated with ulnar nerve injury.
  • For palmar interossei (adductors) of the fingers.
  • Examiner inserts a card between fingers, and the patient is asked to hold it as tightly as possible while the examiner tries to pull the card out.
  • The power of adductors can thus be judged.
  • In the case of weak palmar interossei, it is easy to pull out the card.
  • The first dorsal interosseus muscle can be separately examined by asking the patient to abduct the index finger against resistance.

Option A: Fracture lower 1/3rd humerus

  • Fracture of lower 1/3rd of humerus leads to Radial nerve injury.

Option B: Supracondylar humerus fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture of humerus: Posterior fat is elevated. “Fat pad sign”
  • Fracture is displaced: Distal fragments go posteriorly Extension

Option C: Monteggia fracture

  • Fracture Ulna with radial dislocation

questions.text: After undergoing a partial cystectomy for carcinoma of the rectum, a 76-year-old woman develops a vesicovaginal fistula. The repair will have a higher chance of success if which of the following occurs?

choices.text: The bladder wall is closed under tension
Repair is performed more than 6 months after the causative operation
Repair is performed within 7–14 days of the onset of symptoms

questions.solution:
• Repair of the vesicovaginal fistula is recommended after enough time has passed, to allow a reduction in the inflammatory reaction and even spontaneous closure to occur.
  • To promote spontaneous closure, a Foley catheter is inserted for bladder drainage. It is advised to perform meticulous repair, excision of the previous fistulous tract, and tension-free anastomosis. Frequently an omental interposition helps to separate overlapping suture lines.

questions.text: Which nerve structure is involved in innervation of the first part of the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Option A: Greater splanchnic nerve

  • This patient has presented with dyspepsia and severe epigastric pain relieving mostly after meals or with antacids suggestive of duodenal ulcers.
  • The suggestive symptoms of the pain of duodenal ulcers are relief with a meal resulting in weight gain, nocturnal pain, prolonged use of NSAIDs and a history of treatment for H. pylori.
  • Duodenal ulcers commonly occur in the duodenum's first part or at the duodenal bulb.
  • Both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves supply the first part of the duodenum.
  • The sympathetic supply is mainly by the greater splanchnic nerve (T5-T9) that also carries pain sensations, while the parasympathetic is via the Vagus nerve.
  • The sympathetic nerve fibres travelling via the greater splanchnic nerve are the branches of the celiac plexus that originate from the fifth to the twelfth thoracic spinal segments.
  • These pre-synaptic fibres synapse in the celiac and superior mesenteric ganglia.
  • The post-synaptic sympathetic nerve fibres are distributed to the duodenal wall by following the branches of the celiac trunk
  • Pain arising from the first part of the duodenum cannot be localised well. Therefore, it is referred to as epigastrium.
  • Hence, the pain of duodenal ulcers is mediated by afferent fibres accompanying the sympathetic nerve fibres, mainly the greater splanchnic nerve.

 

Option B: Ventral roots of the spinal nerve

  • The ventral or anterior roots of spinal nerves contain efferent nerve fibres that carry stimuli away from the central nervous system towards the target structures. Motor neurons mostly control skeletal muscles. It does not carry pain sensation from the viscera to the brain.

 

Option C: Lower intercostal nerve

  • Lower intercostal nerves (T7-T11) course through corresponding intercostal spaces and supply the parietal peritoneum, abdominal wall muscles, and the skin of the anterior abdomen.

 

Option D: Lesser splanchnic nerve

  • The lesser splanchnic nerve is formed by the 9th and 10th rami (sometimes the 10th and 11th) thoracic ganglia.
  • It courses lateral and parallel to the greater splanchnic nerves, anteriorly to the spine, pierces the diaphragm and enters the abdomen.
  • The post-synaptic fibres of the lesser splanchnic nerve modulate the activity of the mid-gut and the enteric nervous system.

questions.text: An 82-year-old male patient with chronic diabetes mellitus has infected wounds on the lower part of the leg. The patient and his family opted for self-treatment with maggots. The maggots that can be used for wound therapy are?
questions.solution:
Maggots for Wound Debridement
  • Maggots can either feed only on dead tissue, only on living tissue or both on living & dead tissue.
  • The infestation by maggots of live animals is called myiasis.
  • The flies used most often for the purpose of maggot therapy are blow-files of Calliphoridae.
  • The blow fly species used most commonly is Lucilia sericata, the common green bottle fly.

questions.text: A 25-year-old unconscious patient is brought to the ER. On examination his BP = 140/90 mm Hg, pulse rate is 88/minute, respiratory rate is 10/min, body temperature is 96º F, and has pinpoint pupils. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
• The keyword in the question is pinpoint pupils which narrows the choices to A and B.
  • Pontine hemorrhage has pinpoint pupils but is associated with hyperthermia and is ruled out.
  • Sepsis will have tachycardia and tachypnea. Metabolic encephalopathy will have pupils showing a poor reaction to light.

Clinical Pointers in the question for diagnosis of 'Opioid Poisoning' are:

  1. Respiratory rate on the lower side
  2. Pin-point pupils
  3. Hypothermia
  4. Young age
  5. Absence of focal deficit like quadriparesis

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of spots, and red bumps that are located principally on the proximal cheeks, central chin, nose, and central forehead. It gets aggravated by sun exposure. On examination, telangiectasias are seen on the cheeks. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rosacea

  • The given clinical scenario is Rosacea, as it gets aggravated on exposure to sunlight, redness is seen on face convexities, and telangiectasia is present.
  • Common chronic inflammatory dermatosis.
  • Symptoms present in various combinations and severity, often fluctuating between periods of exacerbation and remission.
  • The trigger factors are hot weather, hot drinks, stress, spicy food, and nicotine.
  • Symptoms present in various combinations and severity, often fluctuating between periods of exacerbation and remission.
  • It causes blushing and visible blood vessels in the face.

Rosacea has 4 subtypes:

  • Subtype 1: Erythematotelangiectatic Rosacea (ETTR)
    • Characterized by transient facial erythema (flushing), combined with a background of persistent centrofacial erythema, with telangiectasia also present in most patients.
  • Subtype 2: Papulopustular rosacea (PPR)
    • It presents with variable intensity of central facial erythema and a variable number of small erythematous papules and pustules.
  • Subtype 3: Phymatous Rosacea (PR)
    • Most commonly affects the nose (rhinophyma) and presents with tissue hypertrophy manifesting as skin thickening and hyperplasia of sebaceous glands.
  • Subtype 4: Ocular Rosacea (OR)
    • Nonspecific complaints of dryness, gritty sensations, tearing, itching, as well as frequent styes. More active ocular Rosacea presents as blepharitis, often with conjunctival injection, lid margin telangiectasia, chalazion, or hordeolum formation.

Option A: Polymorphic light eruption:

  • It’s the commonest photosensitive disorder.
  • Characterized by an intermittent eruption of non-scarring erythematous papules, vesicles, or plaques.
  • Itching and burning sensation that develops within hours of ultraviolet radiation exposure to the patient skin - mainly on the neck and upper back.

Option B: SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus)

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing tissue damage and inflammation.
  • The characteristics features of SLE are:
    • Malar rash - characterized by an erythematous rash over the cheeks and nasal bridge and spares nasolabial fold.
    • It lasts from days to weeks and is occasionally painful or pruritic.
    • Photosensitivity - unusual rash or symptom exacerbation after sun exposure.
    • Discoid rash - develop in sun-exposed areas but are plaque-like in character, with follicular plugging and scarring.

Option C: Acne vulgaris:

  • It is a disorder of the pilosebaceous unit.
  • Clinical lesions include comedones, papules, pustules, cysts, and abscesses.
  • Comedones are pathognomonic of acne vulgaris.

questions.text: A patient presented with bulging right eye with restriction of right eye movements. On examination, the corneal sensations were also found to be decreased. The left eye had no bulging but there was limitation of abduction in the left eye. What is the likely scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely event is that the right orbit was first involved, which gradually progressed to cavernous sinus, and the pathology crossed to the left side and involved the 6th nerve of left cavernous sinus.

Othe options:

  • Superior orbital fissure syndrome and Orbital apex syndrome are unilateral and do not involve the other eye.
  • Pseudotumor is an inflammatory condition of orbit, but corneal sensations are not decreased.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to prepare charts on various national programme to create awareness among the village population. Which of the following Statement is true with respect to program given below?

choices.text: Deworming of children 5-9 yr with Albendazole 400 mg – 2 tablets
IFA supplementation in 5-9 yr. Iron (45), FA (500) Weekly → Pink tablet
IFA supplementation 10-19 Adolescents Iron (60), FA (500). Weekly → Blue tablet
IFA Supplementation of 6-59 months children, Iron (30mg) FA (200mg) Biweekly → Bottle 50 ml.

questions.solution:

- Its aim is to decrease prevalence of anemia by 3% points / yr among children, adolescents & women in reproductive age group [15-49yrs] b/w yr 2018-22
