questions.text: The following microscopic appearance is that of a tumor commonly involving the cerebellopontine angle. What does the histopathology show?
questions.solution:
Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it, a feature that simplifies surgical excision.

Grossly, these tumors form firm, gray masses. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles.

Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies. In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

questions.text: An 11-year-old female in the school was brought to the principal by a teacher who stated that she is always crying, unattentive, and not taking interest in any activity. On further investigation, the girl told that she was inappropriately touched by her uncle in private parts at her home. To whom should the Principal report next?
questions.solution:
Option C: Police

  • Reporting the offense to the police is mandatory.
  • Failure to report attracts punishment with imprisonment of up to 6 months or a fine or both.
  • Section 19 of the POCSO Act, 2012 provides a mandatory report of child sexual offenses to the Special Juvenile Police Unit or the local police.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the weak leg straight. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Hoover’s Sign

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of con­tralateral limb against resistance.
  • Method: Examiner places one hand under the heel of normal limb and contralateral hip flexion is done by the patient against resis­tance.

Interpretation

  • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb→heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
  • Functional Weakness: Heel does not push down i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

Other options:

-O’DONOGHUE’S MANEUVER FOR CERVICAL SPINE

  • Structures affected: Cervical spinal muscles and/or cervical spinal ligaments.
  • Since the resisted range of motion mainly stresses muscles and passive range of motion mainly stresses ligaments, you should be able to determine between strain and sprain or a combination thereof.

O’Donoghue’s Maneuver for Knee joint

This maneuver can be used to diagnose meniscal pathologies in the knee.

O’Donoghue Triad

Note: The medial structures medial (tibial) collateral ligament (MCL) and medial capsular ligament are first to fail, followed by ACL tear if the force is of sufficient magnitude. The medial meniscus may be trapped between condyles and have a peripheral tear, thus producing unhappy triad of O’Donoghue.

Fig. O’Donoghue triad

- WADDELL TEST

Tests of malingering

Each test counts as +1 if +, 0 if – Superficial skin tenderness to light pinch over wide area of lumbar spine Deep tenderness over wide area, often extending to thoracic spine, sacrum, and/or pelvis.

Low back pain on axial loading of spine in standing SLR test positive supine, but not when seated with knee extended to test Babinski reflex.

Fig. McMurray’s test—menisci

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his eyes, generalized fatigue, and pruritus. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 7 years ago. At the time of diagnosis, the PANCA test was also positive. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and multiple scratch marks on the trunk and extremities. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show a total bilirubin concentration of 3.2 mg/dL, direct bilirubin concentration of 2.5 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase level of 450 U/L. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography shows focal areas of intrahepatic bile duct strictures alternating with areas of dilation. Histologic examination of a liver biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Periportal lymphocytic infiltration and piecemeal necrosis
Irregular ductal glands lined by atypical and pleomorphic cells.
)Ductopenia and fibrotic degeneration of periportal hepatocytes

questions.solution:
Histopathology shows periductal concentric scarring and fibrosis showing characteristics of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis.

It is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments.

Ulcerative colitis coexists in approximately 70 percent of individuals and perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies.

Inflamed areas develop strictures because edema and inflammation narrow the lumen or because of subsequent scarring. The smaller ducts, however, often have little inflammation and show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen, eventually leading to obliteration by a “tombstone” scar

questions.text: A lady came with complaints of a bluish lesion over the left side of the cheek and left eye as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nevus of Ota:

  • Unilateral bluish-grey color discoloration.
  • Along with the ophthalmic and maxillary division of the Trigeminal nerve.

Other options:

Naevus of Ito - along the acromioclavicular nerve (neck)

Mongolian spots - Bluish discoloration in infants (MC site is lower back)

Becker’s nevus - Hyperpigmented path with hypertrichosis over the upper trunk

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presented with an enlarging lesion on the upper back of 3 years duration. She had multiple co-morbidities. On examination, there was a 4-cm diameter erythematous, shiny plaque. A punch biopsy showed superficial basal cell carcinoma. It was decided to treat her with imiquimod. What is the recommended treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Imiquimod is indicated 5 times per week for 6 weeks in superficial basal cell carcinoma.

Imiquimod

  • Imiquimod is an immune modulator that acts as a toll-like receptor TLR 7,8 agonists. It is used topically to treat warts on the genital and anal areas. But it does not cure warts, and new warts may appear during treatment. Imiquimod does not fight the viruses that cause warts directly, however, it controls wart production. Imiquimod is used in certain types of skin cancer called superficial basal cell carcinoma and is also used to treat a skin condition of the face and scalp called actinic keratoses.
  • Indication:
    Anogenital wart=3 times per week
    Actinic keratosis= 2 times per week
    Superficial BCC= 5 times per week

Learning objective:

  • Imiquimod is a synthetic imidazoquinolone amine with a potent immune response modifier activity. This characteristic property of imiquimod has led to its use in several applications in dermatology, especially in cutaneous malignancies like superficial BCC, where it is effective and safe. Imiquimod is used 5 times per week for 6 weeks in BCC.

questions.text: A 28-year-old presented to your clinic with a feature/ finding as shown below. Comment on the possible diagnosis in the patient?
questions.solution:
• Notice the visible neck pulsations indicating elevated JVP. Choice C and D are ruled out as they are left-sided lesions and usually do not lead to changes in JVP.
  • The confusion can be with dancing carotids of aortic regurgitation versus giant CV waves of Tricuspid JVP.
  • The dancing carotid produces an outward displacement and does not start from the base of the neck unlike the video shown in the question.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby is brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic with complaints of painful swelling of the leg and a history of fever for four days. He is diagnosed with a case of cellulitis. The doctor sends the patient's sample for further confirmation and a catalase test for the causative organism, the results of which are shown in the image below. Which condition is specifically associated with this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chronic granulomatous disease

  • The test shown in the image above is Catalase Positive Test.
  • Chronic granulomatous disease:
  • Predisposes to infection by organisms giving this test positive.
  • X-linked recessive defect in NADPH oxidase, resulting in an inability to form reactive oxygen compounds and decreased respiratory burst used to kill certain ingested pathogens.
  • Affected individuals will be more susceptible to catalase-positive organisms.
  • Nitro Blue Tetrazolium Test → Negative.
  • In infections caused by catalase-negative organisms (which lack catalase and do not break hydrogen peroxide), the host with CGD is successfully able to "borrow" hydrogen peroxide being made by the organism and use it to fight off the infection.
  • Hence, Catalase-negative pathogens like Streptococci and Pneumococci infections are not severe.

Option A: Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia

  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA).
  • Defect in B tyrosine Kinase gene
  • Failure of B-cell precursors (pro–B cells and pre–B cells) to develop into mature B cells: blocks B cell maturation.
  • Decrease immunoglobulins of all classes.
  • Normal Cell-mediated immunity.
  • Up to 6 months of neonatal life, nothing happens due to maternal Antibodies; after that, severe infection occurs.

Option C: Chediak Higashi syndrome

  • Autosomal Recessive with recurrent infections, partial albinism and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Defective phagolysosome fusion, defective chemotaxis.
  • Markedly decreased in melanocytes.

Option D: wiskott aldrich syndrome

  • X linked Recessive disease characterized by immunodeficiency with thrombocytopenia and eczema.
  • WASP gene defect.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented in the outpatient department 7 days ago with complaints of being irritable and fretful. His mother says the boy's hair is thin and easily pluckable. On examination, the boy has dry hair, sparse hair, emaciated arms and buttocks, and staring eyes. On anthropometry, he has a low height and weight for his age. He was admitted to the pediatric ward and is under treatment. His body weight was recorded daily. The child started to gain weight initially, but in the rehabilitation phase, there was a secondary failure to respond to the treatment. Which of the following is true regarding the same?

choices.text: Failure to regain appetite by day 4
Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day for consecutive days during the rehabilitation phase
Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

questions.solution:
Option C: Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day for consecutive days during the rehabilitation phase

  • The patient has a history of being irritable and fretful suggestive of poor psychosocial development and is also having thin, brittle hair. His examination and anthropometric findings are also suggestive of Marasmus.
  • The response to management in inpatient settings is assessed through close monitoring.
  • There can be a primary failure during phase 1 or the initial phase of management or a secondary failure.
  • Secondary failure occurs during the rehabilitation phase, i.e. when a child has a good appetite and weight gain.
  • Secondary failure to respond is indicated by failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day for consecutive days.
  • This can be due to poor neuromuscular coordination of muscles of the upper gastrointestinal tract, acute infection and refeeding syndrome.

Option A: Failure to regain appetite by day 4

  • Primary failure to respond is indicated by failure to regain appetite by day fourth.
  • The cause must be investigated and managed properly.

Option B: Presence of oedema on day 10

  • The presence of oedema on day 10th also indicates a primary failure.
  • This can increase morbidity and mortality to a significant extent.

Option D: Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

  • Failure to enter the rehabilitation phase or gain at least 5g/kg/day by the 10th day of the initial phase is a primary failure

questions.text: A doctor is taking a history from a diabetes patient and decides to make a chart to assess joint involvement. Which of the following chart is useful to do so?
questions.solution:
• A tree diagram is simply a way of representing a sequence of events along with their probabilities

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of generalized weakness & arthralgia and has developed rashes, as shown in the image below. He has no significant past medical history. Serological tests revealed Cryoglobulinemia. This can be associated with the?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hepatitis C

Hepatitis C is associated with Cryoglobulinemia.

The main clinical features of mixed cryoglobulinemia vasculitis include the triad of

  • Palpable purpura
  • Arthralgias
  • Weakness
  • Other pathological conditions such as glomerulonephritis, peripheral neuropathy, skin ulcers, and widespread vasculitis.

Other options

Option B: Ovarian Cancer

  • CA125 is known as a tumour marker for ovarian cancer. A tumour marker is a chemical given off by cancer cells that circulate in the bloodstream.
  • Women with ovarian cancer tend to have higher levels of CA125 in their blood than women who do not have ovarian cancer.

Option C: Diabetes mellitus

  • Type 2 diabetes is usually diagnosed using the glycated haemoglobin (HbA1C) test.
  • This blood test indicates your average blood sugar level for the past two to three months. Results are interpreted as follows: Below 5.7% is normal.

Option D: Leukaemia

  • Raised CSF LDH and CSF protein levels may indicate CNS involvement in patients with ALL.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents with a humerus fracture as shown in the figure below:

Which of the following nerve is likely to be involved by the fracture?
questions.solution:
* Radial nerve is involved in the distal part of the humerus it is called as Holstein-Lewis sign.

Humerus shaft fracture: The most common cause of delayed union or non-union is a distraction at the fracture site due to the gravity and weight of the plaster.

  • A spiral fracture of the distal third of the humerus is called a Holstein-Lewis fracture. It is frequently associated with radial nerve palsy.
  • Coaptation splint/hanging cast is used for non-operative management. Plating for treatment (usually) if surgery indicated.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male came with pain and watering in the right eye for 36 hours. On examination, a 3x2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins as shown in the figure. what is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above-shown image & features are suggestive of fungal keratitis, caused by Aspergillus.

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: Fungi are a group of microorganisms that have rigid walls and a distinct nucleus with multiple chromosomes containing both DNA and RNA. Though often evolving insidiously, fungal keratitis can elicit a severe inflammatory response – corneal perforation is common, and the outlook for vision is frequently poor.

Two main types of fungi cause keratitis:

  1. Yeasts (e.g. genus Candida), ovoid unicellular organisms that reproduce by budding, are responsible for most cases of fungal keratitis in temperate climates.
  2. Filamentous fungi (e.g. genera Fusarium and Aspergillus), multicellular organisms that produce tubular projections known as hyphae.

They are the most common pathogens in tropical climates, but are not uncommon in cooler regions; the keratitis frequently follows an aggressive course.

Symptoms

Gradual onset of pain, grittiness, photophobia, blurred vision, and watery or mucopurulent discharge.

  • Candidal keratitis: Yellow–white densely suppurative infiltrate is typical.
  • Filamentous keratitis: Grey or yellow–white stromal infiltrate with indistinct fluffy margins. Progressive infiltration, often with satellite lesions.
  • Feathery branch-like extensions or a ring-shaped infiltrate may develop. Rapid progression with necrosis and thinning can occur.
  • Penetration of an intact Descemet membrane may occur and lead to endophthalmitis without evident perforation.
  • An epithelial defect is not invariable and is sometimes small when present.

Other features include anterior uveitis, hypopyon, endothelial plaque, raised IOP, scleritis, and sterile or infective endophthalmitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with torticollis, a tender swelling behind the angle of mandible, and fever. He had h/o ear discharge for the past 6 years. On examination, purulent discharge and granulations in the ear canal are seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Acute lymphadenitis secondary to otitis externa

questions.solution:
History- This is a case of CSOM with purulent discharge that indicates attico antral disease.

  • The infection spread to the neck and other parts. This is an extra-temporal complication of CSOM.

Bezold Abscess

It occurs following acute coalescent mastoiditis when pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and it presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

  • C/F
    • Pain, fever, tender swelling in the neck, and torticollis. Onset is sudden
    • History of purulent otorrhoea.
  • Diagnosis
    • CT scan of the mastoid and swelling of the neck
  • Treatment
    • Cortical mastoidectomy
    • Drainage of abscess
    • I/V antibiotics

questions.text: Observe the clip shown below carefully. Which of the following diseases is associated with the features shown here?
questions.solution:
The above-shown features (INO) in the clip are associated with Multiple Sclerosis.

  • The pathway for horizontal gaze may be summarized as

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a defect of the horizontal gaze which is caused due
to the lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The MLF connects the sixth nerve
nucleus to the third nerve nucleus of the opposite side. Thus, in INO, during lateral gaze
the following features are seen:
• The adducting eye fails to move because the third nerve nucleus does not receive
any input
• The abducting eye moves laterally but suffers from abducting saccades
• Convergence is normal as the pathway for convergence is completely different.




Frontal lobe (right) – Left lateral gaze palsy

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic for his routine checkup. He complains of difficulty in arm lifting during his work. The strength of the muscle is tested using an empty can test as shown below. For which of the following muscle this test is done, and what is its nerve supply?
questions.solution:
Option C: Supraspinatus C5,C6

The test shown in the video is for Supraspinatus (C5, C6)

Empty can test: This tests the strength of Supraspinatus.

  • The patient is asked to raise his arms to a position of 900 abduction,300 of forward flexion, and internal rotation(thumbs pointing to the floor, as if emptying an imaginary can)
  • The examiner applies downward pressure on both arms while standing behind the patient. The patient resists the downward motion.
  • The result is positive; if the affected side is weaker than the unaffected side, the result is positive, and a tear of the supraspinatus tendon is likely to present.

Option A: Infraspinatus C6the, C7

  • For the infraspinatus test the patient is asked to externally rotate both forearms against the examiner's resistance.
  • The test is positive when there is weakness or pain in external rotation. Infraspinatus tears are usually painless so external rotation weakness strongly suggests an infraspinatus tear.

Option B: Subscapularis C5, C6

  • The most common tests of the subscapularis are the belly-press test, the belly-off sign, the bear-hug sign, the lift-off test, and the internal rotation lag sign.

Option D: Teres minor C6, C7

  • Hornblower's Sign is used for the teres minor tear.
  • To conduct the test has the patient in a sitting position with the arm abducted to 90° in the scapular plane. Flex the elbow to 90° and instruct the patient to perform external rotation against your resistance.
  • A positive test results in the inability of the patient to externally rotate in this position.

questions.text:
Case scenario:
A 22-year-old male presented with severe myalgias and backache of acute onset, opisthotonus, and convulsions. History of consumption of unknown leaves with suicidal intent.
Comment on the following Statements.
Statement 1: The most probable Poison could be nux vomica
Statement 2: The toxins acts on posterior horn cells of the spinal cord

choices.text: Statement 1 is true but statement 2is false
Statement 2 is true but statement 1 is false

questions.solution:
Opisthotonus & convulsions are suggestive of Nux- Vomica poisoning.

  • The toxin acts on anterior horn cells of the spinal cord
  • It antagonizes glycine.
  • Convulsions resemble tetanus.

questions.text: The forensic team has begun the autopsy of a 55-year-old man who became unconscious following a road traffic accident. A CT scan conducted six months prior to the injury had confirmed an aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery. Given this information, the forensic doctor decides to perform a cranial autopsy. Where should the incision in the scalp be started to proceed with the autopsy?

choices.text: In front of the ear lobe

questions.solution:
Option B: Behind the ear lobe

  • A coronal incision is made in the scalp, which starts from the mastoid process just behind one ear.

Option A: At occiput

  • A coronal incision is carried over the vertex of the scalp, not at occiput.

Option C: In front of the ear lobe

  • A coronal incision is made in the scalp, which starts from the mastoid process just behind one ear, not in front of the ear lobe.

Option D: At vertex

  • A coronal incision is made in the scalp, which starts from the mastoid process just behind one ear, and is carried over the vertex of the scalp to the back of the opposite ear (intermastoidal incision).

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient develops sudden left lower chest pain and epigastric pain after vomiting. The patient hass diaphoresis, breath sounds are decreased on the left, and there is abdominal guarding. How will you confirm your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are leading to the suspicion of esophageal rupture. The diagnosis can be confirmed with a contrast esophagogram which will demonstrate extravasation in 90% of patients.

Pain is a striking and consistent symptom and strongly suggests that an esophageal rupture has occurred, particularly in the cervical area following instrumentation of the esophagus or substernally in a patient with vomiting. Pain is often described as excruciating and frequently masquerades as a dissecting aneurysm, perforated ulcer, or myocardial infarction. If subcutaneous emphysema is present, the diagnosis is almost certain

Suspicion of esophageal perforation begins with symptoms of epigastric or chest pain, neck or throat pain, and dysphagia. Physical examination findings might include crepitus on the neck, chest, or face; neck swelling; epigastric tenderness; nasal voice or sometimes normal examination findings. Within the first 8 to 24 hours following injury, frank sepsis may develop if the contamination is extensive

Mediastinal emphysema, a strong indication of perforation takes at least 1 hour to be demonstrated and is present only in 40% of patients. Mediastinal widening secondary to edema may not occur for several hours

In cervical perforation, cervical emphysema is common and mediastinal emphysema is rare, the converse is true for thoracic perforation

If mediastinal pleura ruptures, pneumothorax appears rapidly

Etiology

Barotrauma (spontaneous perforation, Boerhaave’s syndrome) is a serious type of perforation which occurs due to an abrupt increase in intraluminal pressure of the esophagus during forceful emesis leading to full-thickness rupture of the esophageal wall. The condition was first identified by Boerhaave

Spontaneous rupture of the esophagus is associated with a high mortality rate because of the delay in recognition and treatment. Spontaneous rupture usually occurs into the left pleural cavity or just above the GEJ

The most common cause of esophageal perforation currently is iatrogenic injury following esophageal instrumentation, accounting for nearly 60% of all cases

Investigations

Initial screening evaluation is with a plain upright chest radiograph which may reveal a pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, subcutaneous or mediastinal emphysema, or mediastinal widening suggestive of perforation. But a normal X-ray does not rule out the possibility of a leak

Abnormalities of chest radiogram are dependent on three factors :

  • The time interval between perforation and radiographic examination
  • Site of perforation
  • The integrity of the mediastinal pleura

The diagnosis is confirmed with a contrast esophagogram which will demonstrate extravasation in 90% of patients. The use of water-soluble medium such as Gastrografin is preferred due to concern of exacerbating contamination if barium were used and leaked. 10% false-negative rate is noted. CT is another diagnostic modality that can be used

Management:

The principles of management after diagnosis include:

  • Treatment of contamination
  • Wide local drainage
  • Source control
  • Enteral feeding access

The most favorable outcome is obtained following the primary closure of the perforation within 24 hours, resulting in 80% to 90% survival. If the time delay before closing a perforation approaches 24 hours and the tissues are inflamed, division of the cardia and resection of the diseased portion of the esophagus is recommended

Cameron proposed three criteria for non-operative management of oesophageal perforation:

  • Perforation well contained in the esophagus
  • Symptoms should be mild
  • Minimal evidence of clinical sepsis

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the ophthalmologist due to bilateral eye pain for one day. It is not associated with any other symptoms. She has had a history of Type 2 diabetes for 20 years, which is controlled on metformin. Tonometry shows intraocular pressure of 22mmHg in the right eye and 25mmHg in the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely cause of eye pain in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased hydraulic resistance of trabecular meshwork
Increased hydraulic resistance of trabecular meshwork

questions.solution:
• This woman has open-angle glaucoma, which is the most common type of glaucoma.
  • Glaucoma is the second leading cause of blindness worldwide after cataracts.
  • Blindness occurs because of damage to the optic nerve.
  • The high intraocular pressure causes blood vessels and axons of the optic nerve to be compressed at the optic disc, which leads to poor nutrition with the possible death of the neurons.
  • The main cause of open-angle glaucoma is reduced flow of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork because of tissue debris, white blood cells, deposition of fibrous material, and other factors that increase the hydraulic resistance of the meshwork.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department after an automobile collision in which he suffered a fracture of the lateral border of the scapula. Six weeks after the accident, a physical examination reveals a weakness in medial rotation and adduction of the humerus. Which nerve was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
*Lower subscapular nerves arise from the cervical spinal nerves 5 and 6. It innervates the subscapularis and teres major muscles. The subscapularis and teres major are both responsible for adducting and medially rotating the arm. A lesion of this nerve would result in weakness in these motions.

- The axillary nerve also arises from cervical spinal nerves 5 and 6 and innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles. The deltoid muscle is large and covers the entire surface of the shoulder, and contributes to arm movement in any plane. The teres minor is a lateral rotator and a member of the rotator cuff group of muscles.

- The radial nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It is the largest branch, and it innervates the triceps brachii and anconeus in the arm.

- The spinal accessory nerve is cranial nerve XI, and it innervates the trapezius muscle, which elevates and depresses the scapula.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy, with his parents, visits the outpatient clinic displaying symptoms such as increasing lethargy, irritability, and pallor that have been developing since he was six months old. On examination, he was found to have significant pallor. Blood tests revealed a hemoglobin level of 7.8 gm%, with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 58 fL, mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) of 19.4 pg/cell, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is 59 dg/dL. His osmotic fragility test shows increased fragility of RBCs. The blood smear highlighted the presence of target cells and normoblasts. Additionally, an X-ray of the skull indicated erythroid marrow expansion. Based on these findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetic disorder of the red blood cell membrane. It leads to spherical-shaped red blood cells, which are less deformable and prone to hemolysis (breakdown). The hallmark findings include anemia, increased MCHC, spherocytes on the blood film, and a negative osmotic fragility test. An expansion of erythroid marrow can occur as the body tries to compensate for the anemia.

  • Given the presence of target cells, normoblasts, severe pallor, and an expansion of erythroid marrow along with normal osmotic fragility, hereditary spherocytosis is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Option A: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • In iron deficiency, severe anaemia is not seen.
  • Expansion of erythroid marrow is usually not seen

Option B: Acute lymphoblastic anaemia

  • Low MCV, no apparent involvement of other cell lines, and expansion of erythroid marrow are incompatible with the diagnosis of ALL.
  • The patient presents with fever, fatigue, shortness of breath, bleeding from gums, and frequent infections.

Option C: Hemoglobin D disease

  • Hemoglobin D is a type of hemoglobin variant. Individuals with Hemoglobin D disease may have mild anemia but typically do not exhibit the severe pallor, target cells, or normoblasts seen in this case.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented to the emergency room with dyspnea and thoracic pain after vomiting. On examination, he was tachycardic & hypotensive. CT scan revealed pneumomediastinum, left collapsed lung, and loculated pleural effusion. Crepitus was heard over the mediastinum. A left intercostal chest tube was inserted with food drainage. Which of the following is the most common site of tear of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lower end of the Esophagus

  • The clinical history & features are suggestive of Boerhaave syndrome, also known as spontaneous oesophageal rupture.
  • The most common site of tear is at the lower end of the oesophagus.

Boerhaave syndrome:

  • Boerhaave syndrome is defined as a transmural rupture of the distal oesophagus.
  • Sudden rise in intraluminal oesophageal pressure produced during vomiting or severe retching due to neuromuscular incoordination causing failure of the cricopharyngeus muscle to relax and is presented as severe retrosternal chest pain and mediastinal emphysema, crepitus heard over the mediastinum.
  • It is associated with overindulgence in food and alcohol.
  • At the left posterolateral wall of the lower third of the oesophagus, 2-3 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction, along the longitudinal wall of the oesophagus common site of rupture is in the subdiaphragmatic or upper thoracic area.

Option B: At a gastroesophageal junction.

  • Mallory Weiss syndrome is the non-transmural rupture at the gastroesophageal junction due to vomiting, retching or coughing. Longitudinal lacerations appear in the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Instrument perforation(iatrogenic) typically occurs in the hypopharynx or at the gastroesophageal junction.

Option C: Upper oesophagus.

  • The upper oesophagus is not the common site of rupture in Boerhaave syndrome.

Option D: Mid oesophagus.

  • The mid oesophagus is not the common site of rupture in Boerhaave syndrome.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology outpatient department due to a 'grey spot' in his visual field for 3 weeks. It is associated with recurrent fevers and weight loss for the last 3 months. He has had a history of mitral valve disease for 10 years. However, he does not take any medication for the disease. Physical examination reveals needle marks on his right forearm. Vision is found to be 6/6. Fundus examination shows the following findings:



Which of the following is correct about the findings shown in the image above?

choices.text: These are only seen in infective endocarditis.
They are characteristically associated with the severe general reaction of the surrounding retina.
These findings are more common in anaemia and leukaemia than in infective endocarditis.

questions.solution:
Option B: The picture demonstrates Roth’s spots.

  • The patient presents with clinical features of infective endocarditis.
  • The image above shows Roth’s spots or Litten's spots.
  • The pathogenesis of Roth’s spots involves rupture of retinal capillaries resulting in the extrusion of blood and subsequent platelet adhesion to the damaged endothelium.
  •  The resulting coagulation cascade results in a platelet-fibrin thrombus, resulting in the pale lesion appearing at the centre of the red bleeding lesion.
  • Roth’s spots are associated with:
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Leukaemia
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • HIV
  • Extreme hypoxia
  • Shaken-baby syndrome
  • Candida albicans infection
  • Kala-azar
  • Vascular diseases

Option A: These are only seen in infective endocarditis.

  • Roth’s spots are retinal haemorrhages seen in multiple systemic illnesses apart from infective endocarditis.

Option C: They are characteristically associated with the severe general reaction of the surrounding retina.

  • Roth spots are retinal haemorrhages due to septic emboli in infective endocarditis.
  • It is not associated with the general reaction of the surrounding retina.

Option D: These findings are more common in anaemia and leukaemia than infective endocarditis.

  • Roth spots are seen in about 80 % of cases of bacterial endocarditis.
  • Roth spots are also seen in conditions like anaemia and leukaemia, but they are rare.

questions.text:
A 12-years-old boy presented with midline neck swelling, moving well with deglutition, moves up on the protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following statements is/are incorrect about this condition :
1)Most common location is subhyoid
2)Congenital
3)Follicular carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients
4)Treated by Sistrunk operation which includes en-bloc removal of cyst along with the body of hyoid bone
5)They never recur after surgical removal
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a diagnosis of Thyroglossal Cyst:

→ Congenital

→ Most common location–Subhyoid

→ Thyroglossal cyst moves with deglutination

→ moves upon protrusion of tongue

→ Increased risk of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid

→ TOC– Sistrunk operation.

→ The cyst passes via the body of hyoid bone–so excision is made

→ Enbloc removal of central part or body of hyoid bone+cyst.

→ The most common complication of the Sistrunk procedure is a recurrence of the thyroglossal duct cyst, which occurs in about 10% of cases.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient, anemic for several years, complains of failing eyesight and hearing loss. On physical examination, it is determined that the patient has lost function of some of the cranial nerves. Which one of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteopetrosis is a genetic defect involving osteoclasts.

Persons with this defect possess osteoclasts without ruffled borders, which prohibit them from resorbing bone. Therefore, bone forms but is not resorbed. This leads to increased bone density, anemia, blindness, deafness, and cranial nerve involvement because the nerves are impinged upon as they exit the cranium via their foramina.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 18 weeks with complaints of right groin pain which worsens with movement and on straining and gets relieved by applying a heating pad, the pain has persisted for 3 days now. Her urine analysis is normal and her TLC is 8.6. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ROUND LIGAMENT PAIN is a pregnancy symptom that’s common during the second trimester and occurs due to stretching and spasm of the ligaments. It is usually felt on the right side but can be felt on the left side also.

The pain is typically relieved by applying hot pads. The differential diagnoses are inguinal hernia and appendicitis and to confirm ultrasound examination should be done.

The management is conservative in the form of hot fermentation, analgesics, and rest, and avoiding prolonged standing.

questions.text: Stool examination in a patient reveals the following finding .What is the likely route of infection of this parasite?

choices.text: Ingestion of food of contaminated with the egg of parasite

questions.solution:
• Adult Trichuris worm lives in the large intestine.
  • It resembles a whip. Anterior 3/5th is thin and posterior 2/5th is thick and stout, appearing as the handle of a whip.
  • The egg is triple-shelled, barrel-shaped with a mucus plug at each pole. It is bile-stained and contains an unsegmented ovum. The egg floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • Natural host: Man is the only host. No intermediate host.
  • Infective form: Embryonated egg-containing rhabditiform larva that develops in soil.
  • Clinical features: Light infection is asymptomatic. In heavy infection, the worm may give rise to acute appendicitis, abdominal pain, mucous diarrhea, anemia, prolapse of rectum, and weight loss.

Diagnosis: Finding of characteristic eggs in stool and sigmoidoscopy may show worms hanging from the rectal mucosa.

Treatment: Mebendazole or albendazole

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady presented with a history of painful abdominal complaints, bone pain, repeated painful fractures and severe fatigue with easy bruising and nose bleeds. Further examination and investigation showed hepatosplenomegaly with pancytopenia. On microscopic examination of bone marrow cells, crumpled tissue paper appearance is seen. Which product is likely to have accumulated?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glucocerebroside

  • Crumpled tissue paper appearance of cytoplasm + organomegaly and pancytopenia suggests storage disorder
  • Lysosomal storage of glucocerebroside (Gaucher disease) in cells of the monocyte-macrophage system leads to a characteristic cellular alteration of these cells
  • Gaucher cells - present in the bone marrow, spleen, lymph nodes, hepatic sinusoids, and other organs and tissues in all forms of GD.

Option B: Sphingomyelin

  • Niemann-Pick disease results from a deficiency of sphingomyelinase that causes the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the cells of the reticuloendothelial and central nervous systems. 
  • The disease is also characterized by the presence of foam cells, which are lipid-laden cells seen on biopsy.

Option C: Sulfatide

  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a rare hereditary disorder that causes lipids to build up in cells, particularly in the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nerves, due to the Deficiency of an enzyme that helps break down lipids called sulfatides. The brain and nervous system progressively lose function because the substance that covers and protects the nerve cells (myelin) is damaged.

​​​​​​​Option D: Ganglioside

  • Tay–Sachs Disease is caused by a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to a build-up of GM2 ganglioside within cells. Notably, the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside leads to the destruction of nerve cells. Signs and symptoms include neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and the appearance of onion-skin lysosomes on EM biopsy.

questions.text: The following Bone scan image findings may be seen in all of the following conditions EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Bone lesions are multiple, lytic, and rarely accompanied by an osteoblastic response. Thus, bone scans are less useful than radiographs.

  • The bone scan is showing several areas of uptake involving the skull, ribs, spine, pelvis, right femur, and acetabulum.
  • These hot spots may be seen in hyperparathyroidism, Paget's disease, and osteoblastic metastases.

In multiple myeloma, there is no osteoblastic activity, hence shows no uptake (cold spots).

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of weakness and coordination problems for the past 1 month. On physical exam, sensory disturbances, muscle weakness & visual disturbances are found. M.R.I. shows characteristic 'Dawson fingers' suggestive of Multiple Sclerosis. Which of the following statement is correct regarding Dawson's fingers?

choices.text: Perivenous Demyelination oriented perpendicular to the ventricular surface
Regenerating axons seen in juxtacortical area

questions.solution:
Option A: Perivenous Demyelination oriented perpendicular to the ventricular surface

  • M.S. Lesions are frequently oriented perpendicular to the ventricular surface, corresponding to the pathologic pattern of perivenous demyelination (Dawson's fingers).
  • Seen on Gadolinium-enhanced M.R.I.: In Periventricular (white mater area ) / Juxtacortical or Infratentorial (cerebellum)

 

  • Clinical presentation depends on where demyelinating plaques are located
  • cerebrum
    • unilateral motor or sensory deficits
  • brain stem
  • diplopia
  • nystagmus
  • intranuclear ophthalmoplegia: inability to adduct the eye on lateral gaze with a demyelinating lesion affecting the ipsilateral medial longitudinal fasciculus
  • vertigo
  • cerebellum
  • nystagmus
  • vertigo
  • impaired coordination
  • spinal cord
  • weakness or sensory changes
  • bowel and bladder dysfunction
  • Lhermitte sign: paresthesias that radiate down the arms or trunk with neck flexion​​​​​​​

Option B: Demyelinated axons in PNS

  • In multiple Sclerosis, the demyelination is in C.N.S., not in PNS

Option C: Regenerating axons are seen in the juxtacortical area

  • Axons are demyelinated in the juxtacortical area

Option D: Regenerating axons in PNS

  • MS lesions are demyelination in the C.N.S.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with Crohn’s disease had undergone resection of small bowel and anastomosis. Ten days later, he is found to have bilious drainage of 1 L/d from the drains. He is started on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Four days later, his arterial blood gases (ABGs) are pH, 7.25; PO2, 98 mm Hg; and PCO2, 40 mm Hg. His anion gap is 10. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

  • The normal value of anion gap is 10–15. Loss of bicarbonate (e.g., small-bowel fistula, pancreatic fistula, or diarrhea) and gain of chloride (e.g., administration of ammonium chloride or HCl and decreased excretion as in distal renal tubular acidosis) result in metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap.
  • In contrast, in acidosis due to increased production of an organic acid (e.g., Diabetic ketoacidosis(ketoacids), sulfur and phosphoric acid in renal failure, and lactic acid in shock), the anion gap is increased.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman has contracted malaria. Which of the following drugs should not be used by her?

Chloroquine
Primaquine
Quinine
Mefloquine

Select the ANSWER using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Malaria in pregnancy:

  • Maternal effects - anemia (megaloblastic, hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, jaundice, renal failure, pulmonary edema, respiratory distress, convulsion, and coma.
  • Effects on the fetus - due to high fever or placental parasitization. Diminished placental blood flow due to blocked intervillous space with macrophages and parasites. This is mostly due to P. falciparum in second-half pregnancy, complications (abortion, preterm labor, prematurity, IUGR, IUFD) are increased.
  • Management: prophylaxis - chloroquine (300 mg base) orally once a week. Treatment with chloroquine-10 mg base/kg PO followed by 10 mg/kg at 24 hours and 5 mg/kg at 48 hours. Radical cure - primaquine should be postponed. In case of resistance to chloroquine- quinine (10 mg salt/kg/PO every 8 hours for 7 days).

Folic acid 10 mg daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented with an ulcer in the genital area. Microscopic examination of cervical smear showed the following finding as shown below. Identify the causative agent:
questions.solution:
• Calymmatobacterium (Donovania) granulomatis is the causative agent of granuloma inguinale, a granulomatous disease, which involves the genital and inguinal part of the infected host.
  • It is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis) characterized by genital ulcers.
  • It is also known as donovanosis, granuloma genitoinguinale, granuloma inguinaletropicum, granuloma venereum.
  • The specimen is collected by scraping the border of the ulcerative lesion and making a smear on a glass slide.
  • The smears are stained with Giemsa or Wright stains.
  • In the stained smear, the body of the bacillus is stained blue and the capsule is stained pink.
  • Tetracyclines, erythromycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are effective for the treatment of the condition.
